name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would remind you that on 24 October 2019 I decided, under the Rules of Procedure, to fine Mr Ciocca, who had behaved aggressively and disrespectfully towards his colleagues and this institution, seriously violating a rule of conduct, during the debate on the Turkish military operation in north-east Syria on 23 October. On 6 November, Mr Ciocca lodged an appeal. At its meeting yesterday the Bureau considered the appeal and confirmed my decision. The penalty resumes from today.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council meeting of 12 and 13 December 2019 (2019/2722(SRR)). I would remind you that it is possible to submit requests for intervention in accordance with the catch-the-eye procedure and 'blue card' questions using both the 'standard registration' system and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance to the Hemicycle.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the December European Council will be marked by a change of the guards, so to speak. It will be the first meeting to be chaired by President Charles Michel and, pending your approval of the new Commission tomorrow, it will also be the first one for Ms Ursula von der Leyen in her capacity as President of the Commission, and for the new High Representative, Mr Josep Borrell. The agenda will be dominated by two pressing issues – climate change and the multiannual financial framework.  Let me start with climate change. You will all recall that in June the European Council came close to an agreement on climate neutrality by 2050. However, a few Member States felt they needed more time to assess the efforts and costs linked to the transition to climate neutrality before committing to such ambitious targets.  The European Council therefore asked the Council and the Commission to advance work on the conditions, incentives and the enabling framework, and pledged to finalise its guidance before the end of the year with a view to the adoption and submission of the EU’s long-term strategy to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in early 2020. In December, the European Council will aim to commit the EU to reaching climate neutrality by 2050 and identify the enabling framework that will allow us to reach that objective.  The Presidency has worked intensively with other Member States and the Commission in order to facilitate this decision. The discussion in this plenary yesterday again highlighted the need for the EU to act decisively in order to remain a world leader in climate issues.  This brings me to the second topic on the European Council agenda: the multiannual financial framework (MFF). The Finnish Presidency will submit a finalised negotiation box with figures prepared on the basis of the exchange of views that took place in Council preparatory bodies, as well as bilateral discussions with all delegations. We intend to submit the negotiation box in the coming few days.  We are nearing the end stage of negotiations. I believe it’s in all our interest to reach an agreement on the next MFF soon in order to make sure our citizens, regions, farmers, universities and other beneficiaries can continue their work uninterrupted. The Presidency’s job in this respect has not been easy, the individual positions being wide apart. With the Brexit cut. the status quo is not an option. We will have to pay more and, unfortunately, some will have to receive less. The leaders’ discussion therefore should identify the most important issues and prepare the ground for the future compromise.  I am glad to say we have had many fruitful exchanges with Parliament during the course of this process. In this plenary we have discussed the MFF already and I am glad that we could organise an informal breakfast discussion last week in Brussels between the Member States and the negotiations of the European Parliament. The Member States found this exchange useful and timely. Thank you very much for that.  Without going into full details of the Presidency’s proposal, I am pleased to note that the positions of Parliament and the Council converge in several important areas. First of all, the next MFF should be able to deliver on the policies set out in the strategic agenda – ambition on climate policy, commitment to just transition, increasing the investments to research and development and a comprehensive management of migration are just a few key policies the next MFF will be able to address.  As in the Commission proposal, the Presidency is committed to renewing and modernising the EU budget by giving modern programmes the largest share of EU funds. However, we also note the importance of cohesion policy to the unity and success of the Union, as well as the need to devote sufficient funds to our farmers so that they can continue to develop sustainable agriculture. The Presidency will also propose to make a strong link between protecting the EU budget from generalised deficiencies in the area of the rule of law, and furthermore new own resources should be decided in order to diversify the financing of the EU’s budget.  We have no illusions that there will be disappointments in our proposal. That is inevitable in a process seeking to find common ground. Not everybody can just get what they want, but it is our sincere belief that our proposal represents a balanced way forward. The European added value and our political priorities will guide us to deliver results over the next seven years.  The European Council will give further guidance to the Union on the way forward, with the objective of reaching a final agreement. It is furthermore possible that leaders will discuss certain external affairs issues in the light of developments on the international stage. In any event, following the Normandy Format Summit scheduled for 9 December in Paris, the European Council will assess progress in the implementation of the Minsk Agreements and decide whether to renew the economic sanctions against Russia for another six months. As we also mentioned, there will be a Euro Summit in an exclusive format to take stock of progress made in the Eurogroup on the implementation of the June Euro Summit statement.  Finally, Brexit will again be on leaders’ agenda. On Friday, the European Council is expected to have a short meeting in its Article 50 format. Leaders will discuss the next steps in light of recent developments.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. Mr President, I have to start by saying that this is the last time I come before you as stand-in for President Jean-Claude Juncker, and I want to use that opportunity to thank him for his leadership over five years. But most of all, from my perspective, to thank him for his friendship, for his wisdom, for his wit, his endless source of anecdotes. Jean-Claude is, what in the Jewish tradition is called, a mensch. And I will miss him, as I think we all will, and we owe him, I think, a big debt of gratitude for what he has done for Europe in the last five years. (Applause) Es ist unsere Chance und Verpflichtung zugleich, die Tagung des Europeischen Rates zu einem europeischen Thursday and Friday for Future zu machen. Wir sind es unseren Kindern schuldig, mit unserem Planeten sorgf-ltig umzugehen. Denn dieser ist die Grundlage fer unser go Zukunft. Europa hat sich deshalb als Beitrag zum 'beeinkommen von Paris dazu verpflichtet, die Treibhausgasemissionen in der EU bis 2030 um mindestens 40% zu reduzieren.  Doch Europa kann, will und muss mehr erreichen. Als European Kommission werden wir uns dafar einsetzen, dass der European Rat ein ehrgeizigeres Ziel beschliet. Europa sollte bis 2050 zu einem klimaneutralen Kontinent werden. Denn wir haben nicht nur Verantwortung fer die nechste Generation, sondern wir messen auch eine Vorreiterrolle in der Welt einnehmen. Unsere europeische Strategie muss ein Signal an die Klimakonferenz der Vereinten Nationen senden und andere Vertragsparteien ebenfalls zu ehrgeizigeren Zielen anspornen. Fer Europa er-ffnet dieser Ehrgeiz auch eine wirtschaftliche Chance. Schlie-lich bedeutet ein klimaneutrales Europa nicht, dass wir Industrie oder Autos abschaffen, sondern dass unsere Fahrzeuge und unsere Industrie zukunftsfit sein werden. Wenn wir jetzt auf gràne und innovative Technologien setzen, sichert das langfristig nicht nur unseren Planeten, sondern auch unsere Wirtschaft.  Es lohnt sich also fer Europa in jeder Hinsicht, Klima-Weltmeister zu werden. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, is it necessary to make it clear that our ambitions, however laudable and necessary, will remain a dead letter if we do not have sufficient financial resources to make them a reality? For example, to achieve the paris agreement alone, the European Union will have to unlock hundreds of billions of euros of additional investment every year until 2030. That is why we are committed to investing at least 25% of our next budget, in the long term, in climate issues, because it is our responsibility to ensure that there is no left behind in the transition to a more modern economy with a cleaner and cleaner European energy system. In Europe, this transition will be made, but for it to succeed, it must benefit all Europeans and promote social justice, economic, social and territorial cohesion and solidarity between member states and between generations. Our compass must be the future of our fellow citizens, our students, our businesses, our researchers, our regions, our cities and our countryside. This future is not waiting, time is running out. Any delay in the negotiations of the next European budget for the period 2021-2027 is increasingly likely to jeopardise the timely implementation of EU policies. The December European Council must therefore be an opportunity to give decisive impetus to these negotiations so that we can reach an agreement by February 2020 at the latest. In May 2018, this Commission chose a reasonable budget that represents 1.11% of the EU's gross national income at 27, foresees moderate cuts in the common agricultural policy and cohesion policy, and reflects the new policies that will determine our future. If we want money for research, the fight against climate change, the future of our young people, digital, better management of migration, there is no room for reductions. Let's be serious! How can it be surprising that, in the next budget of the European Union, national contributions are increasing because, in both cases, this is mainly due to inflation and economic growth? And how can we not accept that it would be much fairer for all to remove the rebates that some countries receive for historical reasons? Finally, let us not lose sight of the fact that the discussion on net balances is a false discussion because, with the European Union budget, everyone benefits, since we are doing together what we can no longer do individually. I would like to finish with a few remarks ahead of the Euro Summit. We can't talk about Europe's future - our efforts to ensure sustainability and the right budget to meet our citizens' needs - without the understanding that strengthening our economic and monetary union is a fundamental component for our success. The good news is that there is a consensus on the main elements needed to continue doing this and even better news because progress on this important work is well within reach. This includes the first-ever budgetary instrument for convergence and competitiveness in the euro area, the main features of which have now been agreed. Secondly, on the European Stability Mechanism, which by its very existence already increases resilience in the euro area, the legal framework still falls short of the political reality which must also include its role as a backstop to the Single Resolution Fund. And thirdly, on the completion of the banking union. On this last point, I would like to underline that when the banking union was launched, it was always going to be based on three looters: supervision, resolution and the third, missing looter - a European deposit insurance scheme. It has been four years since the Commission made a proposal and two years since we proposed pragmatic solutions to find a compromise between Parliament and the Council. Progress is long overdue. I want to welcome the ongoing work of the High—Level Working Group in this regard and, on behalf of the Commission and my colleagues Dombrovskis and Moscovici, I look forward to seeing an outcome of this work and an agreement on how to put this into practice. We may be subject to political cycles. I said something about this at the beginning. That is the nature of democracy. The same should not apply to our economy. Here we need to ensure stability. Over the last five years we've been deepening the Economic and Monetary Union, precisely because doing so is making our economy stronger and more resilient to stress. In the face of increasing pressure in our external environment, we need this resilience at home. We are before the biggest challenge humanity has ever faced and we need to prepare for it well.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work and for the work he has done I would like to begin by thanking Frans Timmermans for referring to Jean-Claude Juncker.  For us Christian Democrats, too, he is in line with De Gasperi, Schuman, Helmut Kohl and other strong Christian Democrats who have shaped Europe. I think we all wish him a good recovery now after the serious operation he has undergone. Changes are now also in the way of changes in the Council. We are getting a new President-in-Office of the Council, and perhaps in the first preparatory debate on the first Council meeting under Charles Michel we will be able to express a few wishes as to what might happen next. I would like, for example, to see a Council that is reliable for the citizens of Europe. The MFF discussion is at the heart of this. Millions of farmers, students and mayors expect clarity, expect planning certainty. That is why our aim now is to create urgency, not to postpone, postpone, postpone, in the hope that the German Presidency will resolve this. No, progress must be made in December, and the Croatian Presidency must then reach a solution at the beginning of the year: reliability. The second is that we need fairness. For us, this means that the next European Council should now give the green light to Northern Macedonia and Albania. What we experienced last time is a tragedy, a historic mistake. It is unacceptable that, on the one hand, we continue to hold accession talks with Turkey and, on the other, we should say to Northern Macedonia that it must not become a member of the European Union. That's crazy what we're doing. The citizens no longer understand this either. I would like the next European Council to speak plainly. In Malta, for example, a Member State of the European Union, we now have the fact that corruption is in the highest levels of government and is also associated with the death of journalist Daphne Galizia. That is what we are witnessing in Malta at the moment. Yesterday, the Labour Government in Malta prevented there from having a debate in the national parliament on these matters. That is not acceptable. I would like the Council to discuss issues such as those in Malta. I must also say that I was surprised to see president Macron's comments on Viktor Orban, because we have all activated Article 7 together and are concerned about what is happening in Hungary. I read in the newspaper that Macron says about Orban: 'I had a very long discussion on this subject' – so on the future of Europe – 'with Viktor Orban. He's quite close to our views and has a key intellectual and political role within the Visegrad Group, which is important'.  I would like to know from Renew how to deal with it. I would like the next European Council to finally discuss issues relating to Article 7 in Hungary. And that we should put this on the table, how to deal with fundamental rights in Europe in the future.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she I would also like to see another wish for the Council's deliberations, namely the CO2 debate. We in Parliament agree that we want to be ambitious. We are even proud that Europe has been the leading continent in the world – already in recent years. Now we want to be ambitious, but also realistic. The task we have is to achieve the goals, but not to leave people behind. On the one hand, there is respect for Greta Thunberg, who is the ambitious voice of the young generation. But there are also the yellow vest demonstrations, where people are worried that they cannot afford the higher fuel prices. And there is the fear of coal workers and car workers about how their industry will continue, whether their jobs are safe. Bringing this together is the task that Europe must tackle. Finally, I would like to see an ambitious proposal from the next European Council on the issue of foreign and security policy. That will dominate the next five years, so away with unanimity in the Council of Foreign Ministers, and an ambitious proposal on a defence union is needed.  I know that this is a wish list. I know that much of that will not happen. But let me say this: at the beginning of a new leadership in the European Council under Charles Michel, something will be allowed to be desired.

name: Eero Heinäluoma
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Council meeting in December will indeed be extremely important for the future development of the EU. It is also the first moment to move forward decisively with the commitments made at the last European elections. Hopefully, the new leadership of the Commission will have been able to start work by then and this summit – the European Council – will be a genuine new start to the work of the whole of the next five years. Climate change is an issue where Europe has already been a pioneer so far. But it is equally clear that it was the big demand of the European elections for all of us that we are capable of implementing a real programme for the transition to a carbon-neutral Europe. This is unquestionably the most important issue of the forthcoming European Council. We must listen to the citizens, and this change must be implemented in a fair way. It is therefore important that social justice is an important factor in responding to climate change when the Council discusses the necessary measures. There really is no more time to waste with regard to the financial framework. We must prevent a situation in which decisions are taken so late that many programmes do not have time to start. It is therefore time for the financial framework to make the necessary compromises. But here, too, it is important that we respond to new challenges. Action against climate change needs funding. Research, product development, building a new Europe requires funding.  European border guarding, which is an important part of our common security, also requires more resources. The same applies to the development of joint European defence cooperation. In all of these, we expect the right solutions to be found in the financial framework. I wish the new Council and its meeting every success and hope that the presidency and the new President-in-Office of the Council will do their own work to make it historic.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Minister, we are preparing for a new presidency of the Council. The Council's multi-year budget outlook is once again on the Council's agenda, alongside our climate ambitions. Europe is not just a question of budget, but the budget is the translation of our political ambition. The Council will have two fundamentally linked issues on its agenda: the budget outlook and the climate. Climate change is one of the best examples. If we want a Europe that is both carbon neutral and with a dynamic economy that creates jobs, we must ensure and support this transition. This is the meaning of the Green Pact: to combine the environment and the economy. However, this cannot only be done with political words and statements. I regret that the discussions have so far focused on the spending limits that Member States would like to allocate to European projects, negotiating up to the second decimal point of the comma. Are we capping the part of ourselves that bears our European identity? Is it an end in itself to limit Europe to an insurmountable course? I do not believe that, and my group, which aspires to a European renewal, cannot subscribe to this vision. Let us talk about what Europe can and must do, and collectively put the means on the table so that Europe is not synonymous with additional spending but with more efficient use of public funds, because Europe can be more efficient than our Member States taken separately. Tomorrow we will elect a new Commission with an ambitious programme of work, so we must be consistent. Let us not be afraid of European spending, as it is usually accompanied by lower national expenditure. Of course, the European Union is not free, it is also accompanied by values, which must be shared. For my group, two subjects are fundamental: the reform of own resources and the conditionality of European funds, to ensure that these values are truly respected. This is the only way to give consistency to the European project. Before we ask others to do so, we must ensure that in our political families these values are respected and that all members of our political families respect them as well.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Heads of State and Government are going to meet in Brussels right after the Madrid climate summit. I hope they take some of the Madrid spirit along with them, because I’m sure they will have heard a lot of urgency from other governments of small island states, of coastal states and of countries and continents that are not as wealthy and prosperous as the European Union overall. So, I hope they take along that urgency and then put it and convert it into some real action, because after Madrid the real action has to start. As it stands right now, not a single one of the European Union Member States has submitted a national greenhouse gas reduction plan that would be adequate or in any way sufficient in order to reach the Paris Agreement targets. But the EU targets are also far from sufficient. In fact, they were agreed in 2014, so before the Paris summit. Clearly, we need to step up the game because, right now, Europe does not lead the game. We are looking elsewhere; we are telling other countries that they should do something. But that doesn’t work. We need to act ourselves; we cannot wait for others to act. A stable climate is not just a nice thing to have, it’s absolutely vital in order to have a liveable planet for the younger generation and also for future generations. It’s vital for security and for peace worldwide. And also, if we’re lagging behind, as we’re doing right now, we’re also losing out on technologies, on climate jobs that, right now, our competitors elsewhere in the world are developing. It is time to act and the Member States need to finally agree on the climate neutrality target of 2050. But, let’s be clear, and let’s keep in mind that that is not a very ambitious target. We should actually do much more to follow the Finnish example and be more ambitious, because 2050 is really late. But having targets for some time in the future is anyway not enough; we need to have concrete measures right now. We need to make sure right now that we will, at some point, achieve and reach targets. And what better way to use as a concrete measure our long—term budget? This is where we decide where we put our money, and we should put our money where our mouth is. That means that we should have a Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) that invests in renewable energies and in ecological agriculture and not, as it is foreseen at present, in agricultural mass production and in fossil fuels. We need to change our priorities. If we don’t change where the money goes, then nothing will change in terms of the actual policies. The EU has to play its fair part in a fair transition and that also needs resources for the European Union. Otherwise we have a lot of demands but not the resources to implement them. And that’s why we, the Greens, fully subscribe to the Parliament’s position of having at least 1.3% of the GNI as the overall amount. But on the income side we also need to be sustainable. A plastics tax or a carbon border adjustment tax is not just a revenue; it can really be a means of how to shape policies and make sure that we have policies that protect the environment and support a fair transition. And of all of these elements, the European Council can, but also really should, deliver. Because in order to stay credible, the EU has to lead with ambitious targets and we have to deliver them at home. If not now, when? So, I wish the best of luck to the Finnish Presidency and really hope that all the groups here can contribute by urging governments to actually play their role and say yes to climate neutrality, yes to an ambitious MFF and not just continue with business as usual.

name: Jörg Meuthen
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking about the next European Council in December. You have proposed 27 Commissioners for the Commission, one Commissioner per Member State, as you usually do. But if nothing deceives me, the EU still has 28 Member States, not 27. This is one too little, mathematics like from the Takka-Tukka country. The new Commission will not be operational until the UK nominates a Commissioner. Because the UK is a member of the EU – one of 28 – and every member is entitled to a Commissioner. That is the legal situation. Once again, you are breaking your own rules. And don't come to me with the need to create work ability. The old Commission is capable of working! It is only a matter of the new one having to wait a little longer before she takes office. They trample the law underfoot, whether on the whole – as in the case of the rescue of the euro at the time by breaking the non-assistance clause – or, as is the case here, on a small scale, when the new Commission started working. A Union in which practical arbitrariness replaces the jointly negotiated law is built on sand. Another: the cost to the EU is skyrocketing. The European Council has just approved, as far as possible, the European Parliament's budget proposal for 2020. They are inflating the already far too lavish EU budget. The EU budget is to be increased by a further EUR 850 million for the coming year. Any thriftiness is completely alien to you. Why? The citizens pay for it and do not even notice it. The EU is being fattened further, while the German taxpayer is being put on a diet, and not just the one. It is significant that German Members of the so-called Liberals and Christian Democrats also welcome this. Both parties are basically selling everything they once stood for. I can only hope that, at a lucid moment, the Council will remember something better and that it will not support the agreement on the budget. Unfortunately, however, there is probably the same inspirit of meaningless waste. They want to provide an additional EUR 500 million to climate policy projects. This is a classic subsidy policy, pure satisfaction with ideology, complete misallocation. Have you forgotten your milk lakes and butter mountains from that time? This economic governance from above did not work at that time, and it will not work in the future. The still gigantic proportion of the agricultural budget should be a reminder enough to you. I would be angry when I look at the ECB and the EIB, in addition to direct subsidies from the budget. The EIB is now to become a climate bank. It will create a series of investment ruins, because it will override the price mechanism with its promotional loans. The ECB should direct its monetary policy in favour of the climate, when it is not even in a position to normalise interest rates. Industrial and environmental policy is not the task of the European Central Bank, I ask you! Mrs Lagarde is already calling for an expansionary fiscal policy. Its mandate relates to the ECB's monetary policy. The German nomination of Ms Schnabel for the ECB puts the crown on the whole. I really do not understand how Germany could nominate someone who undermined the position of the Bundesbank even before its appointment. We will keep this to the federal government for years to come. Unfortunately, this will not benefit the German saver. All we can say is that the euro has failed, you are bringing your money to safety from the European Union.

name: Raffaele Fitto
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this will be a much less optimistic speech than those of the many Members who have spoken today, not because I want to introduce elements of pessimism but because I would like to be a little more realistic than the scenario before us. I would like to insert a political reflection, which we pretend to keep out of this House, but which accompanies all these summits: the Council is firm because there is an underground, which is beginning to emerge, clash between France and Germany over an overall future vision of the European institutions, talking about NATO, talking about defence, talking about economic issues. This is a major issue which has so far also paralysed the Work of the Council. I therefore think that all the issues that we are going to discuss and on which we are making fine proclamations today, in the hope that the Council, with the new Presidency, will be able to address these issues, we know that, starting with the MFF, that is, starting with the fundamental budgetary instrument, there are a number of glaring contradictions. Climate change is a top priority, it is certainly an important priority and we would miss something else, it is a fundamental issue. It should be remembered, however, that European emissions account for 9 % of global emissions and that this issue is therefore an important battle on a global scale, otherwise it could be very limited in the very small context of our continent. Above all, it is also very important to link it to the other financial issues, which we are pretending not to mention.  With regard to the request for additional resources, I would like to include the reflection on the European Stability Mechanism, on which a strange system of automatism is being created between the request for aid for debt restructuring, which leads to the countries that, in a substantial and main way, contribute to the creation of this fund, perhaps preventing them from using it. These too are requests for resources from the individual States which must be considered in the overall batch. When we talk about a number of considerations on the subject of the MFF and say: let us not reduce cohesion policies, let us not reduce resources to agriculture, imagine that climate change policies will be disproportionately increased for a major environmental programme. principle with respect to concrete facts. I will end with an example, which will not be touched on this occasion by the European Council, recalling the many proclamations made on immigration and recalling that, while it is no longer mentioned, hundreds of people die in November – an absolutely unexpected period – who leave North Africa illegally, and all this happens with indications from the various intelligence agencies of the countries , which signal the inclusion and risk of infiltration of jihadism. All these considerations are considerations for which this Parliament often, but above all the Council and the Commission, find themselves dealing with them when the problem arises, not when there are such serious signals that are indicated. That is what we want, and that is why there is not much optimism about the expectations of the next Council.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, this Friday, shortly before the next European Council, young people will take to the streets and take out their signs that will say 'let's change the system, not the climate'. This Friday, I will be with them in the street and we will shout together our thirst for life and the need to radically change our modes of production and consumption to save the planet. Finally, this Friday, they will put us, Parliament, you Council, you European Commission, before your political responsibilities. While the next European Council must define the long-term strategy that Europe will present to the world at COP 25, the voice of these young people must be heard in the hubbub of table-corner goods. The carbon neutrality target that Europe has set itself will not solve everything because it is based on several haphazard biases. First of all, we do not control the absorption capacity of natural carbon sinks, the terrible tragedies of the Amazon rainforest have reminded us. Second, we cannot base our future on CO2 capture technologies, which we have no assurance that they can be deployed on a large scale. Finally, it would be hypocritical to relocate our greenhouse gas emissions out of Europe, which, of course, would not change the global equation of climate change. This is the case of France, which doubles its carbon footprint. Let's face the harsh reality. According to the European Environment Agency, the measures currently in place in the Member States only guarantee a 30% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions against a 55% target set by our Parliament. This objective is indeed ambitious, but the solutions are within reach provided that the current policy directions are thoroughly reviewed. The announcement of an energy retrofit plan for buildings is a good thing, as is the decision of the European Investment Bank to stop financing fossils, contrary to what the far right thinks, in this case, that it is never on the side of the peoples and the planet. Now we must go faster and further, reorient the common agricultural policy, hold multinationals responsible for deforesting and polluting with impunity, and reject free trade agreements. The European Parliament must play its part in these strategic decisions and in the development of a credible financing plan for the ecological transition; this is one of the key issues of the multi-year financial framework on the Council's agenda, namely that we must give ourselves the means to fight climate change but also against inequalities. For this, we must not undress Peter to dress Paul, cutting in the budgets of cohesion and agriculture, as you have confirmed, Mr Timmermans. Political priorities must be set: climate and solidarity rather than the dangerous and overpriced adventure of Europe's defence. The solution is simple: to get the money where it is, by creating new taxes on the ecological and social balance sheet of imported products, on financial transactions, but also on large multinational companies that do not pay their fair share of taxes. In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen, some timid progress has been made in the 2020 climate budget, as Parliament has refused to go directly to the Council. It is up to us to be truly ambitious in the ongoing negotiations so that the next multi-year financial framework will finally meet the environmental and social challenges of the century. It is up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to live up to the expectations of these young people who are simply asking that they be left a livable world.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the December meeting of the Council will take place in a changed environment, with President Charles Michel at the helm of the European Council, but also hopefully with the new Commission very clear as to what the priorities for the next term should be, and this House more pluralistic and more assertive. We here in Strasbourg and Brussels will be very cooperative, but also very watchful as to checking whether the promises are being kept.  There is a widespread feeling, and I share it, that we need to significantly change our institutional gears and redirect our efforts more decisively towards meeting the expectations of citizens. We must spare no efforts to strengthen the pro-European sentiment among our main constituents, the people of Europe. And among the people I mean also migrants: I mean the British expats after Brexit, those who look for asylum to gain security for the lives, refugees from war-torn areas, and climate refugees soon to come.  The dialogue on Europe and its future with citizens and other relevant stakeholders in European future should be permanent by principle. These are the times when we can again have hope for creating a European demos. And I know that we have somehow forgotten this ambition but we must not divest ourselves of the ideal of making the Union something more than just a convenient meeting place for mutual recognition of Member States’ interests.  We see that this elusive European demos is arising spontaneously, especially among the young people in response to the climate crisis. Our role should be to facilitate the creation of a welcoming and generous space where this nascent demos will not only emerge, but will thrive and not only in response to climate emergency, but in tackling jointly other issues.  There is no better environment than the European Union to construct a sustainable and flexible space to leave to the next generation a better Europe. The political landscape is fast-changing and citizens should feel they are the primary gardeners of this new landscaping, so let me finish by wishing the new leaders of the European Council and the Commission, hopefully, God speed in the task they undertake.

name: Javier Moreno Sánchez (S&D).
text: – Madame la Présidente, comme le disait le Président Jacques Delors, l'Europe avance quand le Parlement et la Commission avancent main dans la main. Demain, ce Parlement doit, en masse, dire oui au nouveau collége de commissaires pour que nous puissions enfin relever ensemble les défis qui préoccupent toutes les citoyennes et tous les citoyens. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the same time it is necessary to reach out to the Council, and especially to the European Council, in order for the Council to exercise its role of momentum and political orientation with force. We must find pragmatic solutions to our most pressing challenges with financial resources appropriate to our ambitions. The December European Council must be decisive for the negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework. We need an ambitious budget that can respond to the Union's priorities and defend the common European good. And to do so it must reach 1.3% of gross national income, as this Parliament has claimed. Above all, we must implement the European Union's long-term strategy on climate change if we are to meet our goal of being the first climate-neutral continent, with a fair ecological transition that leaves no one behind. In addition, we must strengthen traditional European policies such as the CAP and social and territorial cohesion and face the challenges associated with migration, an inclusive and fair digital transition, the fight against youth unemployment and, above all, the implementation of the gender strategy. Citizens, and especially young people, gave us their trust in the past European elections with the highest participation rate recorded since 1994, but, ladies and gentlemen, it is not a blank cheque. Only if we work together can we build our common future and build a new, more feminist, greener, more social and fairer Europe.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I’m sure the members of the Council are delighted that they don’t have to spend much time this time around discussing Brexit and the British elections have given them some breathing space to focus on more important topics. Sadly, as a British MEP, I can’t escape the Brexit nightmare and it rumbles on through our election campaign. This means yet more lies and deceptive soundbites, of which the latest is ‘Get Brexit done’. With three and more years of uncertainty and understandable feelings of Brexit fatigue, it is natural that British voters will be tempted by such an offer. But the reality of Johnson’s deal is that it would lead to years of difficult negotiations and the risk of a cliff—edge Brexit at the end of 2020. It must be rejected. As Greens, we know that the climate emergency is a far greater crisis facing us, which is why we are determined that this should be a climate election. Yesterday, the World Meteorological Organization revealed that global greenhouse gas emissions reached a new high last year. Setting a net—zero carbon target of 2050 is totally inadequate and flies in the face of both the science and what our children are demanding of us. Aiming for 2050 means risking runaway climate change, a risk to citizens’ lives that we must not take. This is an emergency. We must act as if we mean that. Leaving it too late to achieve carbon neutrality could literally mean the difference between life and death for millions of people. It could spell the end of human civilization. Safeguarding our planet for future generations calls for urgent action. This means challenging sectors often considered too politically sensitive, taking on the vested interests of aviation, which is still subsidised with European money, the automobile sector and agribusiness. Above all, it means an end to our obsession with economic growth. When your grandchildren ask you, ‘what did you do in the climate emergency?’, you had better make sure you have a good answer.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Robert Rowland (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I would just like to ask Ms Scott Cato what empirical proof she has that the end of the transition period when we will be leaving the European Union – hopefully on a Canada-plus style trade deal – will result in a cliff edge when, as far as I’m aware, she does not have any degree in economics. And maybe she has some business experience that will give some empirical proof that that would be the case? So I was wondering whether you could answer that question, why you’re so certain that the United Kingdom will suffer as a result of a ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Obviously you haven’t been paying much attention to my CV because I was, and I remain, a professor of economics.  (Laugher and applause) I also have expertise in trade policy and have been studying the trade negotiations from the beginning. I rely on the expertise of other trade experts, all of whom have said it takes much longer than the time available to negotiate a treaty. And the likelihood is if we go ahead with Boris Johnson’s deal, we will end up in exactly the same crisis facing a no-deal Brexit at the end of 2020. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: I think Mr Rowland stands corrected.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If you want to debate the forthcoming Council meeting today and always focus on the climate here, I would say – especially in view of the major problems that exist here in Europe – that this could be something of a mishandling of the issue. With all due respect and appreciation for the need to focus on nature conservation and environmental protection, I see the major political weather situation, particularly in the banking and monetary sectors, as very serious problems that we should focus on. We have a zero interest rate policy in the euro area, which is now moving into a negative interest rate policy. We have a situation where the banking sector could be cleaned up again in the coming year. This means that we have a situation where prosperity on our continent could continue to fall and that we should finally take effective measures in this sector. We discussed some time ago that in the euro area we finally needed something like a Glass-Steagall Act at European level, a separation into commercial and investment banks, in order to ensure the banking sector and our financial cycle and our monetary system accordingly. Unfortunately, nothing happens. Something is happening again on the subject of climate: we are discussing whether new CO2 taxes are coming, whether new restrictions should come, and so on and so forth. In my view, however, there is also a wrong setting of the issues here. What you are currently doing is beating the European car industry, which is also a heart of economic efficiency on our continent – whether that is Germany, whether it is France: these are engines. And if you damage the automotive industry, you are damaging the subcontracting sector. Damage the subcontracting sector, damage families and their incomes. I think that is wrong. Where something could be done by the European Union is obvious, in my view: we have debated that the transport of goods across the continent – if you bring agricultural products from Eastern Europe to Western Europe, then process them, resell them in another country, have animal transport – generates an extreme burden on that continent. These are all things where you could immediately and effectively do something for the environment. Here you are in arrears to generate the corresponding. I appeal to your common sense and also to your prioritization: deal with the right topics in good time with proper gravity and do not always look for excuses.

name: Johan Van Overtveldt (ECR).
text: Mr President, last week we reached a historic agreement on the 2020 budget, historically in the sense of a forward-looking shift towards investment in areas where the EU can indeed deliver significant added value. I am thinking of research, development, energy, transport and infrastructure.  We must certainly also make such a change for the budget, the multiannual budget to come: choices for the 21st century, clear choices for innovation, competitiveness, climate infrastructure, security and migration management. A Green Deal for Europe can only succeed if we invest the resources where they are needed. Advocating climate neutrality while at the same time issuing a ban on nuclear energy, as some in this hemisphere do, is absolutely inconsistent. But it is encouraging that I heard the Greens spokesman this morning refer to the Finnish example on this.  Finally, a message for the future President Charles Michel. In October 2017, you became the first head of government to condemn the violence in Catalonia. I sincerely hope that, as President, you will also be on the right side of history and will not close your eyes to political prisoners in the EU.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mrs Tuppurainen, do you know what the problem is? The problem is that in all the major European issues before us, the Council has long been a huge brake and is constantly below the circumstances. We want a new multiannual budget which, in order to serve the objectives, not those requested by the European Parliament but those which you have set, cannot be one per cent of European GDP. We cannot use this to serve the climate change targets, which must be ambitious. We in the European Parliament cannot approve a cut in cohesion policies, or a drastic reduction in the funds for the common agricultural policy.  And also, let the accession negotiations on Northern Macedonia finally begin. It is not possible for what you are giving Erdogan's Turkey to deny in Northern Macedonia. And finally, to finally adopt the reform of asylum policies and not block it, because it is impossible for my country, Greece, to lift the burden of refugees alone, with lack of solidarity, because you are being held hostage by the politicians Orban and Salvini.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Madam President, the European Union and the governments are well aware that the contradictions plaguing the capitalist economy are causing problems. They are more concerned overall about the difficulties of recovery, the prospect of a new synchronised crisis, the sharpening of competition between the US, the European Union and China. The outcome of these competitions concerns critical areas of profitability for large groups, such as so-called green investments, digital, energy, which are an apple of contention, and it is precisely at this time that the conditions are laid down for who will ultimately prevail and who will be left behind. Amid these fierce competition, EU money from the new multiannual framework is directed to large monopolistic groups. The ongoing disputes have nothing to do with the interests or the improvement of the position of the workers of the Member States. Your goal is to create a safe environment for monopolies, to get rich with exploitation intensity, entrenched wages and pensions, dismantling the social security system, abolishing labour rights, drastically restricting trade union rights and intensity of repression. This is what the Government of New Democracy in Greece is doing by continuing syriza's unpopular policy, in the context of enhanced supervision of European semesters, bloody primary surpluses, foreclosures and first home auctions. The Council's guidelines have nothing to do with the protection of the environment and the protection of popular interests. The whole debate on climate change is pre-formal, since the destruction of the environment is a consequence of the capitalist economy, which is the criterion of profit-hunting, as a consequence of the imperialist wars. The increasing militarisation, the debate on the future of NATO, the attitude of France and Germany, on the ground of the withdrawal of the largest military force in the European Union, Britain, underlines, moreover, that the contrasts at the bazaar tables are combined with attacks on the people. The peoples of Europe must organise themselves and fight for their modern rights, against the bleak future that is shaping up.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: – Dear Madam President, Dear Colleagues, The December European Council deals with the 7-year framework budget. The Common Position of the European Parliament across factions is that a proposal for a fair seven-year framework budget should be drawn up by the European Council. Dear Colleagues, allow me to take advantage of today's exchange of views to offer council representatives five clear and unambiguous aspects regarding the forthcoming MFF, i.e. the seven-year framework budget. Firstly, the system of refunds and rebate should be abolished. This system maintains a completely utterly utterly omnised and unfair situation as to the contribution of each Member State to the Union budget in relation to the national total. Secondly, the Council's proposal should take account of the fact that a significant part of the funds received by the Central and Eastern European Member States as cohesion funds will be returned to the Member States that are old from the point of view of 2004 in the framework of economic cooperation. In fact, the cohesion development resources allocated to central and eastern European Member States also contribute to the economic development of the EU-15. Thirdly, it is unfair and unacceptable to reduce cohesion resources, especially given that countries with poorer, more modest economic performance than the average economic development of the European Union should suffer from greater reductions in cohesion resources, whereas in countries that have already attre the average economic development of the European Union or are in a better position, this reduction is much smaller or not. Fourthly, we need a flexible budget. According to the budget proposal of the outgoing Commission and the resources available to us so far, the thinking of the Finnish Presidency continues to show the image of an inflexible budget. Last but not least, on the issue of climate change, I am deeply convinced that, at the moment, it is not a future threat, but a present sad state that our ambitions are empty at the moment. It's not just for young people, it's for the working age and the elderly. It is absurd that it occurred to the Council less than a month ago to ask the Commission to draw up a concrete plan and the common EU funds allocated to the specific plan, what support is needed to achieve the 2050 climate targets. So such a draft budget without concrete measures would be unfair.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the agenda of the forthcoming European Council calls for concrete progress to be made on two key points: the multiannual financial framework and the fight against climate change, which are clearly linked issues. It is necessary for the Union to have an ambitious road map to deal with the climate emergency, as we have heard from our Commissioner, Mr Timmermans, but to achieve it it will be necessary to allocate adequate resources, without delay, so that climate neutrality can be achieved quickly with investments that allow a fair transition, to create new jobs, to secure our countries hydrogeologically. The green new deal, which the new Commission is committed to presenting, must be able to do exactly that but, as I said, we need resources. That is why Parliament must be clear, it must be inflexible in negotiating an ambitious budget with the Member States that will be able to respond to these needs. I would also like to point out that we are already experiencing a situation of great uncertainty with regard to extreme weather phenomena, which are becoming more and more frequent, with often disastrous consequences. The situation is often dramatic and I appeal to the Heads of State or Government, who are meeting shortly, to draw up an extraordinary strategic plan at European level as a matter of urgency to deal with this crisis. Think about what happened in Venice, it will still be discussed here in Parliament. Look again today at my region, Liguria, and genoa, which is already on its knees and repeatedly overwhelmed by mud, which is increasingly isolated. Fortunately, our government is reacting promptly and decisively, but we need a collective European commitment, because these phenomena and situations affect more and more European citizens and their lives, their security and their ability to live well must be guaranteed through a common commitment with the appropriate ambition.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are facing an important European Council, not only because it is the baptism of fire of our own Charles Michel, but probably – hopefully – also the start of the Ursula von der Leyen Commission. And Commissioner Timmermans, you have – quite rightly, I think – thank you to President Juncker. I have to tell you: in recent years, President Juncker has indeed shown that Europe can be great if it wants to. We've successfully fought donald trump's stupid trade war. That's what we want, and we actually want more of that. We want Europe to show that it can be great on the world stage: a European story, a European strategy that goes against Xi Jinping and against Donald Trump, men who actually – must we honestly – know only one language, that of brute power.  But in order to achieve this ambition, Europe must also be given the necessary resources. Cooking costs money. Put your money where your mouth is. That is why I am really asking here to provide sufficient resources for security, for defence, for migration, for the protection of external borders, for the faster creation of Frontex. I think that is what the citizens are asking for. And of course climate. The citizens rightly expect us as Europe to take the lead in this, to be ambitious in this, to achieve results. That is what we need to do and that must be visible in that budget.  That is why I ask the Council: go along with this ambition, protect Europe, make Europe great, again. Make Europe great again. That is what I expect from this European Council: ambitious, concrete, with results, as the citizens expect of us.

name: Saskia Bricmont (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, Mrs Tuppurainen, thank you for your statements. The European Parliament is ready to declare the climate emergency. As you have said over and over again: the goal is a zero-carbon society in 2050. But to do that, we also need to ensure consistency in our policies now. However, there are two sectors in which I do not see any coherence, two main sectors and a major contributor to CO2 emissions: agricultural policy and trade policy. Unfortunately, nothing in the mission letters of the future Commissioners fundamentally changes the course of these policies. The European Commission continues to urge this House to adopt the free trade agreements that sit on the Paris Agreements. I take the example of yesterday's vote in the Committee on International Trade of an agreement with the United States, where Mr Trump has just declared that he is abandoning the Paris Agreement and the objectives we set for ourselves here in the European Union. As you said, for our children, for future generations and for the climate walkers, I believe that beyond the speeches and the political declaration of climate emergency that this Parliament will proclaim this week, we now need concrete actions and binding measures to ensure that our free trade agreements also comply with the Paris Agreements.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, the European Council on 12 and 13 December is planning to focus on two main points: climate change and the multi-year financial framework. We are particularly concerned about the dogmatic view with which the subject of climate is treated. We see, with total misunderstanding, the pursuit of two irreconcilable objectives: on the one hand, climate neutrality projected for 2050, and on the other, a race for globalization with the proliferation of mega-free trade agreements (CETA, Mercosur, agreements with Japan, Vietnam and, tomorrow, New Zealand and Australia).  Until the cost of carbon emitted to transport imported products from the other side of the world is included in the price, efforts for climate neutrality on our continent will be futile and an additional illusion. Two telling examples: in the flower market in Nice, a rose imported from Kenya costs less than a rose produced a few kilometers away in Italy. I am not even talking about the social and environmental conditions in which roses are produced in Kenya: labour exploitation, misuse of pesticides, drying up of soils. The carbon cost of importing this rose is nowhere to be said. It is a pollution permit given by Europe. To claim climate neutrality by turning a blind eye to such consequences is to commit a lie in the service of globalist ideology. The case of the automobile is the same. By ideology, European manufacturers are forced to abandon diesel and switch to all-electric, without the consequences of switching to uncontrolled technology in Europe. Indeed, rare earths all over the world are plundered by China to produce batteries that we will use; the recycling channels of these batteries are not organised, which leads to over-pollution; components are imported massively using giant container ships, the source of the largest carbon pollution, which remains unregulated. You antagonize generations by having a catastrophic discourse that pits young people against the old, but you do not address the real causes of increased carbon production, namely globalization. In order to respond, the Council will have to make efforts on short distribution channels, promote localism, produce as closely as possible what we consume and not encourage a leak forward, with unbridled free trade, a source of increasing pollution. As for the multi-year financial framework, this technocratic title hides a very raw reality: more for migrants, less for farmers. The budget proposals are marked by a significant disengagement of CAP appropriations, due to the disappearance of coupled aid and the preference given to greening payments. There is nothing concrete in this greening, only words and communication to flatter an ideological environmentalism neither concrete nor reasonable, nor responsible. At the same time, this programme is pushing for an increase in aid to migrants, with the underlying objective of a future communitisation of the right of asylum, by ideology again. We are concerned about this programme, both in terms of its thoughtless dogmatic aspects and its dangerous consequences for the future of the peoples of Europe.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, we have a debate and a decision on a new multiannual financial framework. Brexit will lead to a different redistribution of funds and that was to be expected. But we must be careful that the burden we share between us does not hit the weakest among us the most.   The announcement of cuts to the Common Agricultural Policy and Cohesion Policy has rightly alarmed some of the newest Member States still casking for developed members. Croatia, from which I come, is the newest member of the Union and is just beginning to take full advantage of membership. Reducing funds that have been available to others for much longer would have a negative impact on our development.   As we find ourselves in the lobby of another recession, we must think about reforms and increasing resilience to the crisis. Additional investments are needed in countries such as Croatia to avoid the devastating effects that the past financial crisis has achieved this time.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, in this discussion on the MFF, I hear that cohesion policy is a traditional policy. This is not wrong, but cohesion is above all a requirement for today and a guarantee for the future. What I want to say to the Council is that there is no future for Europe without a future for cohesion, and lacking ambition for the European budget is ultimately lacking ambition for Europe. We must also remember that lowering the cohesion budget is a blow to the very heart of the European idea, because it is solidarity that makes our common project. Lowering the cohesion budget would therefore ultimately give a satisfaction to europhobes, who are waiting for this. Finally, I would like to say that cohesion is not just solidarity, because cohesion policy will enable the deployment of new policies such as the new Green Pact and the Just Transition Fund. That's why pay attention to the arbitrations that will be yours.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like first to welcome Minister Tuppurainen and First Vice-President Timmermans back to Parliament.  It is the task of all of us to deliver the best policies for the people of the European Union. We may deliver on the details, but we should be united on the task to deliver policy for the people of the European Union, and as of 1 December, with the new European Commission, with the new leadership in the Council and in the other institutions of the European Union, we truly have no more excuses not to speed up our delivering of policy.  One of the best tools which we have at our disposal to deliver for the people of Europe is the budget of the European Union, and my approach here is the following. Firstly, we should ask ourselves what we expect from the European Union in the next decade, in the next 10 years.  We have seen the people of Europe come out and vote in large numbers. Farmers expect support from the European Union. Local communities expect investments in the form of cohesion policy. Students want more mobility programmes, as does youth in general. Researchers, people who work in digitalisation and innovation expect the European Union to stand by their side. Citizens in all corners of Europe want us to do more on security, defence, protecting the external borders of the European Union and people, particularly our youth, who speak united with one voice on combating climate change. If we agree that the European Union should deliver more in the next decade, then this needs to be reflected in the budget of the European Union. We have to be honest with the citizens of Europe. We cannot do more with much less money. This is why our message to the Council is clear: please put your money where your statements are. If we agree to do more, then this needs to be reflected in the budget and I appeal to Minister Tuppurainen to use the December European Council for a high-level political discussion; not details of the negotiating box, but make the leaders, the heads of state or government, agree on the political priorities. Then it’s easier to agree on the numbers.  If we start discussions by discussing numbers, then the discussions will be divisive and it will just be in the market place. What needs to unite us in the beginning is a vision for Europe for the next 10 years and the budget at the service of this vision.  What should our priorities be? A balance between old and new priorities. Just because agriculture and cohesion are old priorities doesn’t mean that they are outdated. They have been our priorities for decades because they are important, but clearly we have to do more in research, innovation, climate, digitalisation and security. Coming to the end of my intervention, we have to deliver now. We have seen several delays in this MFF and we have to be honest – we, the European institutions, were one of the causes of these delays. We adopted the budget late in 2013 for this MFF. We should learn from the mistakes of the past. The sooner we adopt the budget, the better, but in any case no later than spring 2020.

name: Gabriele Bischoff (S&D).
text: Mrs Tuppurainen, Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We know that the forthcoming European Council will also deal with the conference on the future of Europe. This is a great opportunity for Europe if it really seizes it and also manages to involve citizens – civil society – from the outset. Because citizens need a Union that is capable of action, they need an EU that really protects them and also strengthens it in the face of the challenges we face – with the climate crisis, digitalisation and migration, but also with growing inequality in many countries.  That is why it is important that this European Council send out a clear signal here and that we ensure that together – all the institutions together – we use this conference to turn Europe back on its feet. In this sense, we as a Parliament, strengthened by the last election, also have the ambition to play a leading role here, because we, as directly elected representatives, also play a special role here. In this sense, we have seen that there is a german-French non-paper to set a few key points for this conference in the Council. It asks the right questions, it also makes it clear that it really focuses on Europe's ability to act.  What we as a Parliament are particularly pleased about – and also of us as the S&D Group – is that there should be no taboos, that treaty changes should not be further taboo. Here, however, it is important to listen first to the citizens, to go into this debate with them with specific issues and then to really incorporate what is burning on the citizens' nails into the work of this conference on the future of Europe. So it's not just about listening, it's really about dialogue and participation. We in Parliament want to help achieve this and we are counting on you to send out the right signals in the European Council in December.

name: Charles Goerens (Renew).
text: Madam President, the European Parliament would like 1.3% of the gross national product of Member States to be spent on the European budget. That is very little in terms of the expectations expressed by our citizens in terms of research policy, in terms of security policy, and so on. The attitude of our Member States, to say the least, is not up to scratch. We would like more security, but grace, without the slightest budget increase. We would like to win the race against the big giants that are China, economically, the United States and others, but gracefully, at zero tariff. We would like to be the champions of research, but of grace, without a penny more in our budgets. Everyone knows that multilateralism is being undermined by the United States; there is a great void here that invites Europe to its responsibilities, but Russia, Turkey, Iran, in fact, the representatives of the old empires are allowed to do so. Most of our Member States are not aware of the historical duty before them. I turn to the second item that will be put on the agenda of the next Council, namely climate change. Of course, we in Europe must do whatever is necessary to achieve carbon neutrality. After Brexit, we account for about 7% of greenhouse gas emissions. So the threat is global, and if the threat is global, our response must also be global. We must therefore rely on the climate diplomacy of the new Commission and Mr Timmermans to ensure that China and India, which alone account for more than 50% of greenhouse gas emissions, subscribe to a discipline that could lead us to win the fight against climate change. It was Jeffrey Sachs who brought this to the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the European Parliament's Development Committee a few months ago.

name: Mikuláš Peksa (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, at the moment we are in a situation where the future budget of the European Union will be co-decided at the Council by Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babiš, whose essential interest is subsidies for his own companies. Europe's financial plans for the next seven years are thus decided by someone whose motivation is his own personal gain, someone who, as a lion, has prevented, for example, capping agricultural subsidies, because it is advantageous for his agricultural large-scale enterprise. Let's take this situation seriously, please. I would ask the Council to take the conflict of interest into account in this context and to ex exonerate Andrej Babiš from the budget negotiations. Otherwise, we will lose both the money and the trust of our citizens, because we will not be able to follow the basic principles of fair governance when making decisions. The Council is already facing legal action for this, and I think there is no point in prolonging this situation any longer.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Ursula von der Leyen's new Commission starts badly, immediately demonstrating that it will not be in the interests of Italians and the peoples of Europe. The new Commission will continue to be a slave to banks and lobbies, enslaved to the interests of Germany and France, Merkel and Macron. The Italians do not expect anything good from a Commission in which people such as Vestager sit, who bankrupted Italian banks, or like the former Italian Prime Minister Gentiloni, famous for having silently accepted the orders of Brussels and Berlin. Nor do the Italians expect anything good from the December Council, where the reform of the ESA, which is extremely dangerous for Italy and for all European citizens, will also be discussed. In short, Ursula's Europe will not change anything compared to the disasters combined by Juncker. On the contrary, given the premises, von der Leyen will do even worse than the failed Juncker Commission. But rest assured, the Italians will not remain silent!

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the forthcoming European Council does not bode well for us. There are still no decisive steps on the new multiannual financial framework. Months are lost discussing surreal conditionality on the rule of law, but it is still not clear what the fate of the cohesion funds and the CAP will be, which risk paying the price of Brexit for no reason. General commitments on climate change, which are then anticipated at national level with new taxes and bureaucracy, while new emergencies are advancing that would require instead to invest in prevention to defend a territory battered by extreme climatic phenomena. But what concerns us most is what could be decided, in the margins of the Council, on the reform of the European stability mechanism: new conditionalities for a possible debt restructuring, which translated means linear cuts in public spending, social butchery, austerity and further limitation to the economic sovereignty of states, all at the expense, once again, of economic growth. A line that has already failed and that must be strongly rejected by the sender.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – A chairde, whatever the outcome of the Westminster election on 12 December – I will be voting for Elisha McCallion in Derry – and whatever the latest decision on Brexit, the uncertainty and damage done to Ireland by its larger neighbour will damage the EU too. In April 2017, the European Council said reunification would result in the whole of Ireland automatically entering the EU. Partition is not only Ireland’s problem, it’s now the EU’s problem too, and Irish unity is the solution for Ireland and for the EU.  If you want to protect EU citizens from post—Brexit Britain’s lower standard of goods entering your market, then you need to help remove the British border in Ireland. Its democratic removal is outlined in the Good Friday Agreement, so support the constructive and positive debate about constitutional change in Ireland. Even the Fine Gael government’s youth wing has called for a unity referendum within five years. Irish unity is no longer an aspiration: it’s a project. A wise European Council would know that, and only a foolish one would ignore it.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the new President of the Council will find on his table urgent matters requiring urgent policy. The climate crisis is not a matter for the next five years, it is a matter for the next fifty years and is one of these urgent issues. The European Green New Deal affects us all. And we all have to get involved in their solution. Fighting climate change will not be the task of one man, not even the task of a single political party; it is a task for all men, women and all political parties. It must be a cross-cutting policy and must be supported by strong majority and stable majority. To make the fight against climate change an ideological issue, to legislate from partisan positions is to condemn the fight against climate change to failure. Either we're all together, behind us, or we're not going to do anything.  Both those who do not want to join the consensus and those who exclude others from consensus are as detriment to the fight against climate change. You don't get better at fighting climate change the more you just are. The best are always the ones who know how to form majority in the face of the challenges of history. Our position is clear. We need a green pact three times sustainable: to have a sustainable climate, to have a sustainable industry and to have a sustainable society.  We need a green pact that combines our climate protection policy with our social market economy; otherwise, we will lose the support of citizens and pay for the thesis of nationalists and populists. If we do not do so, we will not protect those who are already suffering the consequences of climate change: coal producers or farmers in flood zones who are just asking for help.  Defending the weather is neither right nor left. It is simply a moral imperative. And the next few months we will have to face the Brexit after Brexit. If there is a new referendum, we will have to get involved - which we did not do in the first referendum - and if there is no new referendum, Brexit after Brexit cannot make the UK the invisible member of the European corps, the phantom member of the European body.  We cannot react to the UK with nostalgia, but we cannot react with a rematch or a grudge. By the way, a UNITED Kingdom separate from the European Union will not be able to fight climate change on its own.  And I hope the Council will be involved in the next conference on the future of the European Union. Without the Council, we will not advance. And we need to move forward, because the European Union is like a bicycle, if it goes off, it falls.

name: President. –
text: And that can be painful.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Madam President, you referred to this European Council as being the changing of the guard and indeed the British general election is on the same day as the first day of the European Council. The results should be known on the second day. So indeed it may well be marked by a changing of the guard and I’m sure that many of us in this Parliament hope that that is the case. You said also that it will be looking at the next steps for Brexit. Well indeed, with a new government in Britain, we will be moving to a situation of having a new referendum on Brexit within six months, based on a different deal than Boris Johnson’s deal.  We would like to revise that to make it a less damaging deal for Britain and indeed for Europe – closer, staying inside the Customs Union, closer to Europe, not tearing up our relationship as one alternative, and the other alternative to remain in the European Union. If the British people choose to leave, it will be on the basis of a deal that can be implemented immediately and would be less damaging to everyone. But there is every chance that they will vote to remain in the European Union and this whole sorry business can be put behind us.  Mark my words, if Boris Johnson loses his majority, we will be moving to another referendum. Every single opposition party, not just Labour – the main opposition party that will lead the next government – but every opposition party in the British parliament now supports another referendum on Brexit and that is something that the European Council must take account of as it examines the next steps forward on Brexit, as you said, on its agenda. Beware. It is not going to be the steps that Boris Johnson wanted. It will be steps in a rather different direction.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Robert Rowland (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Corbett, I know the British population is terribly confused by your leader’s Brexit position. He has talked about negotiating a new agreement with the European Union then putting it to another referendum remaining neutral. Could you elucidate us a little bit further on what kind of new deal the Labour Party is looking for with the European Union and then what your position would be post that in terms of whether you would support your leader in neutrality or you would vote for remain?

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
