text: blue-card answer. – The next prime minister, Jeremy Corbyn, has said that, as prime minister, he felt he should be neutral in the referendum to apply whatever the outcome the British people decide. But the Labour Party will be taking a position at a special conference and I am convinced that, faced with the prospect of remaining or leaving – even leaving with a less damaging deal than Boris Johnson’s deal, which is what we will secure in negotiations with our European friends and partners – that we, like the British public, will choose to remain in the European Union. That’s the best solution for Britain. That’s the best solution for the British public.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (Renew).
text: – Madam President, this session marks the end of the Juncker—Tusk era and the start of a new Von der Leyen—Michel era. Therefore it’s striking that the national governments are still singing the same tune as they have done for decades. I note that the seven—yearly bar brawl over the MFF has very little to do with vision for the future and, at this time of the year, it rather reminds me of Scrooge and the ghosts of Christmases past.  Now the frugal four – not to be confused with the Fab Four – the frugal four, that’s Austria, Denmark, the Netherlands and Sweden, seem to have embraced one percent as a kind of new religion. It is driven by ideology and obsession with a small budget and not by a vision for the future because how is Europe ever going to achieve its ambitions on a budget of one percent? Do we really want to compete with the Chinese digital tiger with a one—percent budget, and do we really think that we can be the climate champion of the world with pennies and dimes? Or do we seriously think that we can be a geopolitical force on a shoestring? No, it’s not about spending less, it’s about spending better.  The frugal four do mention the rule-of-law conditionality for receiving funds, which is a good thing, but I would also like to hear the same frugal four then explain why they say nothing when they know that authoritarian leaders, like Viktor Orbán for example, have used EU funds to enrich their oligarch friends and to get political support in return. I hope and presume that they have read The New York Times and that they will dare to raise this matter at the next Council meeting.  It is very clear that the European Union needs a serious budget and a system of own resources instead of this perverse, undemocratic and wasteful system. In May, over 200 million Europeans voted for the European Parliament. That was the highest turnout in 30 years, mainly because many more young people voted and they did not vote for solutions of the past. They didn’t vote for one percent or two percent or half a percent. They voted for ambitions for the future. So give them the budget that can realise those ambitions for the future.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – I do agree with your vision on budget, but I would also like you to make a contribution by convincing your Prime Minister, from your party, because he was here saying exactly the opposite of what you are saying. And, by the way, the Socialist Party of Mr Timmermans did the same during the Dijsselbloem era, so what I see is a common position from your Government. Please, first convince your Government. Then our work here will be easier.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (Renew)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr Rangel, but I would like to eliminate one misunderstanding. The Prime Minister is not of my party, and my party has a very different view. But obviously we are in a coalition government. There is a position which has been voiced by Mr Rutte, maybe in a way that we would not fully support, but the position of my party is very clear, and that is the position that I have just expressed.

name: Michael Bloss (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I take it from Ms in 't Veld that the young generation voted in the European elections and they voted for climate action. They want us to act, they want the Commission to act and they want the Council to act on climate. If Parliament now does act, they will hopefully declare a climate emergency. But what is emerging is the youth, and what we have to do as politicians is to act. Therefore, I hope that the Council will decide to become climate neutral, that the Commission will agree to increase the 2030 targets to least 65% and that this Parliament will not only declare a climate emergency but also act on it.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at its next meeting on 12 and 13 December, the European Council will address the issue of climate change in order to finalise a strategy aimed at climate neutrality in 2050. In order to achieve this objective, the European Union is calling on European industry, for example steelworks, to have a programme for the elimination of coal, which involves considerable investment in new production technologies. This process will require a long and complicated industrial transition, which cannot fail to have a negative impact on European industry in economic and employment terms. I therefore wonder whether the European Council, in order to facilitate this transition, intends to support European industry through appropriate financial instruments to ensure the competitiveness of our industry, especially vis-à-vis China, India and the United States, countries that do not share the fight against climate change with Europe, not even as a result of the resulting energy transition.

name: Anna Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I echo Ruža Tomašić’s views on the MFF, including CAP and cohesion. Foreign affairs are to be added to the Council agenda. There are reasons for concern from Hong Kong to Venezuela, including my region, Eastern Partnership countries, yet I focus on Iran. Dreadful things are happening there due to mass murders by the mullahs’ regime. Our policies are too weak, too constrained, too tied up in previous decisions actually permissive to murders. I hope for a real shift in our policies; change, clear—cut statements and resolve.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, this graph shows us the per capita benefit each country has from the Single Market. I don't know if anyone will have the courage to take him to the table at the next European Council, but he should. This graph highlights the asymmetric nature of integration and shows us who are the major beneficiaries of this integration. If it were related to the benefits of the single currency you might believe that it would be even more unbalanced. What is happening is that the major beneficiaries of integration, these countries which see here at the top of the chart, now want to deepen their instruments of dominance, the single market and the euro, want to benefit more from the budget as well, contributing less in proportional terms. They want to cut cohesion funds, undermine any redistributive function that the budget may have, and want to sequester a larger share of that budget, particularly through areas such as defence.  Now, the result will be only one: more inequality, more asymmetries, the prelude to new peaks of crisis, an integration in which increasingly the benefit of some is made to the account of the harm of others, and such a project has no future. Or having, in the immediate future, a future that deserves to be fought.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, on the subject of the Council's agenda which will now take place on 12 and 13 December I would like to talk first about the MFF. It is clear that there is only one reasonable and acceptable proposal, and even for the medium term of the European Union it is not enough, which is Parliament's proposal, and as long as the Finnish Presidency and the Members of the Council continue to want a minimalist budget and rely, moreover, on the Commission's proposal – which unfortunately the Portuguese Government has even accepted, or at least signaled at an early stage – , where countries such as Finland earn more funds and countries such as Poland, Hungary or Croatia lose funds, this is not cohesion anywhere in the world.  And therefore we cannot accept either the budget on the table, and which the Council wants to force, let alone the distribution that was foreseen in terms of cohesion funds to achieve convergence, in the case of the Commission's proposal, the Juncker Commission. They are two bad starting bases and, therefore, Parliament must, point one, clearly force its overall package to be accepted and, point two, that there is also no loss of funds for any of the States in accordance with the criteria that have already been defined in that motion for a resolution in the resolution which was adopted by Parliament. It is essential to do this and it is essential for the Council to realise this, and only from a basis like this can there be a successful negotiation, which, moreover, and in passing, should be as swift as possible, because if the negotiation is not quick and there will be many citizens and many companies suffering the consequences. At the very least, a transitional proposal is accepted that there is no, say, a halt to European support for all citizens and businesses benefiting from it. Finally, on climate change, one thing that is very important: it is that fast steps are already taken but that they are steps that not only take the life of the planet, which is an imperative, that it is an emergency, which is an emergency – I have no doubts about it – but also people, because people must be at the heart of politics , and we what we sometimes see is that socialists put society ahead of people, liberals put individuals ahead of people, greens put the planet ahead of people and what we want is a policy for people, that is, for individuals in relation, to individuals in their context, to families , for the relationship of solidarity. Finally, a telegraphic word to say that I hope that the Council will already take decisions here on the Conference on the Future of Europe and to do so consciously and not as I have seen in this Franco-German non-paper, in which there are results that are already defined even before the conference that brings people together. We do not want pre-cooked results, we do not want pre-defined results, we want the institutions and citizens of Europe to be able to decide freely on the future of the European Union.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Mrs Tuppurainen, I would like to address you personally, because I know how much verve, with how much commitment you are pushing this agenda forward. I believe that you would do well to prepare this European summit very carefully. For the next few years, we need budgets in the European Union that are modernisation budgets. We need households for good work, for a clean environment, for households that show that we can generate energy without ruining this planet, households that make us mobile without our cities getting sick and without ruining the health of our citizens, households that take everyone with us and give everyone a chance to participate in the profession as well as in society and make their own contribution – with yield – to a better society as a whole in the European Union. This sustainability agenda must be implemented as a matter of urgency. We are in default, because if we do not deliver, if the European Union does not deliver, if we do not take a leading role in the world, then we will also disappoint the friends in the United Nations who are relying on us in particular, because we must be a leading player in this great process of transformation that we must succeed in in this world. Frans Timmermans, I know how much you are fighting for this new Green Deal to be a success. It will be your central task in the next few years – good luck to you! You rightly mentioned how much investment it takes to make it happen. I believe that we can help the Member States to gain courage by indeed including the objectives in our work plans, including them in the sustainability agenda and making them binding in the next steps in the European Semester. All the best for that!

name: Valerie Hayer (Renew).
text: Madam President, it has already been a year since Parliament adopted its position on the next multi-year financial framework and we are waiting for the Council to be willing to negotiate. It seems that things are finally moving, because in a few days, Madam Minister, you should put figures behind your proposals. This is good news and we hope that you will show ambition but also realism in this exercise which, let us acknowledge, is perilous for a presidency. Indeed, whatever your proposal, I can assure you that you will cause discontent among the Member States and also among the Members here. To answer this undoubtedly difficult equation, there is only one way possible, I have just mentioned, is one of ambition and realism. As it happens, this is the path Parliament has taken to clear its position. First, ambitions are easily shared; they concern the common agricultural and cohesion policy, the Union's flagship programmes such as Erasmus or Horizon 2020 for research, new challenges in defence, migration, innovation, security or digital technology, respect for the rule of law and, of course, the challenge of climate change. Secondly, there are two ways of being realistic: that of some Member States, which want to do more with less, and that of Parliament, which considers that any new initiative must be accompanied by additional budgetary resources. The aim is simple: to ensure the quality and effectiveness of European public policies. Let me think, Madam Minister, that realism is more on Parliament's side, because it is certainly very ambitious for Europeans. It is because we carry this ambition that we are hammering home the urgency of advancing the issue of own resources. Today, the predominance of national contributions fuels the logic of fair return and ignores the European added value. However, with our own resources, we could not only limit this flawed strategy but also support and strengthen the Union's policies through an incentive revenue mechanism. This is what is called in France "to make with one stone, two blows".

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, at the next European Council our government leaders again have an opportunity to solve a humanitarian crisis which has now been going on for almost four years. This crisis is a devastating situation in which asylum seekers find themselves on a Greek island. Forty-six thousand people are now staying in and around centres that are only equipped for eight thousand people. There’s a lack of medical care, lack of basic needs, lack of safety.  Many children, including unaccompanied minors, are left on their own, sometimes even without shelter, water or food. They depend on complete strangers to take care of them. People in need of protection have to wait years before their claim is assessed and there’s a great shortage of legal aid providers and interpreters. How can the European Council justify this ongoing crisis? Why is this not treated as a matter of urgency and put on the agenda of the next meeting?  All this is happening in the EU 15 years after we harmonised our rules on the reception, procedures and qualification of asylum seekers. This harmonisation was based on the idea of an asylum system with shared responsibilities, yet now it seems that we are stuck in a system of shared ignorance.  I remember vividly that in 2015 the European Council drew conclusions at every meeting on how to deal with the influx of refugees departing from Turkey at that time. The situation in Greece is, in part, a result of the measures the Council took at that time, such as the EU-Turkey deal. What now remains four years later is silence. So is the Council prepared at least to put this on the agenda and discuss evacuation, relocation, and speeding up family reunification and ensure that the rights of asylum seekers are respected in the EU?

name: Rob Rooken (ECR).
text: – Mr President, EU leaders will discuss the 2030 climate and energy framework at the forthcoming European Council. This framework is intended, among other things, to encourage investment in green technologies.  We believe that nuclear energy is the greenest technology at the moment. It is the most safe, clean and sustainable energy source. However, renewable energy plays a key role in the EU's long-term strategy. For example, billions of EU subsidies are being spent on polluting and jungle-destroying biomass plants, while generating biomass energy emit more CO2 than coal and gas currently.  I would therefore call on EU leaders to review nuclear energy objectively and to allocate more money to research into genuinely innovative developments such as thorium plants.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, given the programme of this week, I guess this is a good opportunity to express my thanks and appreciation to the Commission of Mr Jean-Claude Juncker and the work of Mr Donald Tusk. I guess that the future can better judge how much they did for our united Europe, but in my view the benchmark for the next team is very high.  Let me go to the Council programme and both points of the programme are points of very high importance. But there are some points that are even more important. This is the ability to work together, to cooperate and find good solutions that will allow us to solve the problems that are standing behind us and that must be, or should be, solved on a European level.  So far, we have been able to successfully demonstrate unity in many matters; let me mention Brexit, let me mention the Russian sponsored war in Ukraine, or maybe dealing with the trade issues with Donald Trump’s administration. But in other matters we are not working so well, for example not only in financial matters but in very important issues in the area of foreign policy, like the case of Albania and Macedonia, the issues that are making us weaker and can make our neighbourhoods less safe. On the climate issue, I fully support the view that Europe should play a central role in efforts to reduce the climate risk. This is a matter of responsibility, a matter of important transformation of our economy and an issue that can be very beneficial for our future. We should act decisively but we should respect, in my view, some principles.  First of all, our policy should be evidence-based, should be based on the impact assessment analysis and studies. We should favour the market approach and technological neutrality. Second, it is good to set ambitious long-term targets, but it’s even more important to deliver on existing targets because only through fulfilling our promises can we reach the long-term goals.  Last, but not least, predictability and fair conditions for our businesses are very key. If the rules are predictable businesses can adjust and we also should make sure that there will be a level playing field for our businesses, maybe through the introduction of some equaliser like a border adjustment tax. I guess we can succeed. We can employ new technologies. We can, if we set the rules, we will benefit, we will benefit substantially but only if we make a good policy.  Last, on financial issues, I just want to say that money is money but time is also money. I call on the Council to find, as soon as possible, good compromise solutions because the cost of delay is substantial. Let me also say that if climate is the key priority, it should be fully respected in our financial plans.  I hope the Council will act according to the principle that if we act together we are stronger, if not we are weaker. I prefer the first one, I hope the Commission and Council do too.

name: Pedro Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, to the Presidency of the Council and to First Vice—President Timmermans, I want to say that Europe really needs institutions that work. Tomorrow, we’ll face a vote for the new Commission and the opportunity to really start meeting citizens’ expectations. It is time to deliver on decarbonisation, on the European Pillar of Social Rights, and on a fair digital economy. The Commission has indeed an ambitious agenda in which we recognise many of our proposals, but we won’t come even close to Europeans’ hopes and dreams if we keep stalling everything that is relevant. In one word, we need to put our money where our mouth is. So let us demand from the Council nothing less than an ambitious budget for the next term. It is time to stop demanding more and more from the European policies, while wanting to pay even less for it. We can do it. We can bridge the gaps by bringing own resources to the table. It is time to go back to basics. This Union is about sharing a common dream of peace and sustainable development for all and, in this case, solidarity pays back through the reinforcement of the single market. Therefore it benefits all Europe, particularly those that tend to say that they just pay for the others. Quo vadis, Europe? Where are the resources we need for the new priorities to come alive?

name: Valter Flego (Renew).
text: – Dear Chairman, I don't know how much we are to blame for all that is happening outside around us, for these temperatures, for the situation in Venice, for climate change, but I know that we are the last generation that has time to remediate this situation, that we are the ones who have to take responsibility. And this can be done in two ways, with the help of funds and with the help of the law.  That is why I ask that both the 2020 budget and all subsequent budgets take this into account. Of course, agricultural policy is important, cohesion policy for less developed countries is important, but I ask that at least 25% of the budget is very much financed by the fight against climate change and digitalisation. What I said is that the same is important and what we have in our hands are laws, but not only to legistise, but also to impose sanctions and penalties for those who do not comply with the provisions of all these laws. When we talk about funds, one should think and act with two different funds. One is a fund that enables an energy transition to clean energy sources and the other is funds for remediation of damages to natural disasters because they are already happening.  When we talk about one of the fundamental policies of the European Union, one of them is the enlargement policy. I think the decision not to give the green light to North Macedonia and Albania is one big, big, unbelievable rookie mistake by the European Union, a mistake that wins the right-wing populist parties. That is why I ask that this mistake be corrected, that again Europe be one that I believe in, open, tolerant, a Europe that includes other Member States. And last but not least, there was a huge earthquake in Albania last night. I'm not saying it's your fault, it is for the political earthquake that's happening in Albania and North Macedonia, but let's help Albania. Let's show heart, resources and great humanitarian assistance I ask that we send to Albania. Now and now.

name: Anna Zalewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Young people listening to our debate and mentioned in every fiery speech expect neither hysteria nor t-shirts with inscriptions similar to those they have, nor the preaching and writing of slogans on cardboard boxes. They expect action. That's why they chose us. They need security guarantees. When is this possible? Then when we honestly put every problem, when we honestly and honestly say how long it will take to investigate for the purposes we set ourselves, and how much it will cost.  I am therefore pleased that climate change and the multiannual financial plans will be discussed by the Council under the new presidency. However, I would like to ask that we analyse what has come out and what has not succeeded, that we examine the potential of each country, including its reduction potential, and finally that the Council learn how Frans Timmermans will write a new climate law in a hundred days. It has been announced, no one knows what it looks like, and you have to put money into it.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the work of the rapporteur for her excellent work The next Council will be the first Council after tomorrow's election of the new Commission and after the Commission takes office by Ursula von der Leyen. You therefore have a chance. The Council has the opportunity to behave like a gentleman and to approach the new President of the Commission and her work programme and to change his attitude towards the Commission and the future of the European Union. And whoever is in favour of the new Commission must learn from the mistakes of the past. I therefore expect you, as a morning gift for the new Commission, to remove unanimity on all those issues relating to the European Union's ability to act in the world and to greater fairness and fairness within the European Union. I expect you to take measures that will make the objectives of the new Commission in the area of climate protection, migration, external border protection, and the budget achievable. Stop the debate about percentages and nation-state vanities. Go and open up your statements to our common challenges to Europe's role in the world and to all those issues where we have seen in recent years that we are reaching our limits in the decision-making and opinion-forming process, thereby reducing and jeopardising the hopes of citizens in the European Union project – tax policy, migration, asylum, security, research. , investment, Africa policy, climate and environmental protection, to name but a few.  Helmut Kohl once said that the major challenges we face are forcing us all to cooperate. They cannot be dealt with by individual countries alone in the spirit of the old national thinking. Yes so is it. But then we stop constantly telling the citizens that we can solve the issues in the Member States alone, rather than approaching each other.  As a Council, behave like a gentleman to the new President of the Commission – then we will have a good future together.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Madam President, a month ago the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the next multi-year financial framework, which, on behalf of the newly elected representatives, set out our position for negotiating the EU budget for the period 2021-2027. In particular, we affirmed our desire not to be forced by the heads of state or government around the table of the next council on 12 and 13 December. Indeed, be aware that Parliament is ready and well prepared. We have a proven case and we will defend an ambitious budget that provides the European Union with the financial resources to meet the commitments it has made. This is what Europeans, including young people on the streets, expect for climate marches and, more generally, civil society. We therefore want real political and financial efforts to achieve our objectives and respect the Paris Agreement while ensuring a just ecological transition for all. It is therefore not gratifying to consider refusing a MFF if the proposed project does not suit us, but it is our responsibility to remind that this is the expectation of Europeans, and especially of young people, for the next five years. We are at a crossroads and everything is at stake. That is why we deplore the delay already taken in these negotiations, which portends the worst for the final beneficiaries. I am thinking in particular of the associations that deal with the poorest, such as food banks which, already in 2014, have found themselves in great difficulty due to institutional delays. This time, I reiterate here a request already made in last October's resolution to the European Commission: it is really necessary to prepare an emergency plan to protect the final beneficiaries and ensure continuity of funding in the event of a deadlock scenario.  Parliament is ready and we want this budget to meet the expectations of our fellow citizens.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the theme of the day is climate change and the European Union budget for 2021-2027. The European Council will discuss the topics in question and prepare budget priorities. We want to be a leader in the fight against climate change, in social policy, in justice, in the rule of law, in international aid, in education, but we also want to be a leader in gender equality and freedom and in many other areas. This is right, because the EU has potential and is indeed a world leader in many areas, many of these areas already today. But we need to know how we're going to pay for all this. If we want to reduce emissions by 40% by 2030, we will actually have to find a huge amount of financial resources to do so. And then to achieve a real revolution that will lead to a no-emission economy by 2050. However, we also need the socio-economic impacts of these proposals and these plans. I ask that this change should finally be made a real contribution, especially to rich multinationals, which bear a great responsibility on today's status quo and, moreover, benefit extremely from it. I call for an end to tax evasion, tax breaks and for the wealthiest to start participating in achieving this change. I would like to say to the leaders of the Member States that change is right and necessary, but change must not come at the expense of the poorest and working people. Change must be fair and must not punish those people who make up our system and give it life.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Timmermans, Minister, the European Summit will be important for the new annual financial perspective. And it will certainly not be easy, because it will need to be able to strike a balance between traditional priorities such as agriculture, cohesion policy and complex new challenges such as climate change, digitisation, the transition to clean energy. It is therefore essential to seek rational solutions to expand the sources of own resources. However, the most important thing is that the negotiations maintain a fundamental European priority, the creation of a socially sustainable and secure Europe for our people. We must ensure that funding is provided to the most prominent social groups, and I am particularly highlighting the children who are our investment in the future. The necessary financial resources must be allocated to the European guarantee of the child. Let us not forget that we have so far failed to fulfil our obligations to eradicate child poverty. We must invest in young people so that they have the opportunity to learn, work and earn. The creation of quality jobs for all groups of people must also be a priority. Investment in economic growth must ensure that the working person is not in poverty. And I would like to thank the Finnish Presidency for its genuine efforts to find a balanced agreement between the Member States, and I really hope that constructive and socially oriented solutions will be found at the meeting. Success.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the discussion of the Multiannual Financial Framework on the agenda of the next Council is vital for the future of the European project. Parliament's negotiating position is well known and clear: an ambitious budget, about 1.3 % of gross national income, with the right priorities to meet the challenges of the present and the future – energy transition, climate change, migration, security, defence – but without making the fatal mistake of disinvesting in convergence, cohesion and rural development. And it is truly amazing how, a few years ago, some seem already so forgotten about the lessons of the financial crisis that it was also a euro crisis. Without an investment in cohesion and convergence it is not possible to respond to the discontent of citizens that fuels Eurosceptic populism and threatens the European project. We therefore need a sufficient level of national contributions to the Community budget and a strengthening of the Union's own resources, without which, it has already been understood, there will be no solution to this negotiation. In the meantime, we need more ambition and more solidarity for an agreement that is up to the circumstances and that it does not delay the entry into force of a new financial framework for the future of Europe.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, Mr Timmermans, the Council meeting in December will be the first under the leadership of the new President Michel, and the last during the Finnish Presidency ahead of the upcoming Croatian Presidency.  While the agenda is still only in principle, it already contains two topics of utmost importance that will largely define the frameworks of our work in the coming years: climate change and the multiannual budgetary framework.  Climate change requires urgent engagement, i.e. adoption of concrete measures to change global warming trends and abolish carbon dioxide emissions al more fully by 2050. The projects we are already achieving, for example, on islands, through a clean energy transition programme can serve as a good example. The islands may be at the foreman of our actions.  Differences in positions around the multiannual budgetary framework remain large. That may be why it's hard to predict the result of the negotiations. Parliament's position on 1.3% of gross social product is justified, especially in the context of a reduced budget due to the possibility of Brexit as early as January. Therefore, we need a progressive budget with sufficient resources to effectively finance the priorities set, from the Green New Deal, through education, research and development, to structural social and cohesion funds. The latest target differences between citizens, regions and member states. We also need adequate resources to expand. Despite recent erroneous decisions, this policy needs to be given new momentum, support and formal recognition through the increased IPA III pre-access assistance instrument.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος (PPE).
text: Madam President, in this Chamber I am speaking as a European citizen, and really, that is how we should all think. The Dublin Regulation must be replaced by a single European asylum policy, with all Member States participating. We first heard about a refugee crisis somewhere in 2015. That's not true. We should not be talking about a crisis, but about a large part of the developing world dreaming of the developed, with Europe being the best destination at work and socially. It's a large, incessant, mass population movement.  I wonder when we will manage it uniformly, as a European issue, for our citizens? The MFF must take into account the gateways, the Aegean Sea and Evros, in order to protect the social fabric, to allow regional structures to contribute to the temporary labour and educational security of asylum seekers. I call, above all, on the Council to put on the agenda a proposal to the United Nations for an international conference on the subject. The European Union is an international factor of stability and peace, but third countries involved in the region must also be committed.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Madam President, I too, addressing the Finnish Presidency, will highlight two issues, which in my view are existential threats to the European Union. The huge issue of climate change and the environment has already emerged. I will not say more, because I think the vast majority of colleagues agree that the view that we should manage this problem urgently and rationally is well documented.  The second issue is the existing threats against the European Union, in the form of mainly hybrid covert tools aimed at our security. A glance only at Turkey's behaviour, in Northern Syria, but above all also in the Eastern Mediterranean, where the European Union has its own energy reserves, makes it clear that we should act as soon as possible, securing the future of Europe.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, this morning we saw the release of yet another report bringing to light the urgency of the climate emergency, this time from the UN Environment Programme, which shows that the world needs to ramp up its ambitions for cutting emissions fivefold in order to bring us down to the ambition of only 1.5 degree of warming. Currently, we are on track for more than three degrees of warming. It’s yet another in the daily reminders of the urgency of stepping up our action to match with our words. And if there is one thing on my Christmas list, it is that the European Council in its meeting finally sets a united target for zero carbon and 2050 is still too late. We need urgent action because we, in Europe, bear historic responsibility for starting this problem, burning fossil fuels to fuel the industrial revolution. We have a responsibility correspondingly to fix it, too, and that starts with leadership in our own department, putting our money where our mouth is, on climate.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, how you spend your money and distribute it will shape the Europe of tomorrow. Ireland is a small country, but since 1970 we have lost 140 000 small farms. It is a direct result of government policy and, sadly, EU policy. We have moved towards industrial farming and away from the production of clean food. We now need to distribute the money of Europe in a manner that would help farmers to move away from chemicals and pesticides. I would also say that you need to stop giving money to the industrial farms – they don’t need it. On environment, I would urge the leaders to consider a permanent ban on all new fossil fuel infrastructure, including liquefied natural gas infrastructure, and those gas infrastructure projects on the EU’s project of common interest list. Infrastructure decisions create path dependencies and these gas infrastructure projects will create fossil fuel lock-in for decades... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Matthew Patten (NI).
text: – Madam President, I’d like to express my best wishes to our Croatian friends for a successful presidency.  Commissioner Timmermans spoke very powerfully about climate change, our responsibilities to our children and the opportunity to be a role model to the world, and Ms Tuppurainen spoke of the challenges of Brexit to the next EU budget and the need for some to pay more and receive less. I think there’s a way that the Council Presidency and new Commission can do both, and that is to take the lead, to set the example, by ending the senseless pollution caused by transporting this Parliament between Brussels and Strasbourg 12 times a year. By 2050 it would save over 600 000 tonnes of CO2 emissions. It would save our hard-pressed taxpayers over EUR 3.5 billion. It would send a massive signal to Europe and the world that the EU is really serious about fighting climate change. It’s simply not sustainable to keep telling others what to do but refuse to do it ourselves. Please will you put this on the agenda?

name: Robert Rowland (NI).
text: – Madam President, what I find extraordinary in this whole debate is the absence of economics. What we’ve seen to date were the two EU climate policies of the Renewable Energy Directive and the Emissions Trading Scheme. Both have failed. The Emissions Trading Scheme has put a completely artificial price on carbon that has led to higher energy prices and the closure of things like British Steel in the UK. The Renewable Energy Directive has led to perverse incentives and the creation of a new crony capitalist subsidy—seeking climate industrial complex that rivals anything that the fossil fuel companies have produced. It’s also led to environmental damage that, for example, leads to virgin forest being been felled for things like wood chips, biomass and biodiesel for palm oil.  The hypocrisy and double standards displayed in this Chamber is truly staggering. In addition, not only have we offshored so much CO2 to China, but we are also offshoring so many manufacturing jobs. So I would warn you, the Commission, to be very careful what you wish for.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Sophia in 't Veld (Renew)
text: blue-card question. – I was a bit surprised to hear you express deep concern about the economic impact of climate policies and you say there was an absence of economics in the debate. But I think most experts agree that Brexit is going to be an absolute disaster for the economy, and yet you support it. Can you explain that?

name: Robert Rowland (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – You are dealing with a hypothetical which may or may not happen, that’s it and I can't prove that and you can’t. But what I can prove is that the climate policies are destroying jobs. Come up to places like Hartlepool, come to Scunthorpe, and you’ll see mass unemployment due to these artificially high carbon prices set by politicians and not by economists. And if you moved to the Green New Deal you’ll continue to see the erosion of jobs and manufacturing which will all be offshored to China. We now produce in the UK 1.1% of all CO2. We’ve offshored it to China.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, just remarks on two issues. On the MFF, I hope the signal given by this Parliament and the Commission to the Council was clear and in very simple words, I would say it’s an illusion to think that the MFF should be more of the same. We want the same, but more of it, that’s not going to fly. We want the same, but less of it, is not going to fly either, so we will have to find a compromise where we do more on what needs to be done now and less on what needed to be done in the past. For that, we need to have a reasonable budget where we convince those Member States who say they are frugal, that it is in their interest to pool our resources at the European level to meet these challenges and we convince those Member States who still cling to outdated policies, that they should embrace the potential of moving that towards new policies especially linked to climate change. This brings me to my second point, and also triggered by some of the remarks that were made. I want to warn of a false contradiction that’s been put on the table by some here, no longer here but some who were here. And that is that there is a contradiction between being ambitious on climate policy and saving our industry. I think it’s exactly the wrong way round. The longer we take to embrace the potential of this transition, the more we will hurt our industry and the potential for jobs in the new economy. I think now that even Jeremy Clarkson recognises that there is a climate crisis, I think there’s no more space for any climate deniers anywhere. So we know we’re faced with an existential crisis and we know we have the collective responsibility to do something about it. I think the sooner we do this, the sooner we put the resources in creating a circular economy, in creating new jobs in the new economy, in helping people transit from the coal mine industry towards a new economy, the sooner we embrace that the sooner we will come out of this as leaders in the world and the sooner we can say to our children and grandchildren: we’ve heard you, we know what our responsibility is, we’re taking it, we’re helping you create a world that is better tomorrow.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for their remarks and comments. I will convey their messages to the President of the European Council. In concluding, let me outline a few things in particular. May I start with the Presidency’s priority, which you mentioned several times, namely the rule of law. Respect for the rule of law is the cornerstone of our Union and, as such, essential for its functioning. As regards Hungary in particular, we started the Article 7 hearings in September. In December, in the General Affairs Council we will organise a second hearing. As a priority, the Presidency has focused on preventive action and on making our rule of law toolbox as effective as possible. Secondly, as noted in this debate, the European Union needs to continue to spearhead climate action and lead by example in order to help raise global ambition. This means engaging in a long—term transition to a climate neutral economy. Such a transition will bring a profound and radical change in almost every industry and the way we go about our daily lives. We know that we need to provide the right incentives for this transformation and we will have to make sure that we leave no one behind, taking into account national and regional specificities and different socioeconomic circumstances. Within the MFF context, this will be reflected as part of our negotiation toolbox. We will provide just transition. As mentioned by some of you, gender balance is another issue that will be addressed in our negotiations box as a very important mainstreaming element. Thirdly, the leaders will provide us with guidance on the overall level of the MFF. We see Europe developing and we see socioeconomic gaps being reduced, meaning that are our policies are effective. But it also means that the level of support from the EU has to be adapted so a realistic budget should be reflecting this. As the Presidency, we are committed to proposing an efficient and effective budget in line with our citizens’ expectations, bringing genuine European added value. Thank you very much for your attention and for this valuable discussion.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. (The sitting was suspended at 11.38 until the formal sitting)

name: Presidente. –
text: It is my pleasure to welcome Mr Oleg Sentsov, the Ukrainian director and writer, who has been released this year and today honours us with his presence here in the European Parliament to receive the 2018 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. First of all, I invite you to watch a short video about Oleg Sentsov. (Screening of a video in the Chamber) Ladies and gentlemen, it is a real honour for the European Parliament to welcome Oleg Sentsov, winner of the 2018 Sakharov Prize. Released in September along with 35 other people as part of a prisoner exchange, Oleg returned to Ukraine after serving five years in prison, as part of a twenty-year sentence on terrorism charges, awarded to him by a Russian court for protesting against the illegal occupation of his native Crimea. Sentsov was still in prison in Siberia last year. His empty seat in this House – many of you will remember this – was an eloquent symbol not only of his struggle for democracy, but also of the emptiness left in society by all those who are punished for telling the truth. A void in the daily lives of families, countries and the democratic community in the world. During the political trial against him in Russia, Sentsov said: 'I do not know what value your convictions have if you are not prepared to suffer or even give your life for them.' I was deeply impressed by what you said, but it struck everyone who listened to them. It is true that courage is not a quality of body, but of spirit, and you, Mr Sentsov, have remained firm in your principles and convictions, and that is why you paid for it.  But no one should have to pay a price for their freedom. There are too many defenders of freedoms, on the other hand, who are forced to be afraid of losing their lives, of never seeing their family and friends again, because they are not prepared to conform or remain silent in the face of human rights violations.  Journalists and artists are increasingly being targeted for expressing their political views. Oleg Sentsov has been released, but many others, including bloggers and journalists such as Stanyslav Aseev, are still being held hostage in eastern Ukraine. Together, we call for them to be released. In the same way, we call for the release of other Sakharov Prize winners or finalists who are still in prison. I would remind you, for example, of Nasrin Sotoudeh of Iran, who was awarded the prize in 2012, who, after a previous release, was arrested again this year and sentenced to thirty-eight years in prison. Others, such as the Damas de Blanco, the Cuban 'women in white' movement, which was awarded the prize in 2005, are still being intimidated by public authorities. Still others, such as Razan Zeitouneh, a Syrian who won the award in 2011, disappeared and left no trace. We have not forgotten and we do not want to forget any of them. The European Union is founded on the values of democracy and human rights. When human rights are called into question, when democracy is at risk and the foundations of the rule of law are being lost, we need the bravest among us: human rights defenders, trade unionists, journalists, bloggers, media workers, artists and publishers, all those who dare to give a voice to those who do not have a voice. Democracy cannot exist without a living and pluralist civil society. That is why we must do everything possible to protect it. Mr Sentsov, I pay tribute to your courage, perseverance and determination. It is an honour for me to award you this prize on behalf of the European Parliament. I am happy now to give you the floor.

name: Oleg Sentsov
text: Winner of the Sakharov Prize 2018. – (The following is a transcription of the interpretation of the original speech from Russian into English) Mr President, good afternoon everybody. Andrei Sakharov, Nelson Mandela, Václav Havel. I would never have imagined that one day my name would be mentioned alongside theirs. It is a huge honour, and also a huge responsibility. Thank you for this. I accept and take this prize not as a personal honour, but as a prize for all Ukrainian political prisoners who have ever been in Russian prisons, and a prize in honour of all Ukrainian political prisoners who are still there; all our prisoners who are in Donbass in the hands of the separatists; all our activists who continue fighting for our country. As an honour for all our military men and women who are fighting for our independence, and some of them have even given their lives for our independence. Currently, a lot is being said and talked about: negotiations and a possible peace with Russia. I don’t trust Mr Putin, and I call upon you not to trust him either. Russia and Putin will absolutely, definitely cheat you. They don’t wish for peace in Donbass or Ukraine. They want to see Ukraine on its knees. They do not want to apply lawful European policy. They would like to rule by their own methods, by force of arms. We won’t allow this, we will fight for our freedom and we will fight to the end. You have many internal discussions and differences here in the EU, you have conflicts, you have different views on how to develop, how to reform, how to go forward. As we say in Russian, ‘we wish we had your problems’. Our problems are much more complex and severe: our country’s corrupt antiquated system has not been changed. We are also subject to military aggression. Each week our military men and women are dying. We have a different level of problems. But given all your internal challenges, the EU is developing. I think it is a great institution and you are a good example to all of us. There is a country which is the greatest Euro-optimist in the world today: it is called Ukraine. For us, there is no other path for development and no other way out. For us, this is a question of survival as a nation. So every time any of you ponder how to be friendly with Mr Putin over our heads, please remember the thousands who have fallen in Ukraine. Please remember hundreds of our young men who are still languishing behind bars who might be subject to torture right now as I speak. Please remember those Russian Tatars who could be arrested right now at this moment. Their houses may be searched, families, children, may lose fathers, brothers. Please remember those young men who right now, at this moment, are in their military fatigues, with this kind of sign on their sleeve in the trenches, risking their lives for our freedom – and also for your freedom. Please don’t forget them. Thank you. Long live Ukraine. (Long and sustained applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, last night the earth returned to tremble in Albania, in an area between the cities of Durazzo and Tirana. The first information tells us of several deaths, many injured and many displaced persons. On behalf of the European Parliament and on my own behalf, I would like to express my condolences to the families of the victims and my complete solidarity with the Albanian people.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ID).
text: Mr President, our vote against the changes in trade preferences for poultry meats, as stipulated in the European Union-Ukraine agreement, is not a condemnation of our Ukrainian neighbour but a condemnation of the European Commission. Indeed, Ukraine cannot be blamed for exploiting a loophole in the wording of the 2,000-page agreement and thus defending its commercial interests, even though we were initially opposed to this agreement. Here we condemn the European Commission and its glaring lack of rigour and foresight, the Commission which negotiates with all-out agreements which it is not then able to assume, the Commission which, when it receives proof of its incapacity and even though it wanted to reduce imports of its poultry parts, prefers to fold and renegotiate discreetly , finally winning Ukraine's case by granting it even more export quotas. This agreement is proof of the Commission's inability to defend our productions, our workers and our consumers and is further proof of the weakness of a declining European Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much. I would also ask you to end this photo session with banners. Banners are not allowed in the Chamber and are contrary to the Rules of Procedure. I would ask you to refrain from doing so in the future, especially during a colleague's speech.

name: Robert Roos (ECR).
text: – Mr President, on 6 April 2016, forum for democracy in the Netherlands organised a referendum on the adoption of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. 61% of voters felt that the Netherlands should not approve this agreement. The reason: this treaty is not in the interest of the Netherlands.  It is not surprising that Ukraine has circumvented the agreements in the treaty. As a result, chicken meat exports to the EU have increased from 3 700 tonnes in 2016 to a staggering 55 000 tonnes in 2018. We have just been forced to vote in favour of an amendment to the treaty: an increase of 50 000 tonnes.  The chicken farmers in the Netherlands and the other EU countries have become an unfair competitor. Exactly what 61% of dutch voters were afraid of has now happened. We call on the EU to terminate this treaty with Ukraine.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: May I ask again, including the folders, for the lords, who take photos here at the back with banners in their hands, to leave the room. It is contrary to our Rules of Procedure. This is also the case when a group chairman is present.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this agreement, or the addition to the Association Agreement. Trade with Ukraine is extremely important not only economically, but mainly politically. We are supporting the economy of Ukraine, our partner in the East. If we do not support Ukraine economically, then Russia's interest in this area will continue to strengthen. I am simply looking at this change geopolitically, which is why I supported it, although some may argue that the change is not beneficial for the Member States of the European Union. We must promote ukraine's stability in this form, support a country that is a dividing line between Europe and Russia. It is, in my opinion, extremely important.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported this proposal that has been tabled for several reasons. Firstly, we are following a really clear support for Ukraine as a state. We have approved the Association Agreement and, among other things, preferential access to the European market, which is one of the components of this association agreement. We must support Ukraine, I fully subscribe to this, I think it is in the interests of both units, that is, both the Ukrainian Community and the European Union as a whole. Yesterday, it was clarified in the debate that certain concerns and gaps resulting from the proposal tabled had been removed. I would like to thank Commissioner Hogan for actually doing so. Concerns about respect for the principles of welfare, i.e. the protection of animal rights, sanitary and phytosanitary requirements were reflected in the proposal. Of course, I see that there are also interests of European farmers, but supporting Ukraine is a priority. In this sense, my support was also a priority.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to support this amendment to the UK— Ukraine agreement which closes the loophole on poultry and which has been having a significant impact on our poultry farmers in recent times. This loophole was found by Ukrainian suppliers and meant that a certain cut, consisting of traditional breast cap with the humerus bone of the wings attached, could be marketed in the EU as a chicken breast by removing the bone, and was then tariff-free, as it entered the EU as a different product. Unlimited imports of those cuts, of which imports from Ukraine reached 55 500 tonnes in 2018, therefore risk undermining the conditions under which traditional poultry breast cuts had been imported into the Union under the association agreement. I welcome that this issue has now been resolved, but call on the Commission in future such negotiations to ensure that all checks and assessments are made in advance to prevent it happening again.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – A Uachtaráin, inniu, vótáil mé ar son na tairisceana i gcomhair rúin maidir le cearta an linbh a ghlacadh agus 30 bliain den Choinbhinsiún um Chearta an Linbh á chomóradh againn. Tá géarchéim mhór in Éirinn faoi láthair agus tá dúshláin ollmhóra roimh a lán leanaí mar gheall ar easpa dídine. In Éirinn, bíonn beagnach 4,000 leanbh i gcóiríocht éigeandála gach lá. Is bocht an scéal é seo in Éirinn agus ní féidir linn glacadh leis. Ní féidir linn glacadh leis ach oiread go bhfuil páistí ag fulaingt de bharr na géarchéime seo. Ní mór d’Éirinn agus do na Ballstáit go léir a n-oibleagáidí faoin gCoinbhinsiún a chomhlíonadh agus a chinntiú go bhfuil caighdeán ceart maireachtála agus cóiríochta ag gach leanbh.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ID).
text: Mr President, our negative vote on the draft resolution, presented by three-quarters of the groups in this Parliament, is obviously not directed against children, quite the contrary. It is precisely because the fifteen pages of this very long resolution are only wishful thinking that we have not been able to follow it. It is a copy of the texts that did nothing to prevent violence against children. In our view, it should have been - and this is what we said in our alternative resolution - to show an educational and economic moral force driven by each Member State and relayed by the European Union. But the latter clearly did not play its part. It should have been in its own right to be in the fight against all the perversions and violence against children around the world. It should also have shown a much greater economic strength, both towards families who find themselves in a state of poverty, but also in view of the national economic systems that have stagnated since the last global economic crisis. Children around the world deserve better than the wait-and-see attitude of a European lesson-giver.

name: Antony Hook (Renew).
text: – Mr President, among the most important rights of every child is not to grow up in poverty, but for too many this right is denied. Children grow up in housing that is damp and in disrepair, and schools and healthcare are understaffed. There is unprecedented air pollution, and there’s also a known link between poverty and mental health problems. The UK has four million children living in poverty – 30% of all our children, nine out of every class of 30. Poverty is rising because living costs are rising and pay is stagnating, made worse because Brexit has destroyed growth in our economy. That is why Liberal Democrats fight to stop Brexit.  It’s time for a European-wide guarantee for the welfare of every child. This Parliament has previously called for a child guarantee for every child at risk to receive schooling, housing, healthcare and nutrition. Let Europe unite in protecting all of our children.

name: Marcel Kolaja (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, 30 years after the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, many efforts have yielded results, yet much more still needs to be done to fully protect children. The European Pirates want the public authorities and police forces to have the human capacity to properly respond to the threat of criminals sharing child abuse material over the internet. We should insist on human intervention via internet hotlines, enabling the exchange of information, and helplines assisting victims of abuse. Calling on private companies to monitor the entire internet in order to make sure that nobody is sending wrong images is, however, not the way forward. When effective law enforcement is increasingly outsourced to private companies and their dominant technologies with very little public intervention, we are only helping to hide the representation of abuse without any guarantee of investigation and prosecution of criminals. While children’s rights need to be protected for the reasons mentioned, we unfortunately could not support the motion for a resolution.

name: Yana Toom (Renew).
text: – Mr President, according to the Egmont Institute, right now there are approximately 700 European children in refugee camps al-Hawl, al-Roj and Ain Issa. The UN says it is impossible to estimate the number of European children in Iraq and Syria as many of them were born there during the war.  The safe repatriation of children should be our priority but so far France has repatriated 18, Sweden 7 and Germany fewer than 10 children. At the same time, the right to return to the state of which one is a national is enshrined in several legal documents. It’s shameful that in practice we are imputing responsibility on children for crimes committed by their parents and let them stay and grow up in terrifying conditions in refugee camps. That’s why I supported this resolution, and especially paragraph 61.

name: Jarosław Duda (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted in favour of the resolution on the rights of children because I believe that this is a very well-prepared, comprehensive document. Children are our greatest treasure, and they will determine the future of the world. It is our duty to protect them from the effects of wars, hunger, poverty, slave labour and abuse, and to ensure that they have access to education and healthcare.  I am pleased that the resolution stresses the importance of investing in children, a holistic approach to education, the availability of crèches and kindergartens, promoting the harmonious development of the child in all dimensions and combating all discrimination. Children with disabilities, already experienced by fate, are often victims of discriminatory education and employment systems. Our job is to change that. I am convinced that the resolution adopted today will be a starting point and a signpost for the European Parliament's further action on behalf of children.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Mr President! I voted in favour of the resolution because, for me, it is a measure of civility. This is because the ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child and respect for the rights of the child define us as human beings. In doing so, the European Parliament has confirmed the commitments and, in fact, strengthened these commitments from both the European Union and the Members, and, of course, opened up the possibility of accession to the Convention by the European Union itself and the commitment to all children, not just to some.  It is a powerful resolution that has rejected an attack by two groups, that is, Identity and Democracy and European Conservatives and Reformists, in which the key principles are the ownership of children's rights and the best interests of the child, what is at the forefront, and for a social democrat, of course, child poverty and social exclusion are unacceptable.  However, I know, and it is necessary to add to this cooperation with both the countries within the European Union and with the Council of Europe and the United Nations.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew).
text: – Mr President, we are talking about the rights of the child and today in the European Union there are Member States where children do not have fundamental access to fundamental rights, such as food or education. We are talking about the rights of the child and there are Member States in the European Union that wanted to criminalise the right to sex education. I myself come from a country that is champion of the number of teenage mothers.  In 2017 more than 18,000 births were recorded in Romania in teenage mothers. 700 of these mothers were under the age of 15. Most teenage mothers come from poor backgrounds, without access to healthcare, without access to education and information. There is a fundamental need for coordinated support in the European Union to ensure these rights of the child. We cannot have children in the European Union giving birth to other children.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar an rúin seo de bharr na béime a chuireann sé ar chearta leanaí. Cuireann an rún seo béim ollmhór ar chearta leanaí atá faoi mhíbhuntáiste. San áireamh, tá leanaí faoi mhíchumas, leanaí a tháinig go dtí an tAontas Eorpach ón taobh amuigh, leanaí atá faoi ghlas agus leanaí a thagann ó chúlra Romach. Mar Fheisirí tá dualgas orainn seasamh suas do gach duine. Go háirithe ár leanaí. Caithfidh muid neamhfhulaingt ar fhostú páistí a thaispeáint agus brú a chur ar ár mBallstáit chun a chinntiú go mbeidh oideachas d’ardchaighdeán oscailte do gach duine. Sin an fáth gur vótáil mé i bhfabhar an rúin seo.

name: Dragoş Pîslaru (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I am happy to be the co-starter of this resolution, and I have obviously voted for the proposed text, because there is no better way to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child than through a renewed commitment. I sincerely hope that this resolution, together with the priority expressed by the new Commission to implement the children's guarantee, indicates to European citizens that the European Union is firmly committed to eradicating child poverty and guaranteeing children's rights in Europe and the world. In Romania, four out of ten children are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This situation is unacceptable and I will fight the whole mandate for children's access to education, health, adequate nutrition and decent housing. We will fight at home in Romania, we will fight in Europe for the future of our children, for our future, for the future.

name: Guido Reil (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I did not vote in favour of the resolution because I find it shameful that this important issue of 'children's rights' is being used to further fuel climate hysteria. I also find it shameful that young unaccompanied undocumented refugees should be further supported. So in Germany, in my country, each of these young undocumented undocumented undocumented refugees is supported by the taxpayer with EUR 6 000, and it is precisely this group – which is so particularly bitter – that is, unfortunately, particularly often responsible for the most serious crimes. Let us finally address real problems: FGM – that is an issue; Child marriage - that's an issue. Issues that are getting worse and worse: forced prostitution of minors – that is an issue; Child pornography on the Internet is a huge issue, with 45 million images and films of child abuse on the internet; Child poverty is a huge issue. There are an incredible number of real issues. Let's finally attack them.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, all of us in this Chamber care about the rights and dignities of children. I don’t think I’m setting the bar very high here, right? The desire to protect children is the most basic of all human instincts. It’s buried deep in our DNA, it’s necessary for the survival of our species. So why did I just vote against this Declaration on the Rights of the Child? Because, yet again, something that has a motherhood and apple pie title is, in fact, filled with a miscellany of trivia, with congeries of accretions – all sorts of issues that have nothing whatsoever to do with the basic title. There are some amendments from the right, some from the left, there are issues here to do with abortion, to do with LGBT rights, to do with sex education, to do with the rights of children of fighters in the militia camps in Iraq and Syria.  Some I agree with, some I don’t, but here’s what they all have in common: they are not EU competences. Sensitive issues of this kind should be dealt with by national parliamentarians elected on respectable turnouts, known to their constituents and therefore in a way that we cannot be answerable to their peoples.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. I have to say, with a bit of a heavy heart, because I did not want to give a signal that I do not want, of course, what is in the best interests and rights of the child.  I would like to start by saying that the European Union should become a signatory to this international convention and the Commission should do everything possible to do so, and this is what one of the challenges of this motion for a resolution has been. This proposal addressed a number of points, violence, new forms of violence against children, psychological forms of violence, in particular committed on the Internet, forced marriages, slave labour, access to nurseries, quality education. A number of topics have been well named. But I also resent how much ideology has been inserted into this resolution. I think that, unfortunately, my political faction has also caused me to have to vote with a heavy heart. In the future, I would prefer to welcome less ideology and the specific practical problems that we are supposed to address in such a motion for a resolution.

name: Patrick Breyer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, this resolution on children’s rights is an important and necessary one. We Pirate Party members of this House, however, regret to see that certain stakeholders, including powerful lobby groups, are using this important resolution to promote their own commercial products. And political groups like the EPP are taking children hostage of private interests and make their support of this entire resolution dependent on this language being included. We fiercely oppose technology to subject an entire network to surveillance, because there are just too many ways to abuse it. The resolution also grossly misrepresents the findings of the quoted study. Internet service providers are increasingly using filters to detect and report the unlawful distribution of child sexual abuse material, but there is no evidence that the total number of such images – reported or unreported – is actually increasing. So, for these reasons, the Pirate delegation regrets that we cannot support the resolution, due to paragraph 16 and recital O and we abstained.

name: Mikuláš Peksa (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to follow up on the previous speaker from the Pirates delegation, Marcel Kolaja and Patrick Breyer. I stand by the fact that we must not take the protection of the rights of the child lightly and I want to protect them. However, I do not agree with the procedure that was inadvertently inserted into this text in recital and Article 16. For this reason, I abstained and stand by my decision.

name: Presidente. –
text: The session restarts at 15:04.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the report by Monika Hohlmeier and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2020 [11734/2019 - C9-0119/2019 - 2019/2028(BUD)] (A9-0035/2019). I would remind you that it is possible to request cards for the catch the eye and 'blue card' procedures, either through traditional registration or through the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Johan Van Overtveldt
text: Chairman BUDG. Mr President, last week we reached an agreement on the 2020 budget after intense discussions between the Council and Parliament, of course, with the commission's highly regarded role in the whole process. The result of these days-long discussions and this joint effort is that we have come to a budget that, taking into account the budgetary constraints and budgetary discipline that must certainly be respected at European level, is forward-looking and meets citizens' expectations. It is a strong, forward-looking budget, a budget that – and this is very important at this stage – bridges the gap to another multi-annual financial plan in which we must resolutely continue to work towards the Europe of the 21st century. It seems quite obvious to me at the moment, when we look around the world: it will depend to a large extent on that multiannual budget and what we can achieve in it whether Europe will be able to play the leading role in the 21st century that it can legitimately claim, but which it must act on.  We are making a major shift in investment in areas where the EU offers added value, such as research and development and energy infrastructure, in the coming year. A strengthening of programmes in high demand, which have proven their effectiveness very clearly, such as Erasmus, Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. Security and migration, too, this budget was given the necessary attention to do what European citizens are asking for. We must dare to go in the same directions in the same direction. We must choose a budget that does indeed take into account the needs of our citizens in an explicit, clear and decisive way, a budget which – once again, the points where Europe can absolutely add value to the national level – to innovation, competitiveness, climate, infrastructure, security and migration management.  As chairman of the Committee on Budgets, I would also like to thank all those involved in the drafting and final agreement, firstly the rapporteurs, Mrs Monika Hohlmeier and Mrs Eider Gardiazabal, but certainly Mr Kimmo Tiilikainen, Secretary of State for the Finnish Presidency. Behind these people there is a whole battery of employees who have also worked with a lot of effort and perseverance – I have been able to experience it for the first time and with great pleasure. Of course, I should also like to mention Commissioner Günther Oettinger and his people, who have contributed more than their part to the final result, which I am very proud of in any case as chairman of the Committee on Budgets.  What I think we can still learn from the process we have seen over the last two weeks is that it is indeed very useful to talk to each other in an open, direct way, to make it clear to each other what the respective parties are talking about, and then to reach a compromise from that clarity. There is nothing more difficult than reaching a compromise when the starting points are unclear. I think that perhaps the great merit of the parties involved in these discussions has been that it was very clear from the outset what the objectives were, where they wanted to go, so that there was room for compromise. I think that's happened in a successful way.  Once again, many thanks to all the people involved.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, dear Finnish Presidency, dear Kimmo Tiilikainen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has all said. I would like to begin by thanking you. A thank you – forgive me at the beginning – to my colleagues in the negotiating team, in particular to Johan Van Overtveldt, to Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, who were allowed to conduct the direct negotiations with me, but also to my shadow rapporteurs and to the coordinators – Clotilde is looking at me, you, Mr Andresen, are also looking at me. We have really tried to work together, to communicate with each other here. We have agreed on common positions. I would like to thank Kimmo Tiilikainen for the fact that, after we initially fought fiercely with each other, he tried to negotiate fairly with us and we had common priorities with us and now also provide these common priorities financially. It is clear that Parliament would have liked to have had more. It is also clear that some in the Council would have liked to have had less. But I believe that we have reached good compromises. EUR 850 million more for climate protection expenditure in the field of research and innovation, including jobs and competitiveness, youth and digitalisation: that is a great deal that we have been able to achieve together. We have been able to increase the total budget lines dealing with climate protection by EUR 504 million. More than 21% of expenditure is therefore climate-related, and we are very clearly above the 20% target, but we still have a lot of work to do to get to 25% or even higher. Horizon 2020 is up 8.8%. I must honestly say that I was somewhat stunned to read the unilateral declaration by the countries that voted against it – in particular Denmark, the Netherlands, Austria and Sweden – which states, firstly, that there are not enough margins and, secondly, that it is far above what is needed. I have to say soberly that Horizon 2020 has so many programmes that are completely oversubscribed, where we can only support 7 or 8% of the programmes at all. That is why I simply cannot understand such a declaration and I am grateful to all the Member States that share this compromise with us. The fact that there are no more margins is simply wrong. We still have EUR 1.5 billion in margins for 2020 and the last two years alone, up to EUR 4.2 billion. I believe that we have really met the Council in this respect as well.
