However, it was important to us to support the issue of climate protection in the area of CEF Energy with EUR 96 million, CEF transport with EUR 37 million, the European satellite systems, which are also essential in matters of climate research, Erasmus – Youth Exchange – with EUR 50 million more, a total of EUR 2.9 billion and an increase of 3.6%, the Youth Employment Initiative with EUR 28.3 million and, if necessary, a further EUR 50 million from June. We were able to increase Life, not as much as we would have liked, but at least. However, we have not left out security issues – the eppO issue, a bit more Europol – that is, we have given the money where it is necessary. We have been in the media sector, in coal regions in transition, in order to answer important questions of climate protection. I believe that we have put together an all-round solid package. I would like to thank my fellow Members most sincerely for their support, and for the Presidency and the Commission together, for successfully completing or deciding on the negotiations.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the truth is that when we started these negotiations we had very far-fluer positions and, of course, nothing would foreshadow that we could reach an agreement. When we talked about priorities, it is true that the Council and Parliament were talking about the same priorities, but when we then translated these priorities into figures we made a difference of EUR 4.5 billion. We had two days of intense negotiations, Friday and Monday. We were already on the edge and, in the end, we managed to reach a point of agreement. Above all, and I think it is the most important thing, we were able to send a very clear message about what the priorities were for the future of the European Union and, above all, how we were going to finance them.  And this agreement we reached has allowed us to strengthen key lines with more than 850 million euros in those priorities on which we agreed. For example, the Horizon 2020 programme – the largest research programme in the European Union – compared to 2019 is increased by 8.8%. I believe that this is a good sign for the entire scientific community, and also that one in five euros of this budget will be earmarked for the fight against climate change.  We are a long way from the goals we have set ourselves, but at least we are teaching the way we have to go. And, of course, we send a very clear message to young people, because we have strengthened two policies that are directly aimed at them. We have improved the funding of Erasmus – one of the most beloved programmes in the European Union – and we have also managed to put the youth guarantee programme back on the table. We have managed to allocate EUR 145 million by 2020 and also an extra EUR 50 million if necessary, because the programme is working well. The truth is that from other sections, which was the part that I had to negotiate, there would not be much to point out, although I think we have maintained a fairly balanced agreement and at least we have not cut the budgets of the other institutions. So at least I think this will allow them to be able to carry out their work in decent conditions. In short, I believe that this is a very positive agreement for the European Union, but, as always, there is a but in all this. I believe that we cannot fall into complacency, because we are a long way from the objectives which I believe we have to put on the table for the European Union. We are a long way from that 1.3% for the financial framework demanded by this Parliament and with which we would really have a budget strong enough to mark a turning point in European policies and, above all, to lead certain policies such as the fight against climate change, which really needs momentum from the European Union. And I want to end up doing a thank you. Of course, the negotiating team of the European Parliament, with the President at the helm and with the rapporteur, Mrs Hohlmeier, who defended this Parliament's position tooth and nail; the Commissioner and his entire team – it has been his last budget, but that I believe leaves an important legacy in his work and I want to give him a very special recognition; and, above all, the Finnish Presidency and Kimmo Tiilikainen, because I think he has been a very tough negotiator, but also very empathetic with the positions that the two institutions held.  And he told us a story I'm not going to repeat here because I don't have time. But in the end, we did manage to save that dog that was in danger at the time. And I believe that this story, which may be an anecdote in the negotiations, has been the one that brought together the two negotiating teams and the one that finally made us get this deal. So thank you very much. They have been an example of how budgets have to be negotiated.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mrs Eider, it is not every day that we see so many greetings to the representatives of all the institutions in a negotiation.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it’s my pleasure to attend today the European Parliament’s debate on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2020. I would like to express the Council’s satisfaction with the agreement reached by the Conciliation Committee on 18 November – the last day of the conciliation period – after long and intense discussions. The positive outcome of the negotiations shows that our three institutions can work efficiently in a spirit of good cooperation. Together, we negotiated a budget for 2020 which responds to today’s concerns and tomorrow’s needs of Europe’s citizens.  The European Parliament and the Council have worked hard to find a solution that would equip the Union for the challenges of the last year of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The deal we reached reflects strongly our common priorities – climate action, growth and competitiveness, research and digitalisation, young people, security and migration. This year we have made a considerable effort to strengthen the climate relevance of the EU budget and get as close as possible to fulfilling the Union’s 20% climate target to be reached by 2020. To this aim, we have reinforced relevant programmes in the area of research and development, transport and energy infrastructure and the EU’s external action. Additional funds have also been allocated to the LIFE programme. In order to improve the situation of young people and help them integrate into the labour market, we have agreed to dedicate EUR 145 million to the youth employment initiative. The other successful programme, providing opportunities for young Europeans to study, train and gain experience abroad, Erasmus+, will see an increase of 3.6%. Furthermore, programmes and projects supporting competitiveness increased by 7.9% compared with 2019. This means more funds for Horizon 2020, the European satellite navigation systems, EGNOS and Galileo, and the energy and transport strands of the Connecting Europe facility.  In the area of migration and security, a number of key EU agencies, such as Frontex, EASA, Europol and Eurojust, will be endowed with additional staff and funding in view of their in-house mandates. In addition, we have provided ourselves with more means to tackle the root causes of migration and step up the EU’s engagement with our neighbours to the east and the south.  While posting support for EU flagship programmes, we have at the same time applied a prudent and responsible approach in line with sound financial management. The Council insisted on such an approach during the whole budgetary procedure and has continuously stressed the need to take into account financial realities at national level. The final result achieved on 18 November foresees a 1.5% increase in the global level of commitments compared with 2019. The remaining margin of EUR 1.5 billion under expenditure ceilings of the MFF will allow us to cope with next year’s contingencies and uncertainties. In this way, we have together established a realistic budget for 2020, which is focused on a maximum European added value for money and takes fully into account taxpayers’ interests and concerns.  In our official meetings in the course of the year, as well as during our informal contacts, I very much appreciated the positive atmosphere that prevailed in our talks. Both sides of the table were ready to engage constructively to reach an agreement to reframe the discussion around shared interests and come up with solutions. I am glad to inform you that after the successful outcome of the Conciliation Committee, the joint text was formally approved by the Council yesterday. The Council expects the European Parliament to also approve the joint text tomorrow. The general budget for the financial year 2020 will then be adopted within the deadline foreseen by the Treaties.  Coming to the end of my intervention, I would like to thank the Chairman of the European Parliament’s Committee on Budgets, Mr Johan Van Overtveldt, and the rapporteurs, Ms Monika Hohlmeier and Ms Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, for their positive and open attitude and for the good cooperation during the last weeks and months. Your hard work and enthusiasm can be highly commended. Together we saved the day. I would also like to extend my special thanks to you, Commissioner Oettinger – Gunther – for your contribution to our negotiations for the last time. Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your attention.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Tiilikainen, I would like to thank mr Tiilikainen for the work he has done. On the one hand, we had a starting point with a very good chance of agreement, because the priorities were the same for Parliament and the Council: firstly, investment in research, innovation and the future of Europe, the second action against climate change and the third fight against unemployment, job creation, especially for the younger generation. On the one hand, a common starting point, but on the other hand, the deviations from the Commission's proposal – which they wanted to invest in these priorities – amounted to EUR 2.7 billion more in Parliament and EUR 1.5 billion less for the Council, i.e. EUR 4.2 billion difference. This was a starting point in which the difference was greater than in the previous budget discussions. In the last financial year of the budgetary framework, Parliament wanted to invest as much as possible all the available funds up to the ceiling, and the Council wanted – which I felt to some extent to be correct – to build up margins, margins for unforeseen events in 2020 or for the foreseeable – refugees who are currently living in Turkey and to whom we are financing human dignity – for the foreseeable, but this has not yet been taken into account in the Commission's budget proposal. The sense of responsibility and the sense of responsibility of all those involved were good. I would like to thank the chairman of the committee for his sovereign moderation, I thank the two rapporteurs for their knowledgeable commitment and their coordination with important Members from the Committee on Budgets, so that in the end a majority of Members from many political groups was achievable. And I would like to thank the representative of the Presidency, Mr Tiilikainen, who, although I believe has taken a hard line on the Council's line, has always been interested in a result, in a compromise solution, and has worked very constructively towards it at every second. The press wrote of dramatic deliberations in the last hour– it was not so dramatic. I believe that it has already been shown that the leaders did not want to let it fail, but were interested in an agreement. The figures speak for themselves: on the one hand, we have not affected the ceilings in any form, but have complied with them, and on the other hand, we have margins, margins of EUR 1.5 billion in commitments – a total of EUR 4.2 billion with other instruments of flexibility – and are thus prepared for what can be added to the European Union in terms of further tasks and expenditure next year. On climate change, we have significantly exceeded the 20% target in the 2020 budget with a percentage of 21.1%, thus rebalancing a significant proportion of the underspends that have been under-investment in 2014 and 2015. We have Horizon 2020 at a peak in terms of investment from the European research and innovation budget – EUR 13.5 billion, an increase of 8.8% compared to 2019. I would advise all those involved to take this high level of funding for research under Horizon 2020 as the starting point for Horizon Europe and not to fall short of it, because this is where economic strength, competitiveness, investment in technologies for sustainability and climate protection become visible. That is why this step, which is primarily due to Parliament, was a decisive step in this budget, with a further EUR 300 million, in the transition to the discussions on the post-2020 budget framework. Connecting Europe Facility: Energy significantly increased, plus 35%, transport moderately increased. In other words, we are already investing in the future, thereby creating added value that can best be realised at European level. We have a 4% increase in Erasmus+ – a small step towards doubling to triple, if you take Parliament and Mrs von der Leyen as a benchmark, in the financial years of the next decade. We have also provided for some moderate cuts, which I believe are justifiable in implementation – pre-accession aid to Turkey, we have some moderate but important reinforcements at Europol, Eurojust and EPPO, the Public Prosecutor's Office, so that these instruments and bodies for internal security and for the rule of law in Europe and for the fight against corruption are more capable of acting. All in all – I can tell you this from my colleagues from the Commission, the colleagues who are responsible for the portfolios and then implement the budget – the Commission is satisfied with this budget. It is a good basis for the implementation of the von der Leyen Commission's budget. I would therefore like to thank all those involved: the Council, Mr Tiilikainen, rapporteurs and the committee chair. And I would simply ask you to bring the vigour now into the discussions on the multiannual budgetary framework. If the ministers in the General Affairs Council had met once as long as we met, with a working intensity over two weeks until late at 11 p.m., with this intensity of work and not just two hours a month and the same line to take, there would also be movement in the budgetary framework. As a citizen, I hope to read very early next year that the Council and Parliament will achieve a breakthrough for a modern framework of the next decade's budget, and that this will not happen in A.C. until Advent in a year's time. Then we would have learned the lesson from the good experience of your deliberations on the 2020 draft budget with a view to a timely budgetary framework for the next decade and thus to added value that can only be achieved at European level. Thank you to all those involved. (Applause)

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, I would like to greet all my colleagues and send a special greeting, and to thank at the same time the rapporteur Monika Hohlmeier, Eider Gardiazabal, Commissioner Oettinger and also Tiilikainen of the Council Presidency. This team also had an over-the-seeded Parliament, a Parliament where moderate and pro-European political groups gave their consent to this budget. It is therefore also a thank you to the shadow rapporteurs and to all the staff of Parliament, a thank you to the Commissioner for all the work he has done and also the strengthening, once again, of the Finnish Presidency. Here is a good foreshadowing: we leave and also leave a good example of the path that must be trodden. The institutions, when they work together, are able to reach agreements that are very positive and this is a good harbinger for the next Multiannual Financial Framework, and parliament will also be overmet, and we hope that the Council, too, can come together and bring Parliament closer together. This is a budget that gives priority to climate, research and innovation and I will point out EUR 302 million in reinforcement and reinforcement, in particular, for the heading of combating cancer, which does not forget youth, the youth employment initiative, the strengthening of Erasmus + and which also favours competitiveness.  A budget that is also a challenge for Member States, and here is a request for all Member States: speed up the implementation of the funds. The implementation of cohesion policy funds is, I don't want to say the word shame, but it is very low. The proof is that the payments of the budget for 2020 are at 0.9 %, below 1 % of gross national income. Finally, I want to say that this budget is, as always, an investment budget, a budget where only 7 % is for administration expenditure, and 93 % is for investment expenditure, and benefits all Member States.

name: Pierre Larrouturou
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, my friends Johan, Monika, Eider and José Manuel have said it: it is a good agreement, it is a good budget in the very constrained framework that is ours. We have done a good job, it is the best possible budget. I thank Rasmus and Clotilde, Commissioner Oettinger and Minister Tiilikainen for negotiating hard to reach this agreement. Beyond this annual budget, however, I think that we are all asking ourselves the same questions. What is our ambition for Europe? What is our real ambition for our future and that of our children? If we had a big ambition, we would have a big budget. When Kennedy said, "We choose to go to the Moon," he really decided and put the budget on it. NASA's budget has increased 15-fold in five years, 400,000 jobs have been created and the United States has reached the Moon faster than expected. Today, the goal is not to go to the Moon but to save the Earth, at least to save humanity on Earth, and we all know that this budget is totally inadequate. We're all talking about the Green New Deal, alluding to Roosevelt's New Deal, it's a very nice picture. But when Roosevelt came to power, he gave himself the means of a real New Deal that would create millions of jobs and give hope to the American people. Roosevelt tripled the federal budget in a few years and it worked. In a few years, to win the war, Roosevelt would further multiply the entire federal budget by four. In total, while Roosevelt was old and paralyzed, the federal budget would be multiplied twelvefold. It finances it first through taxation - taxation on the richest and on profits - and then through another use of monetary creation. Were Kennedy and Roosevelt crazy? Did they ruin the United States? Of course not. They were great leaders who had a real plan for their country and had given themselves the means to break taboos and find funding. They have done no harm to their country; on the contrary, they have revived the hopes of millions of people.  What are we waiting for in Europe today? Once again, this budget is good under the constraints, and the Social Democratic Group is happy to vote for it. But we have to go further. To win the climate battle we have all talked about, the European Commission itself says that we are missing 300 billion each year if we stick to the target of reducing CO2 emissions by only 40%. But since our goal - thanks to Ursula von der Leyen - is more ambitious, since we all agree to halve CO2 emissions in the next ten years, the need for funding is obviously necessary. At least $400 billion is needed each year to win the climate battle. We applaud the European Investment Bank for saying that it will stop fossil investment and double its climate loans, that is fine. But that's only 15 billion more each year, when 400 billion are needed. Dear friends, I therefore think that it is absolutely necessary to find new ways. I hope that this is the last year that we are voting in such a constrained framework. Nothing would be worse than a Green Deal without real funding, it would be Green washing. Nothing would be worse than a Green Deal with unfair funding. We would then have thousands, if not millions, of yellow vests all over Europe. It is absolutely and very quickly that much more ambitious and fair funding must be found. Why not take the idea of Jacques Delors? He said that intra-European tax competition had to be tackled. When I was a child, the income tax averaged 45%. Today, it has fallen to 19%. Income tax has been halved while profits are exploding. If we want to have a bigger budget without asking for more money from the basic citizens and the Member States, it is time to move very quickly on own resources.

name: Clotilde Armand
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur of the Renew group, we have found that we have much greater ambitions in the European Parliament towards the representatives of our governments. Many of us are First-term Members and we have intact the enthusiasm with which our citizens have sworn in to bring about change in Europe. We have put at the heart of the negotiations for the 2020 budget programmes that include measures against climate change because the majority of European citizens continue to express this concern as paramount. We have reiterated the importance of a balanced geographical allocation of funds to address the concern of eastern countries that have difficulty connecting to the European area and difficulties in accelerating economic convergence. Europe cannot be a strong pole if a third of the member countries are in an economic gap.  We would also like to give a clear signal that the European Union is making the fight against corruption a priority. We insisted that sufficient posts be provided for the new European Public Prosecutor's Office to become a functioning institution from next year. I have therefore achieved punctual victories in relation to the objectives that I personally set myself. But we achieved a real victory, a symbolic victory, important from the position of newly elected Parliament. It is the largest amount of funds negotiated in Parliament in relation to the proposal put forward by a Council in recent years. We have made clear our priorities: protecting the climate, innovation and businesses from the future, supporting new generations and the continental economic balance east-west. In conclusion, I believe that our message in the 2020 negotiations reinforces our vision for the future multiannual financial framework. This financial framework will depend on the European Union's political guidelines for the next seven years, including cohesion policy so vital to the Eastern European area. I thank all my colleagues for their work, for the dialogue, for their support during the negotiations.

name: Rasmus Andresen
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the EUR 500 million more for climate investment, at least EUR 80 million more for youth programmes and more money for democracy and human rights work. We Greens believe that the tough budget negotiations have paid off. Instead of cuts to the draft budget, there is now a plus. This is a great success for the European Parliament, for all of us. I would like to begin by thanking Mrs and shadow rapporteur Clotilde Armand for many joint initiatives for climate and youth, but, of course, above all the negotiators, our committee chairman and the two rapporteurs, Eider Gardiazabal Rubial and Monika Hohlmeier. Without their conduct, this success would not have been possible. The budget shows us that we can achieve something if we are courageous. And we Greens believe that we must remain courageous now, because we are at the beginning of an economic crisis. We need to do much more to achieve the climate targets. We don't have time for a "continue like this". We need to invest massively to make our economy climate neutral over the next few decades and to take all people with us. Our answer to this is a real Green New Deal. Now the intriguing question is: What comes into the Green New Deal, and will it be funded? We Greens believe that investment in better, faster and cheaper rail links, for example, should be included. We need to invest more in renewable energy, we need to invest more in good food, in clean air and in water for all the people on our continent. Negotiations on the 2020 budget have been tough. Every small budget title has had to be hard won by us in Parliament, and some Member States, without making any concrete proposals, have simply tried to block everything. I expressly exclude the Finnish Presidency, but there are others who have not been particularly constructive there. Copenhagen, The Hague, Vienna and, in some parts, Berlin, risk missing our targets, failing to meet the Paris climate targets, and not being able to increase research spending. We believe that this would be a bigger problem than if we were all prepared to spend more money on the EU budget and on our common future. We Greens believe that we should continue as Parliament has shown. We look forward to doing so together with many other groups.

name: Nicolaus Fest
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the You have just said that it is not often that the Council and the Commission are praised by Parliament. That is right and that is how it should be, and the fact that there is a great deal of agreement here shows how much has gone wrong. The EU's 2020 annual budget should be a clearly structured budget, a clear overview of spending and financial frameworks. In fact, this budget is the exact opposite. It is an instrument of obfuscation, hidden financing and misleading the European taxpayer. Not only is the EU budget being inflated more and more, by EUR 400 million in 2020 alone; above all, it is becoming increasingly confusing due to countless – sometimes hidden – funds, the use of which and their usefulness are questionable at best and which no one questions. What we are seeing here is not budgeting, it is deliberate lack of transparency. Take the emergency reserve of EUR 1.2 billion. It is currently being converted into another budget title on climate protection, that is, for clientele policy of the Greens and Socialists. This is how we hide the allocation of ever-increasing sums of money for the nonsensical and insecure energy supply that we already have in Germany. But while the liberals criticize this in Germany, they are taking part here. Finally, eu budgeting becomes completely confusing due to the subsequent allocation of funds by another EU institution, the European Investment Bank. Where the EU's budget is not enough to finance any ideology, it acts as a co-financer, with the very large sums and, of course, ultimately, as always, covered by the European taxpayer. So what appears to be a comparatively small budget title in the EU budget can actually be a huge project. However, this cannot be seen from the budget on which we are to talk and decide. But what is the value of a budget that does not show the true distribution of funds, but conceals it? In two words: nothing at all. That is why anyone here who has retained any sense of budget truth and transparency should clearly reject this annual budget.

name: Jessica Stegrud
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In the private sector, shareholders would not have agreed to constantly inject more money into something that does not yield any return. In a competitive market, customers would not have agreed to pay more and more for inferior products and services. But now this is not a business or a competitive company, but a fundamentally good idea that has evolved into an expensive administrative colossus, a costly building financed by working taxpayers, whose employees' constant reflex is to user more power and money.  I have only been here for five months, but I have already noted that the wish list for expenditure increases is only getting longer and longer, and now taxpayers are expected to inject another 10 billion next year. It just doesn't end.  With the tenacity of a fool, I will demand that the EU conserve Swedish taxpayers' money and, instead of introducing fee increases, make sure to correct the mouth after the packed lunch.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, it is a fact that under pressure from the European Parliament, significant improvements have been made to the Council's original proposal. I am sorry, but I do not share the atmosphere of celebration and mutual congratulations, because quite simply the budget, Mr Tigilikainen, is inadequate in relation to the objectives set by both the European Parliament and the Commission, even the Council itself.  I am addressing colleagues from the other political groups in the European Parliament. If we celebrate with a budget of 0.99% of European GDP, below and below 1%, how do you think we will negotiate effectively to achieve the target that you set in the European Parliament, namely the target of 1.3% for the new multiannual financial framework? The truth is that, out of the EUR 480 million more requested by the European Parliament for social and regional cohesion policies, we have achieved an increase of EUR 34 million, eleven times less. This isn't about celebration. That is why I believe that reality shows that the final compromise was stamped by the Council, which unfortunately adopts policies that are inadequate for the future of Europe and, above all, the weakest. That is why the Eurogroup on the left will not vote in favour of the final compromise.

name: Mario Furore (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again Parliament and the Council have reached an agreement which, as far as I am concerned, should invest more in two key points of this European Union, namely the fight against climate change and support for youth employment. We need a stronger and more constant commitment in these two areas, which I consider to be key, and above all I hope that the Commission will be courageous in respecting the will expressed in the declarations during the negotiations. These are the key points of the future and I hope that these negotiations, including with regard to the multiannual financial framework, will take this into account. What has happened in Italy in recent days, with the collapse of a viaduct – the umpteenth unfortunately – shows us that the fight against climate change belongs to us more than we think, and above all that we must invest in prevention, for a strong and shared policy that Europe must promote. I welcome, on the other hand, the agreed cuts in Turkey. I say this because we must support civil society which wants to fight for democracy. We cannot afford to finance warmongering regimes, as far as I am concerned. I will therefore support the agreement reached, despite the fact that the negotiations show once again how difficult it is to find a balance on the one hand for a Union that wants to respect its own budget and, on the other, the Member States that are in the difficulties of having to comply with these constraints. I believe that we must reverse this course.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The 2020 budget is of great importance to the European Parliament as it is the last budget for the 2014-2020 perspective, but it is also the parliament's first budget. And this parliament is made up of 60% of the new Members. Therefore, the way of working and the way of negotiating will have an impact on the years to come and, in particular, on the preparation of a new perspective, namely the MFF. This is so important that the question arises as to whether all three institutions think in terms of follow-up. In other words, not from – to, just building a permanent process. Do all three institutions really want to build a sustainable development framework for the European Union, or do they just think in terms of a one-year budget. We also remember that this 2020 budget will provide a possible basis for replacing the perspective if it is not ready by 2020. For the time being, we do not see much tension in the Council and we do not say that all countries are really interested in a swift completion of the work on the MFF. It is therefore not inconceivable that this budget will be the basis for further action. It is therefore extremely important that it has been agreed, but it has shown the different sides and approaches of the European institutions. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you and the Commissioner have also said that this budget will influence the new financial framework, and I agree with this statement. My question is: do you think that in the new financial framework we will be able to correct, and here we have not succeeded, namely: there is, of course, not a sufficient amount at Erasmus, even if it is an increase of 4%, if we will have money for agricultural policy and cohesion policy and especially if we manage to increase this budget because we have heard here that only 0.9 and not 1.3 as the target was. How do you see that it will influence and how can we put the Council to have a bigger budget and to cover cohesion policy, as I was saying? Thanks.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – In answering your question, you need to be honest. I mean, when asked if we can improve, I say, I don't know. On the other hand, the European Parliament's stance on this budget indicates that we will do everything we can to improve this, and this was a clear signal to the Council.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by joining those who congratulated the rapporteurs on this 2020 budget. In fact, from what I was told – I was a passive and non-active agent – they did an excellent job in the final stages of the negotiations. And why do I say that? I say this because what has been achieved in this budget, compared to the Commission's proposal, has indeed been significant progress and significant progress has been made in what is parliament's priorities.  I start with the very issue of climate, with the issue of research and innovation, but also with young people. In seeking to provide answers to young people, the youth employment programme, youth guarantee and the Erasmus programme were valued.  That said, am I satisfied with the result? You can't be satisfied with the result. I believe that this result is insufficient to finance the challenges of the European Union in 2020, but it was the result that could be reached, and therefore it is with this budget that we will live in 2020. My concern also arises, as it should be, that I am rapporteur for the Multiannual Financial Framework, and I would like to say this: firstly, the value of 0.99 % is indeed a very low value compared to the programme and the ambition of this Parliament.  What we need in the Multiannual Financial Framework is an amount that is actually sufficient to finance the political priorities of the European Union and above all the political priorities that we will be voting on tomorrow when we elect the Commission, because we are actually voting on a political programme. Finally, I would like to ask Commissioner Oettinger, thanking him for his commitment, to transfer this way of getting the institutions to cooperate for his successor in the future Commission.

name: Olivier Chastel (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen have said this before me, we are starting from a gap of EUR 4.2 billion between Parliament's position and that of the Member States, which, I would remind you again, wanted to reduce the Commission's budget proposal by EUR 1.5 billion. Then we finally reached an agreement that reconciles our climate priorities with those for youth employment and innovation. Compared to 2019, we increased the commitment appropriations by 1.5%, bringing the budget to EUR 168.7 billion. We are strengthening the Horizon 2020 research and innovation agenda by making the climate emergency an economic perspective. We are greening budgets for growth, competitiveness, but also transport and energy infrastructure. We defend our SMEs, the real backbone of our economy. Finally, we support digital and Erasmus. To remain competitive with the United States and China, Europe must have an ambitious and responsible budget. Based on the mandate of the European Parliament, we defended our positions with the desire to establish a budget that reflected the expectations of our citizens and we obtained an additional 850 million to achieve our priorities, including more than 500 million for climate. Thus, in 2020, 21%, not 20%, of the EU budget will be devoted to the climate emergency. I just hope that bodes well for the next fiscal years.

name: Damian Boeselager (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, first I have to respond a bit to what Mr Fest said because I think, if you’re not there, it’s hard to be transparent about something if you don’t know it and if you don’t send someone to actually represent your Group. So I think that would help in terms of transparency.  I was also, let’s say, more in an observer role for this first negotiation. For me it was very interesting because I learned three things. The first is that the new set—up of Parliament with Renew and the Greens also pushing priorities can lead to a budget which is actually better. I’m very happy with the outcome in that direction.  The second is that a big deal is possible, and I also want to thank the rapporteurs for their great work in having a good negotiation strategy and working in a proactive and deal—finding way, and also for ensuring that we move from the Commission proposal towards Parliament’s position. So it is positive that we got EUR 400 million on top of that. The third thing is – and this makes me a bit less optimistic – that the national governments often seem only to care about the bottom line of how much they have to pay and how much they get back into their own pockets. If we now think about this as the prelude to the MFF for the seventh annual framework, I think we have to step up our game because the problems that we are facing – and I was in Lesbos a week ago – are so much bigger than what we are currently committing to. We shouldn’t only be thinking about our national budgets, but really about how to fund common solutions to the biggest problems of our time so that we honour the demands of our citizens and that we are actually able to act from a European level.

name: Filip De Man (ID).
text: Mr President, we are not pleased with the 2020 budget. Of course there are good points, but we continue to disagree with the overall vision of the EU and the way in which the funds are/spent. Why give billions to Turkey? Why spend year after year wasting money to accommodate the endless influx of immigrants? Why spend taxpayers' money on the accession of countries that can only bear a heavy additional budgetary burden? When do we stop climate hysteria?  Our group is therefore opposed, especially since the Flemings are the largest net contributors in the union as a whole. But it seems that belgian poachers are being made into foresters here in the European Union. Charles Michel, the prime minister of Belgium, became President of the European Council, and the Belgian Finance Minister, Johan Van Overtveldt, became chairman of the Committee on Budgets. Both, however, left a completely derailed budget before leaving the sinking ship. Belgium dangles at the very bottom when it comes to budgetary discipline. I'm not going to mention any particular type of rodent here, but they weren't squirrels leaving the ship. It is therefore at least surprising that serious countries in the EU reward such failures at the national level – in Belgium, i.e. – with the highest positions in the European Union.  I said.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments.  Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. I am very pleased that this debate is being listened to so much by the audience gathered in the galleries, representatives, I think, from all over Europe. I am very happy that so many young people. Because here were important words about the need for savings. It was also important that we are the first parliament to negotiate this difficult compromise. And precisely because this difficult compromise was made for the first time – perhaps not the first – but unlike previous years negotiated on time, we can say that we will save a significant amount of money. And that is the reason why it must be said that this budget is a satisfactory budget for us. In a special way, I would like to emphasise here – also because of the large number of young people gathered – that this budget offers new instruments and new opportunities precisely to support, for example, the fight against youth unemployment. There, in this budget are saved additional money.  And something that I, as a representative of Polish, particularly enjoys, and I emphasize my national origin here, because in Poland Erasmus+, which is an exchange project that serves young people while studying, is a very popular program. That is why I can say that, as an ECC, we will support this budget tomorrow.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this budget proposal for 2020, compared to the previous proposal we voted on here and which was already limited, represents a €5.6 billion cut in payment appropriations and a €2.3 billion cut in authorisation appropriations. A budget of less than 1 % of the gross national income of all the countries of the European Union, which lays down any idea of cohesion or solidarity.  Although determined by a financial framework 2014-2020 already short, this budget ends up below the ceiling of this framework, being evident the lack of political will to make use of all available instruments to mobilize additional resources.  This is an insufficient budget in the areas of economic, social and territorial cohesion, insufficient to promote convergence by supporting production systems, particularly in countries facing greater difficulties, with greater weaknesses, particularly in terms of production deficits. An insufficient budget in the resources it devotes to the social areas and nature protection and a budget that, in the opposite direction, cutting where it should not, will direct more resources to where it should not, namely the areas of militarism, the areas of external interventionism, the so-called areas of security and defence.  As for the rest, no news. Parliament has a lion's entrance and a sender exit, eventually putting the viola in the bag to meet the Council's positions, a bad first for the multiannual financial framework debate, even if it does not surprise.

name: Robert Rowland (NI).
text: – Mr President, now that the UK is definitely leaving the EU on 31 January and ending our EUR 17 billion contribution to the EU budget, I suppose it was entirely predictable that sparks would fly and acrimony begin between the two remaining heavyweights of the EU. It appears that Franco-German relations have hit a new low point. We have recently witnessed the unedifying display of little Napoleon himself, Emmanuel Macron, as he parades his global ambitions by humiliating NATO, and now it seems, Angela Merkel. Ironically, the Germans are really going to miss us. Great Britain has historically acted as a buffer between those two old adversaries and a deterrent to France’s imperial tendencies. So when the German chancellor uses an English metaphor of gluing the tea cups back together again after Macron has broken them, you know it’s getting bad. The EU budget is essentially an exercise in Franco-German game theory; even though contributions as small as a percentage of GDP the aggregate of EUR 170 billion is big enough to achieve overtly political goals. That is why we never see any reform of the Common Agricultural Policy, which absorbs one third of the EU budget and acts as the world’s biggest subsidy scheme for French farmers. But Macron wants more. He’s an avaricious little chappy. Germany will now see its contribution double over the next MFF, whereas France barely pays a euro more, net. So watching this dispute get resolved will be a welcome respite from my Brexit fatigue.

name: Angelika Winzig (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Protecting the European way of life also requires a future-oriented budget. With investments in research, youth and climate protection, we are certainly on the right track. Above all, it is important to me that the success of EU programmes – in addition to the level of mobilisation by the Member State – should also be measured by how these budgets reach citizens, businesses and the regions. It is also important to me that we also have the courage to change and adapt EU programmes. For example, I see the YEI programme as not so much a structure as a repair programme for the failures of some Member States in youth training. I hope that it will start much earlier that our young people will receive much more support during their training. Budget is policy in figures, and the wishes of the political groups were very comprehensive in the negotiations. With EUR 169 billion in commitments and EUR 154 billion in payments, we have achieved an ambitious budget that is also below 1% of the GNI of the 28 Member States. Efficient use of funds is very important for our citizens, both at national and EU level. It is now important that the Commission, but also the Member States, ensure the accuracy of these programmes.

name: Erik Bergkvist (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Members of the European Parliament, i.e. the European Parliament, i.e Mr President, I would first like to thank Mr Oettinger and Mr Tiiilikainen, who, with patience and constructiveness, led us to conclude the negotiations and, of course, our own negotiating delegation, Eider Gardiazábal Rubial, Monika Hohlmeier and Johan Van Overtveldt. Thank you very much for your efforts, which have made this possible! Budget is much more than just numbers. Behind the figures are of course activities, people, desires, longings, hopes. However, this requires resources. If we are to succeed in our challenges – two of them we must not fail, namely climate and peace – then we must create the resources to be able to change the climate of our industry, our agriculture, energy systems and other things. We must also be able to keep Europe together – a cohesive Europe with narrowing gaps, high employment and good development, in order for peaceful development. We have to do both of these things. One of the founding fathers of the European Union, Robert Schuman, said: 'World peace cannot be preserved without creative efforts. Had he lived today, I am convinced that he would have added: The climate cannot be saved without creative efforts. That is why this budget is important. There are major investments in the climate, research and development, the fight against youth unemployment – not least important now that we seem to be entering a recession – investment in education and important infrastructure. That is the kind of thing that holds Europe together. These are also things that create the conditions for a successful climate change change. A word about the long-term budget: it must not be delayed any more. This causes concern and causes important things to be postponed. We must also look at the needs. The budget must make a successful long-term budget impossible. We need to look seriously at europe's own revenue capabilities in order to be able to cope effectively and quickly with these tasks. We must manage the climate and peace. We must provide sufficient resources if, in ten years' time, when the long-term budget has passed, we are to be able to look our children and grandchildren in the eye and say: we took the necessary decisions. Europe needs more cooperation.

name: Valerie Hayer (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to start by thanking all the players in the intense negotiations that have been carried out in recent weeks, Commissioner Oettinger, Secretary of State Tiilikainen, our rapporteurs Monica Hohlmeier and Eider Gardiazabal and, for the Renew Group, Clotilde Armand and Olivier Chastel. Thank you for your commitment and determination; thank you also to the other colleagues who contributed to this agreement. This year, the climate issue has been at the heart of our concerns. This is how we obtained an increase of 500 million euros compared to the first draft budget for programmes contributing to climate protection, but also 300 million for research, 130 million for the interconnection of our energy and transport networks, not to mention 50 million for Erasmus. This is, without a doubt, a good agreement for Parliament, for Europe. The citizens have given us a clear mandate to ensure that the Union protects them and ensures their future. According to a recent opinion poll, climate change has become the second most common concern of citizens across the European Union. Through this agreement, we show them that this concern is shared, but above all we prove to them that we are an essential relay for greater action in this area. This week, the European Parliament shows that it is a key player for our planet. However, I would like to express a regret. Despite these significant efforts, we will not reach the 20% climate spending target for 2014-2020. It's a failure. The Union has failed in its commitments. However, at our insistence, the Commission has stated that it will redirect money not used in certain programmes to climate-contributing lines. Together with our entire Renew Europe group, I will therefore support the Commission to do everything possible to get as close as possible to this 20%. We will make sure that to the end.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will actually vote on the outcome of the negotiations with the Council for next year's budget. And if the vote is positive, this will mean a further increase in the level of commitments of EUR 169 billion — 1.5% higher than this year.  It is true that there are positive items such as the COSME programme, which facilitates access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are at the heart of the Economy of the Member States. However, it must also be noted that the Union budget cannot grow exponentially and that we cannot continue to increase expenditure if we do not do so effectively, efficiently and consistently. Above all, European expenditure must be stated in those items which give European added value, without overlapping with the competences and expenditure of the Member States themselves. This would reduce the contributions of the Member States, which in the end are the contributions of our citizens.  Other games attract a lot of attention; for example, in the European Neighbourhood Instrument, headings to countries such as Algeria are increased by EUR 25 million, which do not cooperate with Member States, such as Spain, in the implementation of the Return Directive or in the control of irregular immigration; while aid to Turkey , for the reasons we all know , is reduced, which nevertheless cooperates with the Union in controlling the migration flows of this illegal, invasive and uncontrolled immigration.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Oettinger, Monica Holmeier, Eider Gardisabal and Jose Manuel Fernandez on the efforts they made last month to have a budget. The mere fact that we approved it just an hour before the deadline shows how difficult it was. For me, this was the fifth time in a row that I was involved in the negotiations, and I have to say it was one of the hardest. I am happy that ERASMUS has more resources. Much has been said about ecology, however. Many colleagues on the left talked about the ecology, including from the Liberals. I want to remind that ecology deals with the balance between people and nature, not just nature. That is why it was important that we covered enough priorities related to very traditional policies – agriculture, infrastructure, students, young people, of course, and innovation and the environment. But it was very important that such a balance was achieved. Of course, there are also compromises that have been made. I myself would like to see even more in some sectors, especially related to science, especially related to young people and ERASMUS, but budgets come and go. What remains is people, cities and regions. It was therefore important to me that regional development will be a priority for another year, and that is why I want to congratulate everyone who participated in these negotiations for reaching a not-so-good budget.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this Parliament has always worked to ensure that the 2020 budget is an ambitious starting point for the negotiations that await us on the future multiannual financial framework. Today, thanks to the commitment of our entire negotiating team, whom I thank, we can say that we have achieved this objective, responding effectively to the demands of a Europe that is closer to the needs of our citizens. This response is based on concrete results, such as increasing funds to combat climate change and culture, strengthening the Erasmus programme for thousands of students and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as strengthening neighbourhood policies in the Mediterranean basin, which is all too often becoming the scene of tragedies due to the migration crisis. But we do not want to stop there, Mr Oettinger. We will therefore continue our efforts to find solutions that also meet the difficulties of a sector, the agri-food sector, which is the victim of the Trump administration's decisions to impose punitive tariffs on our products. We have made important progress, as requested by our statements at the end of the conciliation procedure. We now expect concrete support in the coming months for European agri-food production affected by this trade retaliation.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. As a Parliament, we have achieved a common success in these budget negotiations: more money and more investment for research, climate and Erasmus. This was a team effort by this Parliament, and that is why I am proud of our colleagues and Would like to thank our rapporteurs. But in the future there is much more at stake. We need a Europe that is really fit for the future. Still, some here – like the Brexit party, and in particular some Member States – are still thinking and calculating: what have we paid in, what do we get out of? In future, however, it will no longer be just a question of what Europe can do for its country, but also of what each country can do for a strong Europe. That is what we must fight for in the next few years. Only in this way will Europe be able to act, only in this way will Europe still be relevant, and only in this way will Europe still have a role to play in the world. We need more top researchers in Europe, we need more Erasmus exchanges and new technologies to combat climate change. But we must also be prepared to set new priorities for this. We need to invest more in our competitiveness, rather than subsidising our competitiveness.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Körner, you have a blue card question from Mr Patten. The speaker declines a "blue card" question from Mathew Patten.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: I would not like to make any further efforts to discuss this with our colleagues in the Brexit party, who no longer want to be part of this budget. We do not want to expect that from them. (The speaker declined to answer a question about Matthew Patten's 'blue card' procedure))

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we all know of the importance of a good budgetary procedure and, of course, of what budgetary control is. This morning we voted on the renewal of the European Court of Auditors and the renewal of its president, the popular German Klaus Lehne. We are the European body responsible for verifying that European Union funds are properly received and used. In Spain we have known these days the judgment in the ERE case, the acronym for employment regulation files. A sentence that confirms an immense theft in Spain, with prison sentences and disqualification for members of the Socialist Party, a party that was ruling the Andalusia region for more than forty years, specifically from 1978 to 2019. And a judgment which shows that the Socialist Government deviand from six hundred and eighty million euros whose origin was the Spanish and European pockets and whose purpose was to promote the employment and social inclusion of people in unemployment. For all of the above, and since there are sentences to be handed down, including with the training funds, I request the ECA ⸻and I hope that all Members of this Parliament will join this request⸻ to carry out an audit of all european funds that have been allocated to the Spanish region of Andalusia, whose socialist management over the last forty years ⸻ has been proven⸻ it has been an immense larceny , the use and abuse of money from citizens, European citizens.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, this Budget of the European Union is a successful budget and this success is credited to the European Parliament. And the success was made because there were two excellent rapporteurs, my dear colleague Monika Hohlmeier and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, but at the same time our coordinator José Manuel Fernandes, the chairman of the Committee on Budgets and the whole group that really fought at the time of the conciliation.  At the time of the battle for these funds, some were absent, such as the Left, which did not come to the field to fight to increase funds for young people, for climate change, for farmers, for the countryside, for technology, for the digital economy, but it also has the right to criticise, it has the right to vote against these funds earned through the struggle of dear colleagues at the time. Conciliation.  We believe that this success of the budget not only resonates with all of us, but reflects on our own Member States. And we want more funds for the budget. And we want more billions. But together we must fight to increase the contribution of the countries. The left cannot ask for more funds when it is not participating and while it does not require an increase in these contributions through the Member States.  At the same time, I have to say that for us it is particularly important that the funds for Turkey have been reduced. For those countries that violate human rights, that violate the rule of law, that invade countries of the European Union but also that do not respect the principles and values of the European Union, not only must the funds be reduced, but they must also be completely abolished. And that is our demand and that is our fight until the last euro given to Turkey is abolished.

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I do not think it is the case that tomorrow we will vote on the 2020 budget, together with the new Commission, because maybe tomorrow – and I hope so – a new political phase is going to start. The 2020 budget, which is actually the largest one of the last MFF, and for which I thank the whole conciliation team, is actually a transition budget. It projects us into the future, because the real challenge is going to be the new MFF. We have to decide whether we want to be ambitious or shy, and whether we would like to work in an expansive – though responsible – way, maybe facing a new economic crisis, or if we want to go on with business as usual.  Two things are very clear. We need new own resources to finance the goals we want to achieve, and both are connected to climate change and to the internal market. We also need a new MFF centred on well—rooted European policies, like cohesion policy and agricultural policy, but also linked to the new policies like, for instance, the implementation of the social pillar. Budgetary policies are, as you know, at the core of political institutions. They represent the way we respond to citizens, but they also represent the way in which we can show what we do or do not do. Numbers do not lie. So I hope we will be very courageous.

name: Nils Torvalds (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for For some reason, the processes in Parliament and the negotiations with the Council are always very complex as soon as it is about money. I have sat a couple of times in my years in this House until well into the night to bring about some sort of solution to it all. It looked quite threatening this time too, perhaps partly because of what we also sometimes have reason to call 'Finnish stubbornness'. We also know that this round of negotiations was particularly important, as the previous speaker also pointed out, because this is a bridge between two different financial frameworks. It might have been rather unfortunate if that bridge had been built with very weak and bad means. Now, however, the negotiators, whom I thank, managed to achieve a clear improvement, which will perhaps serve as a bridge for a future budgetary policy, which meets all the demands that we have every reason to make in the future.

name: Adam Jarubas (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I congratulate the rapporteurs: Monica Hohlmeier and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, the Finnish Presidency, the Commissioner and everyone involved in this difficult compromise. When I left the Council building at midnight on Friday after almost thirteen hours of negotiations, we did not reach a consensus. I think that, like many members of the delegation, we thought it was quite real that we would have to operate in 2020 as part of the 1/12 monthly makeshift. The compromise reached and the consensus reached for the first time, which has been supported so broadly by the political groups in Parliament, are all the more welcome. Consensus, where we managed to agree on a record almost half a billion euros of additional appropriations and even greater budget relocations, to ensure that the eur 169 billion agreed to finance environmental protection more actively, including climate protection, for which we have allocated 21% of all resources, more actively support the fair transition of coal-dependent regions, the fight against youth unemployment, the Erasmus+ student and young practitioner exchange programme, the development of the European digital market, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, research, including particularly relevant research supporting the treatment of cancer patients.  The consensus on the 2020 budget is also important because next year will be the reference year for the 2027 Multiannual Financial Framework. The budget is also two million euros for the innovative darknet monitoring project proposed by me and the experts, and I thank everyone for supporting this initiative.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Could this budget have been better? He could have been. More brave? He could have been. Could he have been more visionary? He could have been. Could we have had more money? Could. But as has been said, we have managed to find consensus between the groups at the last moment. And that is the unique strength of the European Parliament that we have. This was achieved through a great negotiating team led, importantly, by two strong courageous women who led us to this good budget. For me, as a Social Democrat, it is important that there is more money in this budget to fight climate change, that there will be money to ensure that, for example, in a country like Poland, 45 000 people do not die every year just because they breathe poisoned air, that there will be more money to fight unemployment for young people. There are regions in Europe where 50% of young people are unemployed. We deserve a better budget with a real vision.  And I leave this task to the future parliament and to future good negotiators like the current ones.

name: Luis Garicano (Renew).
text: – Madam President, three points I would like to say. First of all, I believe that this budget , which has been placed with a difficult commitment by my colleague and all the other negotiators - is a good budget, I am very satisfied, and I think we have to thank the negotiating teams; reflects the priorities of our citizens, what they have asked us to do, which is to reorient the budget to combat climate change through innovation and support young people in a number of important ways. Secondly, I would like to say that the budget, however, is not sufficient for our ambitions; we need to be aware that the European Union needs more resources to solve citizens' problems. And thirdly, I would like to say that we are already starting the process of negotiating the multiannual financial framework. In this financial framework we must all be aware that the objective is not so much that each country's priorities are achieved separately, but to solve the problems of citizens. And, in order to solve these problems, the European Union needs to have the necessary vision and resources. When we act together, we solve those problems much better.

name: Karlo Ressler (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, the good news is that an agreement has been reached on how we will turn our declared political priorities into reality through the next year, the last year of the current multiannual financial framework. That is why this document is in some way an indicator of the direction of the next seven-year budget.  The modern challenges, demographic, technological, climate change we are witnessing must be adequately recognised in the European budget. Through investments in new technologies, competitiveness and development, we are catching up with the times and creating programs for the future and for new generations.  By strengthening key programmes such as research, innovation, investment in infrastructure, but also caring for the environment or fighting cancer, we are also working on a bridge to new priorities. At the same time, we must continue to invest in the successful, traditional and fundamental policies of the European Union, such as cohesion policy, in order to continue to reduce the economic and social disparities that exist within the European Union.  I have a responsibility to all Europeans to continue to reduce such differences, in order to realise the full potential of the entire European Union, all its regions and all its citizens.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: – Dear Madam President, dear Colleagues, The compromise proposal of the European Council and the European Parliament on our table, which concerns the European Union's budget for next year, i.e. 2020, is acceptable in the opinion of the Hungarian delegation of the European People's Party, so we will support the EU budget for 2020 in tomorrow's vote. The positive elements of the compromise that have been reached have already been detailed by my fellow Members. Allow me to mention a joint declaration relating to the agreement between the European Council and Parliament, which is reassuring for European regions implementing improvements from cohesion funds. In a joint statement, the Council and Parliament committed themselves that if the resources provided in next year's budget prove to be insufficient for cohesion payments in 2020, it intends to mobilise additional resources under an accelerated budget in order not to ensure that the accounts submitted in connection with the development carried out by the regions are not paid. I particularly welcome this additional budget, which is acceptable under the fast-track procedure, and the joint declaration in this regard.

name: Mircea-Gheorghe Hava (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the success of the agreement on the European Union budget for 2020 is a success. I congratulate my colleague Monica Hohlmeier on her involvement, as well as all those who made this achievement possible.  An important target of this budget is to increase the allocation for the Erasmus+ programme by EUR 50 million. A working group of programme specialists from all legitimate institutions and beneficiary organisations should be set up with the aim of doing an in-depth analysis of the shortcomings in the programme, the differences in costs, the motivational needs, the human resources involved. Project budgets should contain amounts of money to help beneficiaries better understand, integration into the lives of local communities. This measure must also be matched by an extension of the durations of studies, exchanges and traineeships. This emphasises a greater knowledge of Europe by young people, would really give importance to young people's confidence in the European Union's work project and fully illustrate the need to protect and promote our European lifestyle.  I encourage Member States to come up with national co-financing solutions. This will increase the chances that the programme's objectives and related performance indicators will be achieved, but the impact of the projects will be solid.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, the European Union budget for 2020 is a development challenge for the Member States, which is even based on the new agenda that our citizens are asking for. EUR 850 million to tackle climate change, to employ young people, to the digital economy, to research are committed. Ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to make an appeal here in this House today on the 2020 budget. I would like to make a very critical request concerning its implementation. The possibility of using EUR 778.1 million in commitments to finance immediate needs to address the problems caused by migration, refugee flows and security threats is an important and necessary step.  These funds need to be directed as a matter of priority to the host countries, first of all my country, Greece. Greece assumes a disproportionate responsibility for its potential in welcoming refugees, but also as a destination for irregular migrants. The European Council cannot continue without the Dublin change, it cannot allow countries that refuse to share responsibilities in migration to continue to have all the privileges of funding and Schengen.  The 2020 budget is an opportunity to send the message that the future of Europe is common. We share responsibility for the hard times. We support countries, such as Greece, that undertake difficulties and difficult tasks and strengthen the perspective of young people, tackling climate change and creating conditions to find many good jobs.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, taispeánann an dul chun cinn seo fírinne an tseanfhocail i mo theanga féin – “Ní neart go cur le chéile”. There is no progress without unity. The unity of the Parliament here, particularly under Monika Hohlmeier, José Manuel Fernandes and Jan Olbrycht and all the others, has produced a fantastic result for the European Parliament and indeed for the European people. EUR 450 million extra and EUR 400 million of prioritisation – that’s EUR 850 million. That would not happen if it were not for the Members of the European Parliament. I hope the critics who like to highlight the negative will at least give some recognition to the positive. In my own country we wanted increased funding for the SEF – EUR 96 million extra. Again, will that be highlighted? I hope it will, and I’ll be watching.  The money has been used in a very sensible way: EUR 302 million for Horizon 2020. That research and development programme started under an Irish Commissioner, Máire Geoghegan-Quinn, and was carried on by Commissioner Moedas. This is very important to keep us at the forefront in terms of competitiveness and development and innovation in the world.  Young people, in particular, can rejoice – EUR 50 million extra for Erasmus, EUR 28 million for youth employment, EUR 25 million for DiscoverEU. This shows that young people are a priority for all the Groups in the European Parliament, which is something everybody can rejoice at and I know that this will be greeted properly if it’s advertised and recognised by all the people of Europe.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! First of all, I would like to thank all the Members involved in the negotiation of this budgetary agreement. I believe that a good compromise has been reached in which commitment appropriations have been raised accordingly in order to respond to the current challenges facing the European Union. An additional €850 million compared to the commission's original proposal increases the chances of achieving the objectives smoothly. A significant part of the money will be spent on climate issues, as we know. However, I am pleased that additional money will also be allocated to youth programmes, namely Erasmus+ and the Youth Employment Initiative. Furthermore, I consider it a great success on the part of the European Parliament to provide funding for pilot actions. I consider it an important instrument that, in partnership with the European Commission, allows us to test innovative and innovative solutions at European Union level.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Oettinger for his presentation. Commissioner, you say that 21.1% will go to fight climate change. But I’d like to ask you whether you are not concerned about the lack of joined—up thinking when it comes to dealing with climate change. Do you not think that all infrastructure projects relating to fossil fuel should be banned at this stage – all new projects – and that we need to move on? For example, we are looking at a liquefied natural gas terminal in the Shannon estuary. It will lock us into fracked shale gas for at least 30 years. Do you honestly believe, Commissioner, that this is the way forward? This is to support the American expansion of fracking in America. It can’t be good.  Someone said that there was 50 million extra to be called upon if necessary. Do you not think, given that we have 25 million children across Europe at risk of poverty, that this should now be immediately directed to help those people out of poverty?

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Just three thoughts at the end. Firstly, a response to the honourable Member's spontaneous speech: we have increased the Connecting Europe Facility for Energy by a large majority. When it comes to energy, it is not primarily about LNG terminals, but about the energy infrastructure as a whole. Europe's energy policy has always been made up of three objectives: firstly, sustainability and thus climate protection, secondly, security of supply and, thirdly, energy affordability. It has been a considerable goal in recent years, an expectation from countries such as Poland, Latvia, Lithuania or Estonia that, as long as gas is needed for heat and electricity, these countries will not depend 100% on gas from the Russian Federation, on Gazprom. Hence diversification of routes and sources. Now the new Parliament has to decide – you: what role should gas play in Europe's energy mix in 2020, 2030, 2040 and 2050? My guess is that as long as we shut down coal, gas will become increasingly important in the next ten to fifteen years, then a decline. There is also green gas – a vision: why not produce green gas from solar plants in Africa, which is fed into the gas grid in European LNG terminals and can thus play a climate-neutral and sustainable role in the energy mix of tomorrow and the day after? It is up to you, the next Parliament. The majority of the money goes across borders to power lines and infrastructure to complete the internal energy market and to bring renewables to where they are needed, electricity from renewable sources, for example, wind power from Ireland via England to the European Union. We will then decide on the specific projects at a later stage, but since the list of applications is long, more resources will certainly make sense. I would like to thank the Finnish Presidency once again, as the second last point. Why? We have cut the budget estimates for administration by means of an amendment, because salaries will rise only marginally next year. And the fact that you, Mr Tiilikainen, did not use the reflex of previous years, namely to demand another EUR 5 or 10 million in cuts to heading 5 at the last second, was sovereign. Thank you very much for that. You can be sure that this will not lead to arrogance in all the institutions – Parliament, the Court of Auditors, the Commission, European Schools, etc. – but that we will examine very carefully what will be necessary for the proper management of Europe next year and in the years to come. One final thought: if you, honourable Members, vote in favour of this 2020 budget tomorrow, this will be the first important decision of the new Parliament, apart from the election of the President and more. Allow me to say that on the subject of 'What role do the leading candidates play?' – functionally, not the people – you did not get a majority. The fact that you have now obtained a broad majority gives us all the courage, and my advice is: keep the objective of achieving a broad majority on the right track for the next decade. Then this 2020 budget may have been a good blueprint for the next seven years. Thank you very much.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the House for this constructive exchange of views and also for picking up a great number of valuable details that the budget contains. The discussion has shown that we are united in our commitment to build a better working Europe to the benefit of all our citizens. The negotiations on the 2020 budget took place under complex and uncertain circumstances. In spite of this, we worked together with a very good spirit and found a way to reconcile our positions. I am convinced that the agreement reached on the budget for 2020 is a good and balanced compromise, allowing the Union to adequately finance our common priorities and different programmes.
