I thank you once more for your attention and wish you success in tomorrow’s vote to finalise our important work.

name: Johan Van Overtveldt
text: Chairman BUDG. Mr President, I think it is a fairly correct summary of the speeches we have heard today that there is a clear majority in this Parliament in favour of the compromise reached on the budget. I have also heard many things say: 'It could have been better', and that is of course true, but that is true for any budget in any circumstances in any period of time. Every budget is a compromise. Each budget falls short of individual priorities or priorities of certain groups or groups individually. So in that sense, that is the fate of every budget. But again, I have found that there is a large majority, which is, of course, a happy observation as chairman of the Committee on Budgets.  This comes at a pivotal moment for Europe. The whole world is on the move as rarely before: China, the US, geopolitical movements, technology, climate... The list can be made for a long time. It is extremely important that Europe is firmly in its shoes here. Without doing so in an explicit way, Europe will become a footnote in history, and I think that everyone who is here wants to prevent it in a constructive way. If Europe is to assert itself, it will also require resources and the efficient use of resources. The two are going together irrevocably. The forthcoming discussions on the new MFK will be of exceptional importance and very careful, well-founded considerations will have to be made in order to reach a constructive, creative and bold compromise, because that too will have to be a compromise by definition.  I hope that we can do so in an atmosphere of mutual trust and respectful candor, as we have been able to do with the last discussions in the conciliation procedure, and the great honour for that goes to the rapporteurs, Monika and Eider, certainly goes to the Finnish Presidency, Kimmo and his team, but certainly also to someone we are saying today – as we say in Flanders. , with his feet hanging – say goodbye to, Commissioner Oettinger. I can't stress it enough. His contribution, from him and from his team, to reaching the compromise over the past week was very great, for which once again, dear Günther, my greatest appreciation.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 27 November 2019. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I congratulate and thank the rapporteurs: Monica Hohlmeier and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, the Finnish Presidency, the Commissioner and everyone involved in the work on the budget. The Council and the European Parliament agreed on 18 November on the EU budget for 2020. Total commitment appropriations will amount to EUR 168.7 billion. This is an increase of 1.5% compared to the previous year. Total payment appropriations will amount to EUR 153.6 billion, an increase of 3.4% compared to the previous year. The implementation of the 2014-2020 programmes is still intensive. Thanks to our budget compromise, beneficiaries will receive payments on time.  We want and support growth and competitiveness, EUR 25.3 billion (+7.9% compared to 2019) will receive programmes from Heading 1a (Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs). Horizon 2020 (eur 13.5 billion in total, +8.8%), European satellite navigation systems (EGNOS and Galileo) (EUR 1.2 billion, +74.8%) are more resources. and the energy component of the Connecting Europe Facility (EUR 1.3 billion, +35.0%). Erasmus+ will receive EUR 2.9 billion (+3.6%) for youth exchanges, which are used by many young people, including from my homeland. The 2020 budget can be called a youth-friendly budget, as EUR 145 million has been allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative in the regions most affected by unemployment.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. " A well-structured EU budget is extremely important for the people of our countries. This is important for the development of the new Member States. The problem of harmonising the potential and standard of living of the so-called old and new Union should therefore be taken into account in particular. More attention needs to be paid to agriculture and unduly lower subsidies to farmers in new countries such as Lithuania, and this situation needs to be changed. In addition, the Youth Employment Initiative should be supported. Cooperation in the European field of youth and the participation of young people in European social life need to be encouraged and improved. The drafting, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of EU employment policy, social policy and EU working conditions legislation also deserve support. The same applies to support to Member States in the event of major natural disasters which have a significant impact on living conditions, the environment or the economy. However, the main objective should be budget support for activities that protect the health and life of our citizens. Further efforts should therefore be made to promote health promotion and prevention. Particular attention should be paid to combating and combating cancer, disability and functional limitations, for example by transferring knowledge for use in clinical practice and innovation activities, making better use of medical data. First of all, human life and health, and secondly, the economy.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the EU's response to extreme weather events and their effects: how to protect Europe's urban areas and their cultural heritage? (2019/2932(RSP))

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, climate change is real and its impacts are all too real. Extreme weather events are happening more frequently, and unfortunately with greater intensity. Droughts and forest fires are no longer confined to the Mediterranean, as we saw in Sweden last year; tropical hurricanes travel up to the coast of Ireland; heavy rain and flash floods occur across Europe. The floods affecting Venice are yet another tragic example, causing immense damage to Venice, its people and their livelihoods – also to the cultural heritage of Italy, of Europe and of humanity as a whole. The European Union has developed tools to provide assistance once natural disasters have occurred. From prevention and preparedness to the recovery phase. On prevention and preparedness, the Commission supports the development and improvement of EU Early Warning and Information Systems. For example, projects funded under Horizon 2020 are improving the prediction of the impact of heavy rain and snowfall on roads. For floods specifically, the European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) offers the latest available information on floods in Europe. The Commission also provides guidelines and encourages Member States to compile national risk assessments, which are an essential tool to fight the impact of floods.  For the immediate response in the event of a disaster, our European Civil Protection Mechanism and the new upgrade rescEU structure can be activated at the request of the affected countries to support them in their response to floods. Recent examples include the 2013 support following extensive floods in Central Europe and the 2014 floods in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, where extensive response capacities were deployed, including rescue helicopters and boats, teams of experts and response modules. To be noted that in the aftermath of disastrous forest fires in 2017, the European Union, as I already said, adopted rescEU. It is a safety net to support our Member States when they are overwhelmed by natural disasters. For the recovery phase, you know very well that the EU Solidarity Fund intervenes to assist the population in the recovery of essential infrastructure, in clean-up operations and in the safeguarding of the cultural heritage. Now, turning to the EU response to the floods affecting the region of Venice. The European Commission, through its Copernicus emergency satellite mapping system – a very sophisticated and excellent system – has already produced high-quality maps to assess the extent of floods in Northeast Italy. These products are provided free of charge to any affected country, and are used extensively by our Member States. Also, the EU Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC) has also been in regular contact with the Italian authorities and continues to closely monitor the situation. The Commission stands ready to support Italy through the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism if needed. So far, we have not received any requests for support. Also, for the recovery phase, the Solidarity Fund could be activated in case total direct damage exceeds a threshold of 1.5% of regional GDP, which in the case of the Veneto region means damage exceeding EUR 2.3 billion. This is our regulation, these are our rules. The Commission has established direct contact with the Italian authorities and is providing guidance and advice on a possible application through the Solidarity Fund. At this stage, it is too early to know the exact extent of the damage on which the possible mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund and the amount of assistance would depend. But we must do more. What happened in Venice is, unfortunately, an example of what is to come as climate change develops. We must be proactive, and this is why in recent years the Commission has been putting an increased focus on prevention, climate adaptation and risk management policies. Here I would like to say that I am really proud of our common achievement to establish rescEU in which one of the most important pillars is prevention and preparedness, and I think we have to continue in this way. I am sure that the next Commission will continue in this way because it is the only way to deal with the new phenomena due to climate change.

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commission and Commissioner Stylianides for the efforts they have confirmed, on the part of the Commission, to help the populations affected by the bad weather in recent weeks in Spain, France and Italy in particular. I would also like to thank Commissioner Hahn for his commitment to helping the populations and areas affected, but also the cultural heritage affected, because Venice has suffered enormous damage, Veneto, Trentino Alto Adige, but also the city of Matera – which is European Capital of Culture this year – has also been the victim of bad weather. In these hours most of the cities of Liguria are isolated, including Genoa and Savona. I spoke to the mayor of Savona just now, I spoke to the mayor of Venice. Bridges have collapsed, roads are closed, the region bordering France is practically isolated, ports are blocked and there is enormous damage to the economy. That is why we need strong solidarity on the part of the European Union. Economic proximity but also efforts to try to prevent everything that happens in a country where most municipalities – I am referring to Italy – are born in areas of high hydrogeological risk. More than 80 % of Italian municipalities, 81.9 % of Italian municipalities, are born in areas with a high hydrogeological risk, and therefore a strong prevention activity is needed. In Venice, historical and cultural heritage is also threatened by the presence of the sea, as salt water erodes the foundations. That is why we need to do even more, and I hope that Italy, the Italian Government and the regions, will demand a strong commitment to the European Commission's Solidarity Fund and therefore make use of the availability that exists. We in the European People's Party have asked the European Commission to set up a fund for the protection of Europe's cultural heritage which has been damaged and to prevent any damage caused by bad weather, and therefore even stronger action in the next Community budget. I therefore agree with you and I hope that the next European Commission, which we will vote on tomorrow, will continue along the path chosen by the current Commission but will invest even more in cultural and infrastructural prevention in areas of high hydrogeological risk, which are not only in my country but also in Central Europe, Spain and France.

name: Simona Bonafè
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the images that have toured the world of high water in Venice, right up to the Basilica where it never arrived, cannot leave us indifferent, just as we cannot be indifferent to the images that come from other European and Italian cities underwater. Of course, it has always happened that in autumn it rains and rains a lot, but today we are dealing with a new phenomenon, climate change, which is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events. The sooner we learn to deal with it, the better. Our cities are the area most at risk, because that is where the majority of the European population lives. It is our duty first and foremost to protect human lives and our historical and cultural heritage, because in Europe we have the honour of hosting almost 400 UNESCO sites. A wealth that every European citizen feels as his own and for which he is willing to mobilize, as happened in the flood of 1966 in Florence, when boys and girls, then called "angels of mud", came from all over the continent to save the works of art, manifesting a first form of European civicism. The question then is: what can Europe do? Increasing aid from the European Solidarity Fund is needed, but it is no longer enough, just as ex post mechanisms are not enough. We can't act every time in the damage count. We need to prevent catastrophic effects first, and that is what I want to focus on. Let's start by saying that we have built too much and badly in our cities. We must start from a great cultural battle, even before the environmental battle, over the consumption and protection of the soil and put the debate on the need for a specific European Union directive back at the centre. In addition, tragedies are avoided if environmental mitigation works are done: one does not expect the river to flood but to build expansion crates and hydraulic regination works. So the sustainable investment plan, which we are waiting for from President von der Leyen, must contain an ad hoc chapter for hydrogeological prevention. Finally, the time has come to open a serious debate on the possibility of offing green investment from the deficit-GDP calculation of the Stability and Growth Pact. On the consequences of extreme weather, the European Union must show its citizens that it is capable of setting an agenda and putting it into practice. The Group of Socialists and Democrats will not fail to play its part.

name: Laurence Farreng
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Venice is now sinking. Indeed, the phenomenon of acqua alta is intensifying, floods are multiplying, are always more frequent and ever higher. What for? Because for too long we no longer respect the identity of this city that has given itself the sea as a bulwark. The lagoon no longer protects because it is no longer protected. Already, in 2016, the organization Europa Nostra ranked the Venice Lagoon first among the most endangered European sites. If nothing is done to finally complete the floating project that was planned for 2001, Unesco will remove Venice from the World Heritage list. For sixty years, the lagoon of Venice has been undermined by oversized maritime traffic to allow the passage of tankers and also to promote mass tourism. However, if the Heritage disappears, the tourist windfall will also disappear. We Europeans have the opportunity to save Venice and, in the future, to protect the threatened sites. Let us therefore make the protection of our cultural heritage an all part of the European Green Pact. Europe already has successes to its credit, such as Mont Saint-Michel. The European Union, through the Regional Development Fund, has provided EUR 10 million to restore its maritime character to this place, by enshrining it in a sustainable tourism approach. Preserving cultural heritage also means protecting the ecosystems in which they are located, promoting the development of responsible tourism that will ensure the maintenance of activity and employment. Today, our priority must be to save Venice. It is a unifying project for all Europeans, it is also a global responsibility.

name: Pär Holmgren
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for When the first reports came from the UN Panel on Climate Change, which is now almost 30 years ago, what is happening right now was still just theories about what could happen in the future. So it is happening now – exactly what climate scientists have warned about. Heat waves are getting longer and warmer, the torrential rains are getting more intense. Periods of drought are also becoming longer and more intense, and thus also increase the risk of forest fires. The seas are rising, just as we see in Venice now. What is happening in Venice now will happen again, more and more often in the future. So far, the world's oceans are only rising by three millimetres per year. It sounds quite a bit, but it will accelerate and it will last for centuries or even millennia to come. Unfortunately, there are simply some things that we can no longer avoid. It's gone too far. That is why we need to work very intensively on climate adaptation, not least with regard to our coasts and all the major cities and ports that lie on our coasts. Thankfully, there is also much that we can still avoid. We can avoid the worst disasters. We can still keep global warming below 2 degrees, but then it is important that all of us here, parliamentarians and the Commission, work together in all policy areas to meet what we have promised each other and the rest of the world in the Paris Agreement, namely to keep global warming well below 2 degrees, with a view to 1.5 degrees. Science has provided us with the basis for what is required. It is now a matter of us as politicians in all political groups delivering what is required, for ourselves and, of course, also for our children and grandchildren and future generations.

name: Rosanna Conte
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 'Venice sinks', 'Venice is scourged', 'Submerged Venice', are just a few headlines around the world after high water caused incalculable damage to their value in Venice on 12 November and the following days. True, bad weather has affected several regions of Italy. Today, here in Strasbourg, I express my deep affection for all the people affected and for my land. Venice, however, is unique and belongs not only to the Italian State but to the whole of Europe and the whole world. Venice collects western humanism and eastern humanism, the historical stratification of its monuments, with its imposing St. Mark's Basilica, heavily damaged by this new flood. Seeing Venice wounded and annihilated by the water that invaded it everywhere was a real blow to the heart. Wounded but proudly always with his head held high, as it is in the character of the Venetians: proud, hardworking and never tame. The words of a poem say: "From the overwhelmed water, from the betrayed sea, once again Venice is wounded", and then "Venice, you are alone!". They also say, "But the sunrise is near, the day wants you, be strong, Regina, that the sun will come". Today we have to show that Venice is not alone. Venice needs everyone, it needs Europe. Venice with its territory, with the islands of the Lido and Pellestrina, with the reality of Chioggia and the coast. Well, today I am here to represent, as a Venetian, the high cry of pain that has been raised and that Europe must collect, without wasting time because the further we go, the greater the risks. This time Europe must not turn its head the other way. It is essential that not only messages of solidarity but concrete interventions, certain interventions, with mechanisms that make them immediate and more responsive, start. The work of civil protection, firefighters and volunteers, the expectations and needs of citizens and economic operators demand speed and immediacy from this Europe. The Solidarity Fund must be reviewed today because it is complex in its activation. We need special ad hoc funds for particularly sensitive and difficult areas, possibly with direct management of the regions, and leaner and less bureaucratic procedures. Venice, but not only Venice, expects this from Europe, quickly and without wasting time.

name: Anna Zalewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I think we need to start with the fact that we need Venice here and now to say that we are with it and we will support it. The Commissioner has shown the mechanisms that are already in place in the European Union and that can be used. And he declares full commitment. It was mentioned that it is worth appointing a committee to analyse the review. Yes, you need to see how these mechanisms work and how to improve them to better prevent them.  I am a little worried that my colleagues are mixing the situation in Venice with climate change. It is enough to know the history of Venice to know that every 10-20 years this situation is repeated. Even in 19th-century works of art, for which we are responsible as citizens of Europe and the world, such evidence can be found. I would also like to remind you that it was in Venice in 1966 that a preventive decision was made to build a dam assembly. This construction has been going on since 1985 and is endless. It is constantly accompanied by protests by environmentalists. I will not mention the discussions that have taken place in recent years about the use of the money allocated to this project. Let us act. Let us respect each other. Let us be responsible for civilization.

name: Αλέξης Γεωργούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, it is a fact that we are experiencing a serious climate crisis. Natural disasters of the past have demonstrated the danger of this crisis, wiping out important parts of our history and memory. This is a destruction of valuable knowledge that makes us backtrack. Greece, the country from which I come, is a country with great cultural wealth and numerous archaeological sites, which contributes significantly to our world cultural heritage. Unfortunately, however, he mourns many such losses. And of course she's not the only one.  The recent example of Venice shows us that we cannot and must not turn a blind eye to such losses. Similar losses, for example, occur in Corfu, Delos and Rhodes. It would therefore be unjustified, until criminal, to wait for them to be noted. We cannot let the climate crisis wipe out the foundations of our civilization.

name: Sabrina Pignedoli (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, continuous environmental disasters afflict every country in Europe, from north to south. Last week, a world heritage site such as Venice suffered very serious damage as a result of the floods. It is necessary to release the EU Solidarity Fund appropriations as soon as possible and to facilitate investment in land maintenance, but it is likely that what happened in Venice will happen again. The latest report by the UN Environment Agency talks about a 3.2 degree rise in temperatures from pre-industrial levels, with a great risk of destructive weather events. The reason? Global greenhouse gases continue to increase, despite efforts to try to limit them. Europe has decided to move towards a green new deal, but its vision must be global and indeed very ambitious. The European states must, in fact, become an example of how development and environmental protection can go hand in hand. Europe can and must become a point of reference and a model of success for newly industrialised states that continue to increase their emissions of polluting gases. And it can only do so by putting in place successful actions, with major investments in green conversion. We must certainly focus on research, development and new technologies, but we must always keep companies at the centre, which must not be left alone in this path, but rather must benefit competitively in the medium and long term.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, indeed, the north of Italy – and also the region from which I come – has been hit by severe storms in recent weeks. This comes just a year after Storm Vaia moved over exactly the same region and fortunately – with the support of the European Solidarity Fund – has managed to repair the worst damage. Now it is the case that we are already used to dealing with extreme weather conditions in the mountains, and also know what to do then. It must also be said that if in the last few days the damage has been somewhat contained, it is also thanks to the thousands of volunteers – the fire brigades, the civil protection units – who have worked day and night, bringing electricity and water back to people and trying to get to grips with the worst damage. But the city of Venice is, of course, a symbol of Europe. I think it is also up to the European Union to ensure that this symbol of Venice – this very special city – is put right and that the damage that has been caused there is also repaired. However, I also think – as many of the previous speakers have also said – that we also need to think long-term. We need to consider the extent to which we are investing more in civil protection. I would remind you that a euro invested in civil protection will save four euros in repairs. But we must also see that people stay on the mountain, especially in the mountains. The mountain farmers, the people who live there, are responsible for ensuring that the land, the area, is preserved. That is why we also need an active policy for people living in rural areas.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Madam President, at the outset I want to express my solidarity to the people of Venice and Italy itself. There is no doubt that Venice is a cultural capital. It’s an iconic city. You look at the Renaissance architecture and all that it has given to Europe in terms of history, politics and culture. So, from that perspective, I do want to convey my deepest sympathies.  Of course, we have to acknowledge that global warming and rising sea levels are now a factor that continually threaten our coastal areas, so Venice is just a symbol of what is happening across the globe. Couple that with the fact that most major cities are in confluences or deltas and coastal areas would indicate that we’re going to face these challenges on a continual basis. The European Union and individual Member States will have to accept and address this particular issue of rising sea levels and how they protect our cities and towns from flooding. From that perspective, I can understand how people in Venice feel, owing to the fact that my own city of Cork in Ireland has experienced flooding on a regular basis. So we do need to put in place proper funds and ensure that there is solidarity with cities and towns that continually flood.

name: Caroline Roose (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, in recent days we have been very affected by the events - floods, rescues, floods - that have taken place in Venice and on all the coasts of the Mediterranean most exposed to bad weather. The images of these storms are striking and show us the need to put in place more effective response mechanisms to deal with natural disasters and protect our cultural heritage. In France, heavy rains across the region over the weekend caused huge damage. Last weekend, I was on a mission and returned Sunday evening to my town, Villeneuve-Loubet in the Alpes-Maritimes, which was totally flooded. The area was hit by a heavy rain on Saturday night and residents were surprised by a sudden rise in water. Despite the existence of a retention pond, the river in my village, the Wolf, overflowed at an impressive rate, causing major flooding. We cannot ignore the fact that because of global warming, the temperature of the Mediterranean water has increased, increasing the frequency and intensity of storms. In the face of these events, cultural heritage is increasingly exposed to natural disasters. Appropriate measures are needed to reduce the risk of disaster. Thus, an integrated vision of cultural heritage is needed to assess the risks to heritage sites before and after a disaster. In addition, integrated disaster risk management involves adequate mitigation and adaptation strategies. For example, there is a need to curb the limitless urban sprawl and the artificialization of soils that make them less permeable. In conclusion, it is still possible to defend our regions and their cultural heritage in the face of climate change, but governments need to provide more resources to protect their citizens and implement strategic management plans that are resilient to floods.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 'apocalyptic and total devastation', as the Governor of the Veneto Region, Luca Zaia, described the emergency situation caused by the flood of 12 November that hit the city of Venice, the lagoon and the Venetian coast. The damage caused to Venice's infrastructure, businesses, public and private property and cultural heritage is more than one billion. Particularly affected are the basilicas of San Marco, Murano, Torcello, not forgetting the impressive number of churches, 120, half of which went underwater, causing greater damage, only to churches, for 3 million euros. The damage suffered by the library and the Conservatory has been extensive: numerous important musical documents have been compromised, including the scores of composers such as Vivaldi and Beethoven. Faced with a disaster in Venice and its lagoon, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, the European Union cannot remain indifferent. This is the time to show that the European Union is not only a union of great financial interests but also a citizens' union for its citizens. The European Solidarity Fund is therefore mobilised immediately, with additional extraordinary funds and funds for the preservation of a unique cultural heritage such as that of our great city.

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, venice, a world heritage site, is crying. Matera, European Capital of Culture 2019, mourns. Liguria and Piedmont suffer, plagued by the bad weather of these days, like the coasts swept by very violent storms. All this, as well as similar phenomena that have occurred over the years in many Member States, leads us to say that Europe cannot be content to react after tragedies, with a few small appropriations. There is a lot of discussion about the green new deal, but the real turning point, in our opinion, is to invest first, alongside the Solidarity Fund, which we are once again worthily mobilising, a European Fund for the prevention of hydrogeological failure, seismic risk and coastal erosion, debing from the calculation of the debt the expenditure on investments dedicated to secureing infrastructure and seizing our territories , to defend not only its heritage of architectural, cultural and natural beauty, but also to defend the presence of man and his activities in these unique territories, but so fragile. Now is the time for action.

name: Pernando Barrena Arza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, according to a study published by The Lancet magazine, at the end of the century climate disasters could lead to up to one hundred and fifty thousand deaths per year in Europe. Extreme weather events will mostly affect the countries of the south of the continent, and we know that they will be more extreme and severe. In the Basque Country and Navarra we are also suffering these consequences. Last July, in Tafalla we suffered flooding caused by unprecedented torrential rains. The Union should ensure more ambitious measures and policies for the prevention and mitigation of the consequences of these natural disasters, because the Union's solidarity funds are insufficient to deal with these increasingly local and timely disasters, as in Tafalla, because, despite the irreparable damage caused, they do not reach 1.5% of the regional gross domestic product necessarily established in order to be able to count on such aid. The European Union should reconsider the fate of its funds, ensuring that they help build a just and ecological society. And on Thursday this Parliament has the opportunity to declare the climate and environmental emergency so that we can allocate more funds to mitigate the impacts of climate change and take steps to adapt to the new situation.

name: Rosa D'Amato (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, here we go again, we are still here talking, once again, about natural disasters. We are faced with the enormous damage to the historical, cultural and archaeological heritage of Matera and Venice. There are major economic losses for businesses and citizens. All right, the European Solidarity Fund will be used, but also the Union Civil Protection Mechanism, the clause that the European Commission has available in the budget law can and must be applied in these cases. These are useful tools, but now we need to reverse the perspective, the vision. We need to get out of the emergency logic and act structurally on prevention and the causes. In December 2016, this House adopted a motion for a resolution and an amendment, proposed by the 5Star Movement, calling for and approving by a large majority the need to exclude from the calculation of the deficit, within the framework of the Stability and Growth Pact, investments in sustainable reconstruction and earthquake prevention, including the European Structural Funds. Therefore, there can be no green new deal without recognising the hydrogeological disaster as a priority, and above all without recognising and concretely addressing with the facts the fight against climate change, which exists and exists, and which some, on the other hand, continue to forage or even deny, but it finances investments in fossil sources.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to start my address by expressing my condolences to all the families of the loved ones who lost their lives in today’s earthquake in Albania. Unfortunately, a few weeks ago, Venice made it into the headlines following massive floods and, unfortunately, this is yet another disaster which we have to address. I hereby call on the Commission for a speedy procedure in order to trigger the Solidarity Fund and targeted ERDF support. I believe that, in order to prevent such things, we should invest in prevention more than recovering from such disasters. I believe that the European Union should have relations just like in a marriage so it should be there in good and bad times. When somebody falls to the ground, there should be a hand to pick him up. These hands will be the European Commission and the European Parliament for Italy.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I think it is important that we take this opportunity to talk, not only about extreme weather as such, but also to link it to the global warming that we are seeing and the climate emergency that Europe and the world are in right now. Extreme weather can take different forms, but the damage to Venice in recent weeks is hitting the heart of Europe particularly hard – Venice, with its unique cultural influences from west to east, intertwined over the years and centuries and has helped to make this city truly unique. It is both one of the most beautiful cities known to many in Europe and a city that is loved not only in Italy but throughout Europe, and which forms part of our world cultural heritage. It is clear that we feel very strongly on the part of the European Parliament with all the people who are affected and with the city as such. I myself come from a country where we have been hit by fires as a result of the drought and warming that we are seeing in the world. Fires and forest fires have ravaged my country, Sweden, where several people and cities, as well as nature, economic values and jobs have been threatened because of this. It is important that we act resolutely in the light of these extreme weather. Of course, it is about climate policy and long-term prevention policy, but it is also about urgently helping and ensuring that resistance is built where we see that cities and people can be affected. It is not just fires, floods, hurricanes or droughts, but it is actually a question of us having global warming that we have to deal with and that we must work with firmness on the part of Europe. The temperature increases that we are going against at the moment mean that we will see much more of this. I would therefore like to call on my fellow Members to vote in favour of the climate emergency that we also have on the table for this week's part-session.

name: Salima Yenbou (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I would still like to draw your attention to what is happening today in Venice and its region, but also elsewhere unfortunately. We have all seen this very large flood, which has reached 187 cm, an all-time high since 1966. No, Mrs Zalewska, this flood is not ordinary. According to forecast figures, the damage could reach more than one billion euros, and every day spent underwater significantly damages buildings. According to experts, St. Mark's Basilica ages twenty years a day of flooding. This phenomenon of floods and natural disasters affects other regions in Italy, such as Basilicata, Matera , the European Capital of Culture in 2019 - and many other countries around the world. Several observations appear. First of all, it is obvious that exceptional climatic phenomena are increasing and that the entire Mediterranean rim is affected. By 2100, the rise of the waters could be up to 140 cm, unlike the 30 cm of the last century. The combination of natural and human-in-hand factors endangers all ecosystems and the preservation of cultural heritage around the world. Thus, poorly managed urban planning, mass tourism, especially in high-risk areas, and projects such as the Moses dam, which are neither completed nor necessarily solutions, are all causes that could slow the fight against rising waters, the preservation of our cultural capital and the assistance to the inhabitants. That is why we call on the European Union to urgently release the Solidarity Fund, we call for research on ecological systems to prevent flooding to be undertaken and we call on the European Union to seize this event in order to preserve our world heritage. If you don't, everything will disappear.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my solidarity with all the citizens who have been victims of the terrible wave of bad weather that has hit the whole of Italy, in particular Veneto, Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Trentino-Alto Adige and Emilia Romagna. I would like to thank civil protection and the volunteers who have helped and are helping citizens in difficulty. Venice, its lagoon, the Venetian coast, from Jesolo to Chioggia, have been plagued by floods and storms. Houses, businesses, public and private property, historic buildings, 70 churches, symbolic places like St. Mark's Basilica have been devastated by high water. More than 80 % of Venice has gone underwater. We're talking about a billion damages. Faced with the emergency in Venice, Europe has a duty to make all possible funds available immediately, starting with the European Solidarity Fund. Our money must be used to help the Venetians, brought to their knees by bad weather, and to secure a city unique in the world, which represents a historical and cultural reference point for all Western civilization. The Venetians reacted immediately, with heart and pride, put on their boots and cleaned the houses and shops. The Venetians are asking Europe, and we together with them, are asking for maximum cooperation in order to allocate extraordinary funds and to save Venice, a world heritage city. As they say in Venice: "Hard benches!"

name: Nicola Procaccini (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Italy is experiencing times of great suffering as a result of increasingly violent weather events, which affect a territory of great beauty but dramatically fragile. Almost 90 % of my fellow countrymen, it has already been said, live in the shadow of hydrogeological risk and in 2018, last year, tens of thousands were landslides, as unfortunately dozens were the victims of those landslides. I myself, before becoming a Member of the European Parliament, was mayor of my city for many years and had to mourn the disappearance of too many of my fellow citizens. We need concreteness and we need it now. We need to invest in the prevention strategy, economic investments to be accompanied by the deficit-to-GDP ratio imposed by the European Union, and we need to support the civil protection system of our nations, because when the time comes for need we need men and means ready to intervene and not the empty words of politics.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, with the debate on extreme weather events and climate change you are trying to conceal the fact that today the progress of science and technology is able to offer people much greater protection from natural phenomena than in the past, preventing or significantly limiting the consequences, and on the basis of any changes in the climate.  The brakes on these possibilities are now putting the criterion of profit, the dangerous cost-benefit perception of the European Union, the minimal piecemeal projects, the distinction in high- and low-risk areas condemning workers to remain unsemed. All of the above are the result of European directives and the timeless unpopular policy in Greece, both new democracy and SYRIZA.  You have answered our question about the floods in Evia that neither the Solidarity Fund nor the ERDF compensates individuals, i.e. those affected themselves. So your tools are only for the groups. In the area of Kinetta, with last year's large fires, this is the third time that the same houses of the fire-affected people, who have not even been compensated for the previous disasters, have flooded. Extensive damage has recently occurred in Crete, Evia, Halkidiki, Thassos, Ionian, Rhodes, Peloponnese, Western Greece and elsewhere, and require immediate compensation and restoration projects. In conflict with European Union policy, we demand that those affected now be compensated and that immediate measures be taken against flood defences, civil protection, infrastructure, personnel, with integrated state scientific planning.

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Floods, storms, severe fires, but also earthquakes and landslides and other natural disasters are constantly endangering our cultural heritage. Venice, the unesco World Heritage site, was hit by an extraordinary flood in the first weeks of November when the water reached 1.80 metres high. There is also severe severe weather in other parts of Italy. Matera, this year's European Capital of Culture, was also flooded. It was the worst flooding in more than 50 years and, to this extent, not a recurring event. Venice declared a state of emergency and the Italian government pledged €20 million in emergency aid to repair the immediate damage. But it is still difficult to quantify how much damage is actually done. St. Mark's Square, home of St. Mark's Basilica, many museums and cultural monuments, as well as the Venice Biennale, were under water, and the salt water alone caused enormous damage to the cultural sites. The floods are a stab in the heart of Italy, said Italy's Prime Minister, but it is also a stab in the heart for us Europeans, because a primal European task is to protect our cultural assets, and we do so in many places. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has proposed to the Commission the creation of a fund for the protection of the EU's cultural heritage to ensure the preservation of our most valuable historical treasures and to ensure that Europe stands behind its Member States when natural disasters hit them hard. The purpose of this fund is to restore and preserve our cultural heritage, which is threatened and damaged by natural disasters, for future generations. But protection projects such as the MOSE project must also be promoted, but also many others. We must go hand in hand here. But this fund will at least help to rebuild our cultural heritage where damage has already been done.

name: Hannes Heide (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Floods, floods, avalanches, landslides, mudslides: we in Austria are regularly confronted with this.  However, we note that these events occur more intensively and at ever shorter intervals. I have also had this experience as mayor of a city of 14 000 inhabitants. Perhaps a small city, but we have a great cultural heritage, and we are also the European Capital of Culture in 2024. There is often a lack of money for prevention measures, and I also call for the funds for risk management to be taken into account for prevention measures. Often the money is missing for alarm plans, for flood pictures, for level readings, for equipment for our volunteers or for flood warning cards. It is very important to make funds available for prevention as well and to invest in this area as well. There is also also often a lack of funds for appropriate protective construction measures. I would ask you to draw attention to this and to take this into account.

name: Niklas Nienaß (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Article 167 of the Treaty states ‘action by the Union shall be aimed at the conservation and safeguarding the cultural heritage of European significance’. How to fulfill this duty? Well the last weeks have proven that once again one of the solutions is tackling climate change. What we do not need now is this religious-like belief that future technology will save us, is this bullshitting around of denying climate change or this useless discussion about what to do. We know what to do: stop coal until 2030; implement an ETS that covers all sectors with a limited amount of certificates; introduce additional carbon taxes on transport and travel; establish a border adjustment and use all the revenues for climate research adaptation and mitigation. But what we also need is more money to save our European culture. I call for a fund for the salvation of heritage sites with special significance for our common European history. We must protect our background, but also invest in a common cultural future or, as Robert Schuman put it in 1951, ‘much more than an economic alliance, Europe has to become a cultural union’.

name: Markus Buchheit (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The events, particularly in Venice, have also particularly affected me personally. However, extreme weather events are not a modern phenomenon. Coastal residents have been battling the tides for years and days. In cities such as Venice, Rotterdam and London, people have been working for centuries not to control the uncontrollable climate, but to arm themselves against its excesses. They do not sit in their ivory tower, but are personally rooted in their homeland and also personally affected. That should also be the lesson we should learn here: subsidiarity is the best protection for the cities concerned. No one knows the local conditions better, is more committed to protecting their own cultural assets than the local people. What is currently required is not to apportion blame, but to recognise the competence of those affected and to support their protection efforts for the future, as well as support in dealing with the current disasters.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the dramatic images of the floods that are taking place in recent days are yet another demonstration of the effects of climate change. At the end of October the high water in Venice reached one meter and 56 centimeters. Yesterday a portion of viaduct collapsed on the Turin-Savona and devastating images also come from southern Italy. Between now and the year 2100 extreme weather events such as these could increase by 50 % and, according to a study by the European Environment Agency, in just 36 years extreme weather events have resulted in economic losses totalling EUR 450 billion And who is paying for it? It is not the citizens who should pay, but the companies that operate with fossil fuels, because it is they who have contributed to the rise in global temperatures and thus to the increase in natural disasters.  In the past, oil companies have not only concealed that the use of fossil fuels would have harmful consequences for the climate, but some have even invested in disinformation about climate change. But the time for disinformation is over and with the recent development of attribution science it is possible to link the responsibility of a single company to a particular climate event, and this would allow the "polluter pays" principle to be truly applied. So no more lies, it's time for the oil companies to pay for the damage they've done.

name: Alessandra Moretti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the whole of Italy has been plagued for weeks by weather events that are putting the very country's resilience at risk. Unfortunately, these are no longer extraordinary events, but the regularity and continuity of what is happening is dramatically worrying. Climate change puts us in front of our responsibilities, but we cannot blame climate change all the time, we must be able to do more and better. Human lives, economic and productive activities, artistic and cultural assets of inestimable value: we are facing a phenomenon that affects our country with unprecedented hardness. In the immediate future, the Italian Government has created a special economic zone for Venice and the municipalities of Polesine, in harmony with European standards and demonstrating synergy between the institutions. Europe, however, will also have to play its part, including through the activation of the most urgent instruments available, such as the Solidarity Fund that was activated in 2012 for Emilia Romagna. But the emergency answer is not enough. Today we need a real European strategy to take care of our most fragile territories, an extraordinary plan against hydrogeological failure, for the modernisation of infrastructure, to secure all our citizens and to preserve Europe's artistic heritage. Finally, I would like to see one of the symbols of this fragile Europe, the city of Venice, which for centuries has defeated the impossible: built on the sea and made unique in its beauty. Venice can, if we so wish, be the symbol of a European rebirth based on security and sustainability, one that can defend us against the negative effects of climate change and that puts into practice all the actions necessary to reverse course and definitively stop the environmental degeneration that is taking place. If Italy and Europe are able to save Venice, this will be the symbol of a Europe that can do it, overcoming enormous obstacles, and then being able to do it together will be a good message that we give to the world.

name: Ciarán Cuffe (Verts/ALE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá cathair stairiúil na Veinéise i mbaol agus tá seans ann gur gearr go n-imeoidh sí i léig. Tá gach cathair atá suite cois farraige nó in aice na farraige i mbaol. Ciallaíonn sé sin go bhfuil na milliúin daoine i mbaol. I mbaol ó eachtraí adhaimsire. Ón truailliú. I mbaol ón athrú aeráide. Coicís ó shin, chonaic an Veinéis na tuilte is airde le caoga bliain anuas. Ailtireacht iontach na cathrach, a dánlanna – iad uile i mbaol. Is mian liom Massimo Cacciari a mholadh, iarMhéara na Veinéise, a labhair ag an am sin faoi éiceolaíocht leochaileach mhurlach na Veinéise. Is mian liom ICOMOS a mholadh as an dea-obair a dhéanann siad chun na foirgnimh agus na tírdhreacha seo a chosaint. Ní mór dúinn droim láimhe a thabhairt don mheon gurb í an teicneolaíocht agus an choincréit an t-aon réiteach atá againn. Caithfimid spás a chruthú do na haibhneacha. Caithfimid a bheith ar aon dul leis an timpeallacht chun réitigh a chur ar fáil. In Éirinn, ní mór d’Oifig na nOibreacha Poiblí ceachtanna na hÍsiltíre a fhoghlaim, áit ina dtuigtear na fadhbanna seo. Ní foláir dúinn dul i ngleic leis an athrú aeráide.

name: Paolo Borchia (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are regions in the Union that have seismic and hydrogeological peculiarities that increase the degree of vulnerability to weather phenomena. Think, for example, of the earthquakes that struck the regions of central Italy or the floods that regularly affect the regions of northern Italy, a tragedy that affected Venice only a few days ago and is still in the eyes of all of us. However, the consequences of meteorological phenomena need different responses from those that Europe has given so far, not least because Italian citizens are perfectly aware that they are net contributors and, as a result, need and expect to have different answers and have expectations of a certain kind. The criteria for access to the European Solidarity Fund, although revised and simplified in 2014, continue to have limits that still slow down the mobilisation of appropriations and also do not exclude the risk that requests for mobilisation may be rejected even in the event of a real disaster. The European Parliament, among other things, has already called on several occasions for the lowering of those access criteria which appear to be contradictory to the emergency nature of the Fund. The timing of the disbursement of appropriations, firstly, given that six weeks of evaluation for the European Commission seems far too long, while the clearance time is too long and causes difficulties for the beneficiary bodies. In conclusion, it is essential to include new indicators that go beyond the mere calculation of damage to GDP, as injuries to people and communities cannot be quantified by percentages alone.

name: Isabel Benjumea Benjumea (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin my speech by condolences and showing my solidarity to the families of both the victims of the earthquake in Albania and the French military killed in Mali in a combat accident. I send you my solidarity and my condolences. Since I arrived in this Parliament, of which I am a Rookie Member, I have just joined in July, there has been no plenary session in which there has been no debate about the environment in which the words 'catastrophe', 'extreme' did not appear, and in which we citizens have not been sent a message of alarm and catastrophic that , honestly, I think it's very exaggerated. Of course we regret to see the images of Venice flooded, and of course we are concerned about how to protect cities that, because of the effects of environmental disasters, see their heritage endangered. But we cannot allow this debate to revolve around the left and be monopolised by the European Parliament every time the environment is talked about, every time there is a debate on the environment, to turn around the left and be monopolised by it, to be raised, and to be catastrophic. We must take out of Parliament that alarmism which is sincerely exaggerated and I think we should focus on what is important, which is to provide real solutions to citizens, real solutions for historical heritage in Europe, and real solutions to prevent and prevent future natural circumstances that will happen, as has always happened.

name: Isabel Carvalhais (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is too clear that the European Union is increasingly confronted with extreme weather phenomena, translated, as we have seen here in these testimonies, in the loss of property, of priceless cultural, material and natural heritage, and also, even worse, in the loss of life.  But I also recall that in 2018 alone, almost 18 million people around the world were forced to move from their homes, precisely because of climate phenomena. Therefore, no one is safe from this reality, as the esteemed colleagues here have illustrated. And, therefore, it is urgent to act.  The Civil Protection Mechanism of the European Union, on which we must urgently think about ways of simplifying its activation, will certainly be important in this fight. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to maintain the principle of subsidiarity in the review of the mechanism, but I recall the need to increase eu co-financing in order to support Member States in better prevention, preparedness and disaster response. Finally, I also call on the Commission to review the conditions for the activation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, stressing that not all regions have the same financial capacity to prevent and respond to crises that can take on huge proportions.

name: Annalisa Tardino (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have all seen the dramatic images of Italy, submerged from north to south, from Licata to Matera to Venice, with prompt reactions from volunteers and civil protection. Today we are here in Strasbourg to ask for the concrete support of the European Union, as we have already done with a written question from the League through the call for the rapid mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund and by unblocking all the economic aid that can be provided. It is also necessary for the affected territories to be able to enjoy the exception of the automatic decommitment of resources from EU funds and for Italy to be given the right flexibility for the money spent on damage caused by natural disasters, especially for the most deficient territories. A Europe that protects its citizens must be present in times of need and must be able to give concrete answers to the real problems, those that citizens expect, immediate help to start building again looking to the future.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, I am truly pleased that this very current topic is on the Agenda of the European Parliament today.  Indeed, climate change and weather extremes are a reality and leave increasing and greater impacts on the economy and on life in the Member States of the European Union as a whole. In particular, as projections suggest, southern and south-eastern Europe and coastal areas, i.e. the Mediterranean coast, are at risk. In addition to Venice, which has suffered this damage of more than 1 billion euros according to the latest estimates, the Republic of Croatia is particularly at risk. In fact, the Republic of Croatia belongs to the three Countries of the European Union that from 1980 to 2015 suffered the greatest damage from weather extremes in the amount of almost three billion euros.  Our coastal towns, our jewels, our treasures, most of which have existed since the Greco-Roman period and later through the Middle Ages, as well as our many islands representing a truly beautiful landscape and a true jewel in the landscape of the European Union are particularly endangered.  I hereby call on the European Union and the European institutions to take all the measures necessary to address this problem, as this is indeed something that Member States cannot address on their own. Subsidiarity is essential, member states' sovereignty is essential, but also the European Union has those instruments that can, based on the Christian principle of solidarity, help those countries in need. There is a regulatory framework where the European Union can do a lot, but there are also all these sources of funding that we mentioned, as well as cohesion policy. I therefore call for solidarity from the States of the European Union, I call for action by the European institutions to address this problem and to show solidarity towards the Member States.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, I come from Croatia, a country proud of its cultural heritage. Croatia has as many as ten protected Unesco sites, mostly located along the Adriatic coast. However, according to a report by the European Environment Agency, Croatia is one of the three European countries with the highest cumulative proportion of damages from extreme weather and climate events in relation to gross national product.  According to a 2017 study, sinking threatens as many as 37 places in the Mediterranean and erosion threatens 42. Among them are the most famous Croatian protected sites such as the Old Town in Dubrovnik, diocletian's palace and the Cathedral of St. James. In addition to cultural heritage, our citizens will be directly threatened because as many as a third of the inhabitants of the European Union live along the coastal zone up to 50 kilometers from the coast.  It is high time to declare a climate crisis and urgently implement measures to reverse global warming trends. Its invaluable cultural heritage has resisted historical calamity for thousands of years. Let's not let it be destroyed by the climate change we caused ourselves.

name: Georg Mayer (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Of course, such weather extremes are always particularly tragic and, of course, dramatic for the people concerned. First of all, we need to provide aid quickly and unbureaucratically. In this sense, we need this European fund and we should now benefit the countries concerned, especially Croatia and Italy, as soon as possible. But the debate here is again remarkably hypocritical, because once again it is climate change that is to blame, it is soon to blame for everything. But when we go within ourselves, we know that natural disasters have always existed and always will exist. We have to live with that. This is a way in which Mother Nature shows us that we do not control this planet. We have to put up with that. However, it is, of course, particularly dramatic in the area of Venice, because it also affects a World Heritage Site, which must of course be saved and is threatened by these constant floods there. However, this is not only the climate change that is causing the problem there, it is also the human being who, by widening the canals for years, so that even larger ships can enter the city, is making sure that, of course, more water can now enter this city. In this sense, protection and aid must be guaranteed, but let us have a more nuanced discussion.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, what we are currently experiencing are truly extreme meteorological phenomena – indeed, across the continent – that are important precisely for urban areas. We experience changes in precipitation models, long-lasting droughts or, on the contrary, thunderstorms and intense rains with subsequent floods, long-lasting high temperatures. These are symptomatic phenomena for almost the entire continent at the moment. In these years we experienced the longest-lasting drought, even in the Czech Republic. I would like to mention that a number of European states are indeed very severely affected. What do we have to do? I think it is the resilience of urban areas in terms of adaptation that will increase. The main objective in dealing with the effects of extreme temperatures is to reduce the vulnerability of human society. Extremely high temperatures lead to a significant deterioration of the indoor environment of buildings, overheating, an increase in air conditioning systems, especially in urban agglomerations. In an urbanised environment, the impact of the so-called thermal island of the city should be prevented or reduced by supporting lower albedo surfaces, increasing, for example, the proportion of vegetation areas with soil, the use of water elements and slower water drainage from the urban environment.  What should be at the centre of our attention as a priority? Increase critical infrastructure protection, adapt buildings to climate change, strengthen ecological stability, ensure flexibility and reliability of the transport sector, and strengthen the development of an integrated rescue system.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, our cultural heritage is more than ancient historical monuments. It’s also the landscape itself and the urban environment. Our towns and cities rely heavily on their cultural heritage as an income generator through tourism. Taking care of our cultural heritage can also improve the quality of life for the local population. We must therefore do our utmost to protect cultural heritage from the effects of extreme meteorological events, which is an increasing threat due to climate change.  A good example of EU action is the Storm Project, which safeguards cultural heritage through the management of technical resources. The Mellor heritage site in my constituency of Stockport, Greater Manchester, is one of the projects to benefit from this innovative EU collaboration. Meanwhile EU cohesion policy continues to provide an important source of funding for cultural heritage of EUR 351.8 billion over the past seven years, and that must continue to be a commitment over the next MFF. Cultural heritage is our common inheritance and it’s our duty to protect and preserve it for future generations.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we still have in our eyes the dramatic images of Venice with high water. For the landslide emergency, territories such as Lombardy, Piedmont and Liguria and many others have been dramatically affected in Italy. Unique places in the world, think of Venice that you all know and that is a World Heritage Site. In Italy there are 600 000 landslides, affecting 7.9 % of the national territory; 91 % of Italian municipalities have at least one area at risk of landslides or floods or floods. Europe does absolutely nothing. The League has tabled an urgent question calling for the immediate mobilisation of the European Solidarity Fund. But it is equally necessary, of course, to be able to spend our money on cleaning up our territory. It is therefore necessary not to take account of expenditure on combating hydrogeological failure in the calculation of the deficit, thus allowing us to use those funds without overshooted the Stability Pact. Only in this way could we finally clean up our Italian territory.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I am convinced that strengthening civil protection in relation to weather-related disasters is one of the most important priorities. Our fundamental task is to mitigate the risks of disasters in accordance with the stand-by framework. When trouble is inevitable, however, all our fellow human men must be informed of the emergency in a timely and appropriate manner. This will also ensure that the protection of urban areas and cultural values will be implemented more effectively in the future. It is very important for everyone to develop an effective and accessible warning system. It is also crucial to get immediate help for those in distress. However, how does a person who is desic or blind or has limited mobility ask for help? I believe that by introducing the technologies and applications currently available, we will make sure that those in distress in all EU countries are informed of emergencies without hindrance and, if necessary, can seek help for themselves or for their fellow human beings.

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too can only address the damage and emergencies that have affected my country and, in particular, the regions of the North-East.  The figures are alarming, but it is worth quoting them again: in Italy we have 6 million citizens at risk of floods, one and a half million at risk of landslides, landslides have been counted in a number of 61 000 – 8 % of Italian territory – and 40 000 cultural goods are at risk. In Emilia Romagna, between 2 and 20 November, there were 17 allertes, many of them with a red level, with 800 interventions by the Fire Brigade and 450 teams of volunteers, whom I thank. In addition to the damage, of course, the administrative aspects are added together. On the small and medium-scale projects that are lagging behind, work will have to be done mainly at national level. Europe has done so far, it has not turned the other way, because with the Solidarity Fund Italy has obtained 2.5 billion since 2002. We are now calling for one more step, as Article 11 of the Treaty on European Union says: that environmental protection be integrated into all European Structural Funds, in particular the Regional Development Fund and the Rural Development Fund. This is the next step.

name: Francesca Donato (ID).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of recent climate changes which are causing more and more frequent atmospheric phenomena of exceptional violence in our territories and also of frequent seismic events, given that in many European countries there are urban centres of very high historical and artistic interest for the whole Union, some of which are geographically more exposed to the risks of serious damage caused by bad weather and earthquakes – I remember for Italy Venice , Matera, but also the city of L'Aquila – I believe that the logic proposed by the European Commission of an approach that is no longer just emergency for the protection of Europe's historical and cultural heritage is correct. In concrete terms, I think that we must intervene ex ante for the safety of these sites, first of all by carrying out a census of these sites, on the recommendation of each Member State, and by creating a ranking of the most important and at-risk locations, and then to have the appropriate studies on the interventions necessary to prevent environmental and seismic damage, quantifying their costs and execution times. On this basis, a strategic safeguard plan, a European initiative, must be implemented, to be financed from the funds we already have for cohesion, the environment and infrastructure. Only with such a global project can the European Union really protect its cultural, historical and artistic heritage.

name: Lucia Vuolo (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Venice is certainly the most striking case, but I could mention Matera, in Basilicata, and other cities in Campania and the South. Landslides, landslides, flooding, collapses of viaducts, crops being lost and unfortunately victims. From 2014 to 2018, Italy suffered severe weather damage of 8 billion euros. Europe, through the Solidarity Fund, has helped our beautiful country with EUR 740 million. Aid, but also delays. In September 2019 alone, one year after the calamitous events in the North East of Italy, the Commission released 277 million euros. Italy, however, is not just bad weather. Unfortunately it is also earthquakes, as in Molise, Abruzzo, Calabria and Emilia-Romagna. Damage of EUR 2.5 billion. This is an extremely concise and dramatic picture which will not improve in the future. Italy, because of its immense cultural heritage, needs more than all speed in granting this type of funds. We have asked for this as an ID Group, and I repeat this personally here in plenary. I also call for greater constraints on funds aimed at maintaining existing infrastructure.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Violent atmospheric phenomena, unfortunately, are increasingly becoming a challenge that we have to face. The situation in Venice, which has been closely followed by the whole of Europe in recent days, has shown us very clearly how important it is to ensure adequate protection against such events. That is why it is so essential to develop an appropriate adaptation strategy for climate change and to provide the necessary infrastructure to protect or reduce the negative effects of such phenomena. I would therefore like to remind you that the European Regional Development Fund, which is currently under negotiation with the Council and the Commission, provides, among other things, the possibility of financing actions that adapt our regions to climate change and increase their resilience to natural disasters. However, in order for these measures to be effective, it is necessary to ensure that it has a sufficiently high budget, which I hope will be taken into account in setting the final amount of cohesion policy appropriations.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A report published in April this year by the European Environment Agency indicates that over the last 20 years all Member States, including my country, Poland, have suffered the greatest losses of tens of billions of euros as a result of floods. However, recent deeply moving events, images of flooded Venice clearly show that despite these many experiences and warnings, we are still not well prepared in Europe for the consequences of extreme weather events. Member States alone are not able to effectively counteract the effects of the elements on their own. As a result, not only our priceless cultural heritage, but also our human life, is at risk. With this in mind, I believe that the new committee should activate additional resources and coordinate appropriate action at Union level to minimise the negative effects of floods and storms in the future. I am pleased that the Commissioner's announcements are going in this direction.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think that the fact that Polish's representatives are speaking in this application procedure is such a symptomatic sign, because there is a Polish word, but the word that the whole world knows, that word is 'solidarity', and I think that on this subject where we are now sitting, the key word should be the word 'solidarity'. Today we are all with the people of Tirana, with the people of Albania affected by the earthquake. Yesterday we were with the people of Venice, before we were with the people of Sweden. And here I also have such a personal thread, when, at the invitation of MEP Czesław Hoc, as Minister of the Interior and Administration here in Strasbourg, I opened an exhibition illustrating precisely this Polish solidarity, when Polish firefighters came to Sweden with help. It seems that we should also look today at those who, in these extreme situations, are always at the side of the citizens: firefighters, the police, the medical services – and we should support them, as representatives of the European Parliament.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, meteorological catastrophes are not a left- wing alarmist plot, as one of the speakers suggested. They are sadly a reality for the people of Venice; they are a reality for the victims in Albania who tragically lost their lives; they are a reality for the citizens of Portrane, a coastal village in Dublin where I come from, where chunks of land have fallen into the sea, even today. Where residents watched earlier this year to see their house falling into the sea and months later remain unhoused in that area. Climate experts say that Ireland is already overdue a catastrophic storm surge of up to 3 metres at a nationwide cost and damage to property alone of EUR 1 billion.   Now governments and the European Union need to be ahead of the curve on this. We urgently need disaster-relief preparedness and we need a long-term strategy, mitigating coastal erosion. Our government seems to be incapable of that, kicking the can between the local authority and the government. We, on a European basis, need to come together and to deal with what is a meteorological catastrophe.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The consequence of climate change is hurricanes, floods, droughts, avalanches, but above all human tragedies. With each year there are fewer and fewer days with snowfall and more and more hot days. This has an impact on human health and creates costs for the economy and agriculture. Extreme weather events are destroying our homes and threatening our cultural heritage. Increasing droughts are causing millions of people to migrate. We must be aware that existing systems such as Copernicus and funds such as the European Union Solidarity Fund make it possible to warn about natural disasters or to remove their effects, but they do not prevent them. Without the fight against climate change, without knowing that not only is Europe to bear the costs, but the whole world, led by large corporations, is committed to fighting global warming and emissions, without thinking about responsibility for future generations, we will increasingly remove the effects, bear increasing costs and mourn more and more victims.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, disasters are, as we know, deeply unjust: they almost always affect those who have less to protect themselves, whether they are people or states. If there is an area in which solidarity in the European Union and the principle of cohesion should have a visible expression, it is that of protecting the population, the economy and the environment from disasters. The problem of disasters has already been the subject of resolutions by this Parliament on several occasions. It is necessary to follow up due to the recommendations and to pass them on to practice. This is the case with the creation of a financial framework appropriate to disaster prevention which allows, among other measures, the correction of risk-inducing situations. Unfortunately, very little has been done and the European Commission has particular responsibility for this delay. For us, a Community approach to disaster prevention should include, as a central concern, the reduction of disparities between regions and Member States in this area, in particular by helping to improve prevention in regions and Member States with high risk exposure and lower economic capacity.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, respected Commissioner Stylianides, two years ago there were large fires in Split, a city celebrating this year 40 years since its entry on the World Heritage List as one of the first monuments included by the Republic of Croatia on this prestigious list.
