Thanks to the work of this Parliament, thanks also to you Mr. Stylianides who came and with whom we worked together, our people's party has achieved an improved civil protection mechanism, now it has an instrument where we can prevent the damage that is happening as well as in Paris, and in Venice, Venice to the city of beauty that caused Unesco to also set up its office to control meteorological changes.  I call on this Parliament to support my initiative to declare a European Fire Protection Day and this Parliament to start using the civil protection instrument of the enhanced mechanism that is working so hard and for which we have enabled funds to be allocated and now to use this instrument as much as possible to make these prestigious places such as Split, such as Venice and Paris forever protected and preserved for generations to come.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for this really very productive discussion. I would like to say that, once again, recent events in Venice show us that climate change is real, is happening now and is not fake news.  So, at the same time, we need two approaches: a strategic approach called the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and, of course, prevention and preparedness. What we tried to do in the former Commission was what Ms Zovko has already said, rescEU, and thank you so much for your kind words. Yes, we tried to establish and to upgrade the European civil protection mechanism through rescEU in order to deal with natural disasters efficiently and effectively. But we have only taken one first step. We need more and more. So it’s your responsibility, as the European Parliament, to go beyond, as we have already done as the former Commission.  Thank you so much for your support. It is a common achievement, but my sincere advice, through the last five years of experience, is that you have to go beyond the first step in the rescEU field. Otherwise, we will face a lot of problems because the new phenomena due to climate change is so complicated and complex. Nobody can deal with this phenomena alone because it is so complicated. At the same time, many of you already insist on solidarity. Yes, solidarity is the fundamental principle for our Union and this is why, now, some rescue teams, through the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, are running and are in action in Albania in order to save lives. I’m really proud of these institutions because the European Union can provide solidarity in very difficult circumstances.  At the same time, I would like to take this opportunity to say more about our EU initiatives that will help us address the challenge over the years to come. First, disaster risk management is vital, in particular for our cohesion policy. Local and regional authorities are the first to face the impact of disasters. Investing in risk management is cost-effective; it prevents future losses and it contributes to sustainable development. Over the period 2014-2020, cohesion policy is investing almost EUR 2 billion in climate change adaptation and risk prevention. As I said, prevention is the main focus of our investment, with actions to improve the modelling of risk, early warning systems, the preparation of strategies and guidelines, etc. In this period we have also seen a large focus on green infrastructure to manage risks. Furthermore, under the Urban Agenda for the European Union, the Partnership on Climate Adaptation coordinated by the City of Genoa is implementing ten actions to anticipate climate change and take appropriate measures to prevent or minimise the damage it can cause to urban areas. The Commission has also launched the European Natural Hazard Scientific Partnership, a network of scientific European institutions and international organisations that monitor natural hazards. They are ready 24/7 to support the European Commission and our Emergency Response Coordination Centre. Besides prevention, we also focus on preparedness with support for equipment, infrastructure and training of civil protection units. We offer flexibility in our programmes. Programme amendments can be proposed and swiftly agreed to shift resources towards areas that are most in need. So, if changes need to be made, we can still do this within this funding period. The second point is that we are promoting initiatives to mitigate the impact of climate change on cultural heritage. That is in particular the case with the support of the Horizon 2020 Programme with climate action, mitigating the impacts of climate change and natural hazards on cultural heritage. At the initiative of the Commission, 27 European countries agreed to work closely together to advance the digitisation of Europe’s cultural heritage in a Declaration of Cooperation launched in April 2019.   The Commission has also been funding the use of digital technologies for the preservation and restoration of cultural heritage. The latest initiative includes a future European Competence Centre for the preservation and conservation of European cultural heritage by using ICT technologies, under Horizon 2020 once again. The intersection between cultural heritage and climate change has also been under the spotlight during the European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018 with the report ‘Safeguarding cultural heritage from natural and man-made disasters’.  In the same vein, the European Framework for Action on Cultural Heritage includes a focus on protecting cultural heritage against natural disasters and climate change. In 2021, a group of experts from EU Member States will analyse and share innovative policy measures for heritage sites to mitigate the impact of climate change. With the support, of course, of Horizon 2020, the Commission is investing some EUR 18 million in this field.  So the list of what the European Union is doing to protect our communities against the disastrous impact of natural disasters, but also to preserve our cultural heritage, is long. No doubt much more remains to be done. I know and am sure that we can count on your support and your initiatives in order to be more effective and more efficient.  Thank you so much for your attention and for this very constructive discussion.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Commission's statement on public discrimination and hate speech against LGBTI people, including LGBTI-free zones (2019/2933(RSP)).

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this opportunity to speak to you about the development in Poland, as regards the LGBTI community.  I would like to express my strong concerns on this. As you know, the European Commission has been closely monitoring the developments and the accounts of recent events that have reached to the Commission are very worrying.  Particularly last July an equality march organised in the Polish city of Białystok that was intended to be peaceful was met with an avalanche of verbal and physical violence and hate speech directed at the participants. LGBT free zone stickers were distributed by a Polish newspaper. Moreover, several Polish regional and local authorities have adopted declarations, statements or resolutions, banning LGBTI community postulates as an ideology, and declaring their territories ‘LGBT unwelcome’. All this is occurring in a climate of rising anti-LGBTI rhetoric in the run-up to the Polish parliamentary election that took place last month. The European Commission strongly condemns these developments. Any form of discrimination, intolerance or violence based on sexual orientation, gender identity or sex characteristics, goes against the fundamental values of the European Union that are founded in Article II of the Treaty. In addition, Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which has the same legal values as the Treaties, prohibits any discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and sex. Some of the Polish authorities that have adopted anti-LGBTI resolutions, declarations or statements, are managing authorities or beneficiaries of operational programmes supported by the EU Structural and Investment Funds, and on 23 October this year, the Commission met with Polish authorities in the framework of an annual review meeting of the regional operational programmes that are financed or co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund and we stressed the need to respect EU law, including the Charter, in the implementation of these programmes, particularly the principle of non-discrimination. By issuing anti-LGBTI resolutions, declarations or statements, Polish managing authorities and beneficiaries of the EU Structural Investment Funds raise doubts of their ability to ensure respect of the Charter. The Commission will continue to monitor the situation in Poland, and we will engage with Poland to make sure incidents of this kind never happen again. Discrimination, violence and hate speech against the LGBTI community must be stopped in the European Union.  Thank you very much for this possibility to have the debate. I’m looking forward to your questions.

name: Magdalena Adamowicz
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The darkest times are back in politics again. Again, he divides societies, inventing enemies, scaring non-existant threats. The mechanism is simple and old as the world: indicate a characteristic – let it be religion, skin color, sexual orientation or affluence. Then i abed, come up with uncreated lies. Arouse fear and hatred. And finally, show yourself as the only savior before this imaginary evil. This is how populists, nationalists and Nazis work. We must stop them hard, because at the end of this road there is death, civil and religious wars, extermination camps. This is what leads to the sowing of hatred.  Today, the blade of hatred of the rulers and their henchmen has turned to non-heteronormative people. A new enemy was invented – it was called LGBT ideology. It's just that there's no such thing. These people are trying to convince us that homosexuality is contagious, that if we tell children in school that there are gays and lesbians in the world, then these children will give up their heterosexuality. Unbelievable, but it works and hatred grows, a wave of hate crimes based on sexual orientation is intensifying.  The rulers ban sex education, because in a conscious society they would lose the cretes with their hateful propaganda. Hatred and homophobic hate speech kills. Recent research shows that in Poland about 70% of LGBT teenagers have suicidal thoughts and half have symptoms of depression. Let us stand behind the most important values – not only European, but human in general. Human dignity is a universal value. Every person is entitled equally, regardless of race, religion, age, religion, nationality or sexual orientation. Human dignity is man's most precious good, natural and inviolable law. No individual, no group, no power or state, just no one, can change that, much less endure it.  There is no such thing as "LGBT ideology." Non-heteronormative people are ordinary, normal people, who have dignity and respect on an equal footing with everyone else, unconditionally, just like us and everyone else.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. Homophobia in Poland is spreading as a disease, and I welcome the activists from Poland who are with us today, and with whom we are struggling to hear their cry for help. Representatives of the LGBTI community are increasingly subject to hateful words and actions because they are simply increasingly tolerated and tolerated in public, cultural and political discourse. It is a shame that in Poland, almost 90 local communities have declared areas liberated from LGBTI ideology. Young people are suffering, suicides are on the rise, such intolerable decisions reflect the ubiquitous climate in a country of which it is working hard to suppress the right to freedom of choice of a partner and the right to abortion. And here I point the finger at the Polish organization Ordo iuris. But it does not end with Poland, inadequate reactions from the authorities in Hungary, in the wake of homophobic violence, of the growing verbal and physical attacks on LGBTI members of the community reported from Germany, the United Kingdom, Finland, Lithuania, and also the honey, unfortunately, not too far from home, and recently we have seen another attack on the LGBTI club in Ljubljana. And how anyone dares to interfere with people's lives just because they love differently. When, as a society, we realize that embracing diversity and diversity is what makes us stronger. Homophobia, discrimination and hate speech have no place in my Europe, so I call on all of us, the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council, to condemn once and for all the violence against the LGBTI community throughout Europe and commit ourselves to efforts to increase their legal protection.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, incidentally, I note that the Council is absent; that part of the House is also absent, while it is largely about them. But clearly they have got more important things to do. The Polish government party, Law and Justice, how ironic, is calling LGBTI people a threat to the Polish identity, the Polish nation and the Polish state. It has actually declared LGBTI people to be an enemy of the people and it is proposing, or encouraging, LGBTI- free zones. In the meantime, indeed as Tanja Fajon has said, 70 villages and cities have declared to be an LGBTI free zone. Difference – that is not just discrimination. There is a word for this policy. If you want to eliminate, erase a whole part of the population, there is a word for that, I am not going to name it here. It is not just discrimination and we should go much further than just condemning it; it is a violation of human rights and a violation of international law and it has no place in the European Union, it has to stop.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the map that I’m holding up here is a map of Poland, and you can see the areas of Poland where LGBT free zones have been declared by the local councils.  Imagine for one moment you are growing up in one of these regions as a young gay, lesbian or transperson. You are already lost. As it stands, being a teenager is never easy, and especially not if you’re LGBTI. You probably have a lot of questions, some of which you might not want to discuss with your parents, but in your school you cannot discuss it with anyone because your teachers are not supposed to talk to you about this. Then your city council unanimously approves a motion that states that you are against the law of nature. That the way you love, or the way that you are is threatening so-called Christian morality and family. How would you feel? Alone, abandoned, scared.  Already LGBTI youth are at the highest risk of attempting or committing suicide inside of the European Union. These declarations are fuelling a problem that has already cost far too much hardship in European families, and we here in this Parliament we have to be the voice telling these young people - you are not alone, you are not wrong, you might be different, but that’s okay. You have rights and we, as the European Union, will stand up and defend them here in this Parliament, and we are there for you. We cannot accept such an attack on European values and fundamental rights in this Union and this is why more than this resolution that we have to adopt, we have to make this part of the Article 7 procedure against Poland because this is going beyond anything that the European Union stands for.  And lastly, I was raised and baptised as a Roman Catholic. The Jesus that I learned about in my church, was not preaching hatred, he was preaching the exact opposite. He was not telling his followers to go with pitchforks against anyone who is different. He was preaching love, and we should bring exactly the same to the people who are marginalised today, and not use our Christianity against them (applause). So please, let’s stand up for these young LGBTI people in Poland.

name: Maximilian Krah
text: on behalf of the ID Group. – Madam President, I’m wondering that we speak about hate speech against gay people but now I have the impression we speak about hate on Poland. The Polish nation is worth that it decides themselves how it organises its lives and we thank the Polish nation a lot. They brought us freedom against the communists and they now give us a new hope in Europe for a conservative approach in government. I understand that you are very upset with Poland as they voted for a Conservative government and I’m not surprised that you attack now the Polish nation for something which is not okay and which has to be defeated, but which is not a problem of the Polish State or the Polish people but it’s a problem of the police and the justice authorities in Poland. You use something which I don’t support to blame the whole nation of Poland and this is something which is the greater problem and the larger problem. I want to say for my Group, we stand with Poland and we think that the Polish authorities are smart enough to tackle that problem, but I don’t agree that you attack Poland, its tradition and its pride. God bless Poland and I’m sure that Poland is self-confident enough to not get impressed by your words of hate against this state in Europe.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8)

name: Silvia Modig (GUE/NGL)
text: blue card question. – Mr Krah, this is not about hate speech towards Poland. This is about defending the human rights of sexual and gender minorities. You said that Poland has the right to decide for itself what it is doing. Do you really think that we can decide which points on human rights we respect and which points we do not? Human rights are a whole that concerns us all. If the human rights of one of us are trampled under, then human rights and the human rights of all of us, including yours, will be trampled under way.

name: Maximilian Krah (ID)
text: blue-card answer. – It is binding the public authorities; that is the first thing. If we are in a relationship between two private persons, then both have the liberty to express their opinions and their concerns. The State is only asked to interfere if violence is in the game or if the law is violated.  The point is that what you are doing here is that you are attacking the Republic of Poland and the authorities for something that happened because of a private organisation or the misbehaviour of an individual. That is the reason why I think that you are attacking the State of Poland, because you dislike the conservative government, and use misbehaviour and maybe criminal acts of private individuals. And that is not acceptable. For misbehaviour and laws broken in Poland, the Polish police are responsible and Polish courts have to pass sentence. It is not a matter for which the European Parliament has to ask for sanctions to be imposed on the Republic of Poland. This is unacceptable and is an attack on the sovereignty of Poland.

name: Beata Kempa
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Let's talk about the facts. Lgbt activists have made their strongest weapon out of provocation. During their numerous marches in Poland, there were often acts of discrimination and blatant violation of the religious feelings of millions of Christians. Insult, desecration, attempt to desecrate perhaps the most sacred image for Christians, which is the image of the Mother of God. Isn't that discrimination and hate speech? After all, such acts encourage further brutal attacks on Christians, attacks on priests, the lioning of symbols sacred to Catholics. It is important to know that in 2018 only there were 1063 of them in France. Why did Parliament not have the courage to debate this?  The "LGBT-Free Zone" sticker was published after an Ikea employee was kicked out of his job, quoting the Scriptures when he refused to participate in an action in support of LGBT pride month, even though he had a full constitutional right to do so. The newspaper that published the sticker became the subject of censorship and persecution. Kiosks were raided, vendors and journalists were intimidated. There has not been such a wave of persecution in Poland since 1989. So let us talk in the European Parliament about the scale of hate, about the scale of your hatred.  Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The High Parliament, i would like to thank you for your comments. I am in favour of mutual respect, because everyone has dignity. But you can not remain silent when the aggressive ideology of minorities, demanding privileges for themselves on the banners, at the same time vilifys those who have a different opinion. Please take this into account. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Róża Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, I would like to ask whether criticising the government in Poland and criticising the letters close to the government are partly co-financed by citizens' and promoted taxes, or is this an anti-Polish action? Because here I see a few Poles and Poles who feel attacked by this monstrous action discriminating against environments that are clearly in the minority in Poland.  Secondly, we are also Catholics in this Chamber and the use of the rainbow does not offend Catholics. Decorating the halo of our Lady with a rainbow of very many Catholics does not offend in Poland, and I would ask you not to use such words relating to attacks, brutality, sacrilege and so on, because this is simply not true when it comes to Polish society.  I am sorry that this debate is turned into a Polish-Polish debate, but we must from time to time straighten out this false image of Poles, which the ruling party gives us here. I would like to know if this is the official position of the ruling party, which has just been delivered by an MEP, a former minister from that party?

name: Beata Kempa (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Dear MEP, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I want to make it clear that many Christians actually sit here, but we know very well that faith must not be relativised. And it must not be the case that next to this rainbow, which you have said, and the image of Our Lady and her coronation, it is already more than 300 years since the coronation of the image. It wasn't there, and I don't remember – and I've been living 53 three years in the world – that there was a rainbow in that image. It was a blatant provocation. And the second thing. If the image of Our Lady at one of the events in Gdansk is placed in the background of a vagina, how is it not discrimination against Christians? It is a pity that this is the Polish-Polish War here. I am ashamed of her, but we are not calling her.

name: Malin Björk
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is not a debate on Poland, but it is a debate about what is happening in Poland right now. What is going on is no longer a form of discrimination, as a colleague said earlier here, but it is persecution. We have local and regional representatives and parliaments who adopt declarations and programmes when they talk about 'LGBTQ-free zones' and state that only Christian, heterosexual couples should be allowed to exist. I quote in English: We express our disapproval and disagreement for attempts to promote LGBT ideology, which is against natural law and against our long traditional values and our Christian morality.   This is, to me, a form of persecution. In particular, these anti-LGBTQ forces want to use school as an institution and ban it from promoting the human rights of LGBTQ people or young people's right to free sexuality. I think that most people in here and most people who listen to us at home also understand how dangerous it is for many of us when public representatives and parliaments pronounce and then legitimise a type of hatred and a type of oppression like this. It's simply lethal. Instead of being a safe place for all young people, school is transformed into a dangerous place. What comes after this? Witch burning? Persecution of non-believers? I really hope not! It's time to stop. To my LGBTQ siblings from Poland – some of you are sitting up here – I just want to say: you are not alone, we will stand with you, and together we will push back these forces.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 'united in diversity', this is the motto of the European Union but, decades later, we find ourselves in this House having to defend the fundamental rights of citizens, rights that should be universally recognised. Perhaps the extreme right would like to rewrite the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adding that these rights apply to many, but not to everyone. Today, we are even talking about 'LGBTI free zones', tomorrow we may not recognise the rights of those who have blond hair, those who are women, those who are so tall. History seems to repeat itself, but it repeats itself in the darkest pages of our history. Do you remember the concept of Judendfrei? Are we preparing for a new Nazism? The drift that events are taking is alarming, the climate of hatred can be touched with one's hand. You hate anyone who is different, by race, by religion, by nationality, by sexual orientation. But these are excuses, they are excuses used by those who want to channel this hatred for propaganda purposes. I ask myself: is this the Europe we want? Is this the future we want for us and our children? That is certainly not what I want and I ask all of you in this House today to send out a strong and clear message: attacks and restrictions on anyone's fundamental rights will not be tolerated! We want to rewrite history, but good history!

name: Maria Walsh (PPE).
text: – Madam President, everyone, regardless of who they are, their skin colour, their creed, their orientation, their language, has the right to dignity and respect, to be treated like everyone else, to have their basic human rights acknowledged and respected. What we are talking about today and what we are hearing is happening in our European Union. This is not just a question about policy. It is a direct assault on human rights.  Hate crime undermines the inclusiveness of our society. When we talk about LGBTQI rights, we can recall how much has been achieved, in my own country of Ireland in particular. But what we are discussing today, what we are hearing, reminds us we cannot be complacent. We need to defend what has been achieved. The promotion and protection of rights of LGBTQI persons is explicit in all EU policy. And, unfortunately, there is strong evidence that hate speech and discrimination is still a reality for many of our communities and we need to take action together.  We need all our politicians to make it clear that we cannot and we will not tolerate any hate speech or discrimination. We need our institutions, such as our criminal justice systems to be able to take action against hate speech and discriminations. And finally, we need EU institutions to take action. This kind of discrimination has clear cross-border dimensions and it is a fundamental challenge to the values of our EU and our Member States. Finally, to my colleague sitting to the right: I’m a pioneer. I’m an LGBTQI person. I’m a practising Catholic. I am Irish and I am European and no one has the right to tell me where I should live and how I should live.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I’ve got news for Mr Krah and Ms Kempa: LGBTI people exist in Poland, they exist in your town, they exist on your street. And they have every right to be proud of their country like you are, they have every right to be a part of the community like you are, and you have no right whatsoever to exclude them. The other week we had to listen to a long and tedious rant from Mr Legutko about how social engineering was occurring in the European Union on a scale that you would find in communist countries. You would think that someone who bravely fought communism would be aware of the grim irony that under communism LGBTI people were persecuted against and, in some cases, executed. The words that we use in this place matter. It is important that we recognise the hatred that is out there. The rise in homophobic attacks across the European Union, and the fact that in Poland since the start of 2019, 87 localities have declared themselves to be LGBT-free. I’ve got news for you: they’re not LGBT-free, and we stand with the people in those communities. But I wish to ask the Commission: since 2009 Lithuania has had a law which is being used to censor and silence LGBTI. The LGBT+ organisation LGL appealed to the Commission, saying that Lithuania was in breach of its fundamental obligations under EU law. What is the Commission’s response to this? When will action be taken? And can we expect LGBTI rights to be a fundamental part of upholding the values of this place which we hold so dear, and which are clearly under attack from people in this very room. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 171(8))

name: Beata Kempa (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab I hope that the Lord listened well to my speech. And please show me at which point in this speech I refused people with a different sexual preference the right to live on my street or in my city.  I will tell you more, I know such persons, and I believe that every such person has human dignity and this dignity must be respected. Just those people with different preferences that I know do not shout and take part in demonstrations where they offend Christians. And I did not refuse in any of my statements the right to cohabitation. This is the first basic thing, so please don't tell me that. I am a supporter of the truth.

name: Maximilian Krah (ID)
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned that in Communist states, in Communist countries, homosexuals would be persecuted, and sometimes face the death sentence. I grew up in Communist East Germany, and I would ask you, can you tell me in which Communist country in Eastern Europe homosexuality was prohibited by law? Or was that just Socialist fake news that you offered to the plenary?

name: Seb Dance (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – There’s a lot of denial going on in this place. Ms Kempa, first of all, your question. This is a debate. If you read the title there: ‘public discrimination and hate speech against LGBTI people, including LGBTI-free zones’. You might have used the opportunity to speak in this debate to condemn the fact that many authorities in Poland are saying they are LGBTI-free zones, instead of some nauseating rant about the Virgin Mary and the use of the rainbow flag. But that’s your choice. You use your time in this Chamber as you see fit. However, don’t tell me that you weren’t insinuating that somehow the LGBT+ community is not an adversary of the Polish people. That is entirely what you insinuated in your remarks. Mr Krah, are you seriously suggesting to me that communism didn’t persecute LGBTI people? Are you seriously suggesting to me that the Soviet Union, for example, did not have a systematic programme of exterminating gay men? Are you seriously suggesting that what we see today in Chechnya is not a legacy of what happened? I would think that the people who have their very identity as having fought communism – as they so proudly say in debate after debate, after debate – would be aware of the history of their own continent and not try and twist and have this disgusting, ironic attack on gay people as somehow being a symptom of the rebirth of communism. it is appalling and it erases history and you should be ashamed of yourself.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the truth is that I did not think that we would have to talk about this in 2019 in the European Parliament. It is that we have had a Charter of Fundamental Rights since 2000. And the Charter of Fundamental Rights provides for human dignity and sexual orientation freely. And there is rhetoric and there are some prejudices in some of the things that have been heard here today. None of us are against Poland, but it is not particular who are encouraging indecent rhetoric from the point of view that it believes that those who have a sexual orientation that is not conventional or majority in Poland have to live in secret, or cannot provoke, or cannot make manifestations. We may or may not like them, but they have the right to free manifestation and free sexual orientation. And anyone who doesn't understand this doesn't understand that sexual freedom shouldn't be secret. One of the people who have formulated these spaces without LGBT ideology, Kaczy-ski is against ideological pluralism, freedom of conscience. This is what is currently at risk in the European Union. And this is what we have to understand. We have to look, very inside, at what is going on with freedom of conscience to understand that there are indeed people who manifest themselves and are LGBT. Well, it manifests itself.

name: Alice Kuhnke (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is sad and upsetting that we need to devote time to this debate, and that it is so clearly a homophobic development in one of the EU's own Member States, in Poland. Hatred of LGBTQ people cannot be accepted and must never be normalised. That is why the Polish Government must stop fuelling hatred and threats against LGBTQ people.  I am convinced that the majority of Poles are not homophobes. I am equally convinced that the political forces that are driving homophobia do so for their own benefit.  I demand that the Commission, the present and the future, clearly dissociate itself from the push for homophobic policies. I also demand that the Commission, the present and the future, stand up for the right of all people to live free lives and love whomever they want. That the EU sees it between its fingers when human rights are being violated – it is unworthy of the EU.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the far left, again, brings us here a debate in which we all essentially agree, which is that we are against violence against anyone. But by taking advantage of that rational consensus, they will want to put us through the hoop of their prejudices and their own resentments. Nothing says the left of anti-Semitism and anti-Catholicism, or the hatred they distill in their own speeches in this Parliament to those who do not think like them.  Yesterday, in Spain, a newspaper that you will know—The Country—turned a propaganda tool—kept an article that read "heterosexuality is dangerous" and its author demanded that women carry weapons to confront men. That's hate speech, too. Why, you, there's only one hatred you care about and other hates you're not interested in? Do you have anything to say left of it? Do you have anything to say to the left of the general criminalisation of the male in Europe? Look, I agree to fight hate speech. But everyone, not just the ones you're going to impose on us. The left cannot tell Europeans what to think or how we should live.

name: Silvia Modig (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in my country, Finland, next week we will celebrate Independence Day and then we will always be asked: What does independence mean to you? I answer it every year the same way. It means freedom. Freedom to live freely as yourself without fear of discrimination, fearing harassment, without fear of hatred. That is what I would like to see for every European to mean Europeanism. Freedom to live as yourself without anyone else coming forward to tell you how you have the right to express yourself and what you get to do.  Mr Kempa said here earlier that homosexuals, too, have the right to a dignified life, as long as they do not cross a certain line. Who is the one who can set limits on how he gets his life to live?  The most grotesque thing about this homophobic debate is that positions are justified by the abuse of homosexual youth and the increased risk of suicide. It's not because he's gay. It is because of the rhetoric and attitudes that we have heard in this Chamber as well. My friends, being gay isn't a choice, but homophobes are.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am speaking as a Polish woman on behalf of millions of Poles who want to live in a country where there is mutual respect and tolerance. I am speaking on behalf of mothers crying after losing their children who took their own lives because they could not stand the hate speech caused by having a different sexual orientation. I am speaking on behalf of Poles who cannot accept that the prosecutor is discontinuing the trial against those who hung portraits of MEPs on the gallows. I speak as a Catholic who has no mouth full of commandments only for political purposes, but who tries to live according to the decalogue, and one of the commandments says, "Love your neighbor as yourself."  I ask you, in the 21st century, to understand history and remember what hatred has led to, which led to the creation of jewish-free zones in Nazi Germany, for example. This story is bloody and tragic and may it never happen again.  Nor can I agree, as a former self-governing person, as an open person, that anyone in any country adopt resolutions that create places free of any social group. We should react. No modern country should agree to hejt, actions and hate speech. Tolerance should be the cornerstone of any modern state and modern society. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I wanted to ask you a question, because you speak very nicely in terms of values and, in general, what can you agree with. However, as we are in a serious chamber, I would like to ask for details. Can you point out at this time a specific case (documented) where the activities of a member of the Polish government led to the suicide of an LGBT person. Specifically. That was the first question. And secondly, please give me information – since you mentioned hanging politicians in quotes, of course – why, as your party ruled in Poland and at the marches organised by you, the president of the current ruling party was hung, then the prosecutor's office did nothing?

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Firstly, dear my dear, I have not said anywhere that the taking of a life by a person of different sexual orientation was the result of direct government action, that was a consequence of hate speech, hate speech, hate speech, and also in schools. That is, someone does not react to such phenomena and actions. However, I always regret, no matter who governs, what government, when there is no response to actions that are unacceptable in a modern country in the 21st century, no matter who they are, whether minorities, politics or ordinary people.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D)
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am Polish and in 2019 there are places in my homeland, in the heart of Europe, that I cannot enter. There are shops, restaurants, hotels that I can not enter. For 43 years I have lived in a country where people like me use words like "homoterror", "promotion of homosexuality", "LGBT ideology". It is possible to promote apples in the supermarket, not homosexuality. If we can promote anything in this House, if anything we can promote as politicians, it is tolerance, acceptance and respect for others. Imagine that on this board instead of "LGBT people" would be written "Jews", "Catholics", "Poles". Everyone in this House would agree that we need to act. When lgbt is involved and hate speech is used, part of this room applauds. In 2019 in the temple of European democracy. And that's a shame. It is a shame for us that we have led to this.  If anything we can do – and Here I am turning to the new Commission and the new Council – then we must adopt a law that treats everyone equally, introduce an anti-discrimination directive, prepare a strategy for LGBT people, protect everyone equally throughout Europe. Then such zones will never again be and such embarrassing debates will never again be.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Honourable Member, as if you were polite to give concrete examples of shops that you cannot enter in Poland.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Yes, of course. There is a whole list of such places. Welcome. Yesterday, for example, an article appeared in many Polish newspapers. One of the restaurants in Krakow hung another sticker on its door yesterday, one of several hundred that hang on the doors of such shops, restaurants, places where people like me today in a symbolic way, but perhaps soon according to the law, will not be able to enter. (The speaker agreed to answer another question raised by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Beata Kempa (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, very specifically, which shop and which hotel? Because you see, ideology very often uses generalities, tries to make an impression that exacerbates an imaginary problem, and I want to know, this is a serious chamber, this is a serious debate, which shop and which hotel. Secondly, you must acknowledge that the Government of the Republic of Poland and the police during the LGBT march in Bialystok, which was calculated for about a thousand people, protected this march, there were more than seven hundred, nearly eight hundred police men, and waited a few days for those who may have suffered to come forward. Apparently there was no problem with it. Police have even released images of people who may have used hate speech. Please provide specifics.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Unfortunately, we can find many of these specifics on the Internet. In five seconds I found the first example. Unfortunately, we will do them an advertisement. The Green Cafe at Stolarska Street in Krakow had such a sticker. But in a few seconds you can find many such addresses in Poland, where LGBT people can not enter. And I am surprised, ladies and gentlemen, that with such energy and zeal you are defending a situation in which a group of citizens from your homeland is humiliated and ridiculed. If anyone ever had the idea to treat right-wing people, Catholics, Poles, anyone in this way, I would stand first in your defense. Therefore, stand on the side of good. Stand on the side of respect for others. You still have a chance to rehabilitate during this debate. It's not over yet.

name: Anna Júlia Donáth (Renew).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Despite the positive change in attitudes of Europe's society towards LGBTI communities, we have once again come to the point where they need protection not only from a few extremist groups. Today, political groups with real power again, and in many cases the governments of EU Member States, see LGBTI communities as the next enemy image against which society can be teased in the hope of electoral success. While LGBTI-free zones are introduced in some municipalities in Poland, this is part of government rhetoric in Hungary. For example, the Speaker of the Hungarian Parliament has called rainbow families who want to adopt children a paedophile. These can happen anywhere if we do not take decisive countermeasures and show where the border is finally. Do not wait for LGBTI-free zones to spread in Hungary or other European countries. I am therefore pleased that the European Commission strongly condemns what is happening in Poland, but monitoring and dialogue are not enough. Meanwhile, those affected live in fear. I would like to ask if we could possibly suggest that we include this in the Article 7 procedure, when it comes to Poland, because I think that we cannot live in a Europe where citizens have to live in fear just because they are different or think differently.

name: Kim Van Sparrentak (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, this week we celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Convention of the Right of the Child, which ensures the right for everyone under the age of 18 to not be discriminated against for one’s sexual orientation or gender identity.  However, within the EU, we see an increase in organised attempts to create an atmosphere of shame, disapproval and hate against everyone who is LGBTI including, and specifically targeting, kids and youngsters. If we here in the EU state so proudly that we are united in diversity, but at the same time allow elected officials in Poland to create LGBTI ideology free zones and make feel kids feel unwelcome in their own community, we can’t say we are doing enough to protect our young people. Being LGBT is not an ideology. Being LGBTI is first and foremost about love, about loving someone else of whatever gender, or being able to love the person that you truly are. But perhaps the most important thing for every LGBTI person, is experiencing love and respect from your immediate surroundings. Every child has tthe right to grow up in a safe space, where you can be able to love yourself and to grow up to be the beautiful and unique person that you are.  We need to work harder to make the European Union an LGBTI friendly zone. We need to let every kid struggling with who they are know that they are loved and welcome to be who they are. Today we stand together with the LGBTI community in Poland and in every country where LGBT people are not fully free and we won’t stop until everyone is.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, dear, with all the conditionality of the word "honourable", I see that in recent years Poland has been your favorite chewing gum and very irritating to you. Both Poland and Hungary and Bulgaria annoy you a lot, and I understand why. Because in these countries we still believe and know that family is a voluntary union between a man, a woman and their families, or if you want a woman, a man and their families. And that you off. LGBTI propaganda in this session has reached a crescendo. Every second report is dedicated either to the Istanbul Convention or to LGBTI people, or to your beliefs that you should take the children and watch them some other people. We, dear, do not accept homosexual propaganda in school and kindergartens. We do not accept actions that border and are close to paedophilia. And that annoys you. I get it. But why do you think your opinion is stronger than mine? Why do you think your opinion weighs more than that of us – the people of Bulgaria, Hungary and Poland? Why do you think that? This, dear, is Bolshevism. You act like the Chinese Communist Bolsheviks. They did that during the Chinese cultural revolution - they shot at everyone they didn't like. That's what you're doing right now. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Seb Dance (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Have you ever been told that you’re not welcome in a community and have you ever been barred from any receipt of public service on account of your identity? And, if you were, how would you feel?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – First of all, I would not go to a place where I am not welcome. I choose the places I go. I'm not intruding on someone who doesn't like me. And secondly, yes. Many times your community has shown intolerance for my opinion. I tell them I don't recognise same-sex marriage and they are very aggressive. They want to impose same-sex marriage. I'm not welcome in your community. But it won't make me sad. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Karen Melchior (Renew)
text: blue-card question. – These are words in the Polish constitution. Should not all Polish citizens be treated equally in Poland?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Because everyone must be equal under the constitution, so your opinion should not weigh more than mine. We should have the same opinion. And because Poles vote in Poland, dear, the Poles decide. They choose law and justice and they want her to govern them. Why do you think you know better than Poles how to manage Poland? I don't think so. I think polish citizens should rule Poland, Bulgarians should rule Bulgaria, Spaniards should manage Spain. You can manage each of your countries. But you don't say what's good for Poland or not. How do you know? You don't know.

name: Eugenia Rodríguez Palop (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I am sorry to stress and point out, but the Polish Government is an inexhaustible source of misogyny and homophobia in the European Union. There are zones free of ⸻dicen⸻ LGBTI because it is considered alien to Polish culture and natural order which, apparently, must be the same thing. It has been said by members of the government and blushes its pride. You in Europe do not represent civilization but barbarism. They remember the worst that has ever been experienced on this continent: the Holocaust and the genocide of the Jews, when sexual minorities were persecuted. They remember the gay concentration camps in Chechnya. They recall the attacks in New Zealand claiming the white man's homeland in front of the invaders, the massacre of Charleston Church in the United States, which was driving a racial war, the Oklahoma bombing, Oslo, and the Norwegian island of Utoya. You want a Europe free of feminist women, homosexual women, Islamic women, racialized people, migrants, left-wing people. They want a Europe in their image and likeness, as if you were God's own representatives on earth. But God is not with you. You cannot Christianize Europe, even if this is your crusade, because you are as far from Christian and European values. Just for violating the principle of equality and non-discrimination should they be opened up by another infringement procedure.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, Europe has been the pioneer of LGBTI rights and I am proud of that. Unfortunately, legislative pitfalls and aggression are the most visible problems facing the LGBT community and, unfortunately, the difficulties are multiplying in Europe. In France, 53% of LGBT people say they have been assaulted because of their sexual orientation. In the UK, for fear of being poorly accepted, only 12% of men, 17% of LGBT women told their families. In Portugal, ILGA Portugal denounces verbal attacks and threats, but also violence, harassment and discrimination in access to health. Germany, for its part, has recorded more than 300 crimes motivated by sexual orientation, a third of which are violent assaults. Belgium, which is my country, has admitted 84 cases of discrimination and violence against sexual orientation in 2018. The Netherlands, which was the first country to recognize same-sex marriage, is of course the country where the population best accepts the issue of homosexuality; yet 29% of its inhabitants consider a kiss between two people of the same sex to be offensive. It is worse in Central and Eastern Europe, where Hungary opposes traditional values to gay rights, and 50% of doctors in Romania consider homosexuality a mental illness. So we must continue to be the pioneers and defend their rights. It is a right enshrined in the Charters of Fundamental Rights, it is a right that we must defend in Europe.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: – (Beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off.) ... It is simply sad that we have to discuss here this evening that anti-gay propaganda is being carried out in Poland. It is sad what we have just had to hear in this House. Homosexual love does not take anything away from anyone who is heterosexual. Love only grows when all people can live it freely accordingly. Dear Members of the PIS, there is no LGBTI ideology, as you keep saying. There are only two people who love each other. If that bothers someone, they might ask themselves if they have a disorder themselves. How evil do you have to be to sow hatred against other people who love each other? How insecure do you have to be if you can't bear to see gays and lesbians and therefore want anti-gay zones? Above all, it is particularly cowardly to seek a minority – supposedly weak – as a target. They are the ones who are weak because you obviously do not recognize or know what sincere love is. That is why you can only feel sorry for me.

name: Rasmus Andresen (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her "People feel threatened, they are afraid and they feel the hatred. They are mainly young people from small towns and villages. Often their parents throw them out at home when they learn about their sexual orientation." With these words, a young Polish LGBTI activist describes the situation in her country. Two thirds of all Polish LGBTI people have experience of violence. Hooligan groups attack young homosexuals in the street, throwing stones at them or with rotten fruit. In this environment, more than 80 municipalities in Poland are now declaring themselves an LGBTI-free zone. This is not a political matter, it is not a purely Polish matter, but a question of human rights, of human rights in our european Union. And it is our duty to stand up here in the European Parliament, but also out on the streets, for human rights, for the rights of LGBTI people. What is happening in Poland at the moment can happen tomorrow in the Baltics and the day after tomorrow in Germany. We must not remain silent about this, but we can take action, through invitations from LGBTI activists, for example, here to the European Parliament, through joint events, through support for prides or also through town twinning, and also through very concrete support for many Polish NGOs, such as Tolerado, who are doing a good job and fighting against it. Let's do this together – for love and against hatred!

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Poland is the one of the most tolerant and open states in the whole of Europe. LGBT marches are secured by the state. But this is not about people, it’s about ideology. Poland has the right to protect traditional and Catholic values, and the parents’ right to teach their children according to the rules they approve. Tolerance does not mean a lack of tolerance for traditional family patterns. That is what Poland is fighting for. Ask yourself which Member States have been the most aggressive ones throughout history? Which Member State were breaking European values and which were defending those values, for instance during the Second World War? Do you know which Member State was the first choice to live in of the Jewish community when the State of Israel did not exist, before the war? It was Poland. So maybe the values of the Polish people are not that bad. You can learn a lot from the Polish people, so leave us alone.  (The speaker agreed to take three blue-card questions under Rule 171(8))

name: Magdalena Adamowicz (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask the representatives of PiS, who are here in the chamber, to say and confirm that it is not true that the president of their party, Mr Kaczynski, challenges LGBT people from the plague, that they can be infected, and frightens children, that is, it speaks of the fact that we should protect our children from dangerous LGBT ideology? As we said, this ideology is not there. Please tell me if this is not true, and did Kaczynski not frighten us with refugees in those elections, and now he scares us with a new imaginary "plague" –LGBT ideology just to cause fear in people?

name: Katarina Barley (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I have a brief question: do you also consider the expulsion of LGBTI-free zones to be an act of tolerance?

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (Renew)
text: blue-card question. – You say: ‘Poland has the right to defend its Christian values’. Wouldn’t it be more correct to say that it is not Poland, it’s the Polish Government imposing one particular set of values on the whole population, ignoring the rights of all the Polish people. Wouldn’t you agree that the Polish Government should not be defending Christian values, it should be defending the rights of all Polish citizens?

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – At the beginning, in relation to mrs in 't Veld's last question. Of course Polish the government should defend all people regardless of religion or orientation. And that's exactly what happens. Therefore, if this is not the case, I would very much ask the Member to give an example that Polish government imposes Catholic values on everyone. Because on a general level, as you can see, we are all very nice to discuss, but when I asked the Polish representative to give an example of these supposed zones that are created in Poland, he could not immediately give. On the internet he dramatically searched and found one address. And that's what it comes down to, ladies and down. On a general level, it's possible to say anything. And on a general level, I can even say that I agree with you on this. But when you ask, show the details, because we are professionals, it always ends exactly the same. Here, too, I would like to reply to Mrs Adamowicz. If you say that such an ideology does not exist, and President Kaczynski has never talked about people, just talked about ideology and did not use such words, because you also cannot give an exact quote and you do so on purpose, so please say, if such an ideology does not actually exist, then please tell us what the gender cathedrals in the world are doing if such an ideology does not exist.

name: President. –
text: Mr Jaki, maybe I can defend the rights of colleague Barley, but you did not respond to her question. You would have 10 more seconds.

name: Katarina Barley (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – Is the expulsion of LGBTI-free zones an act of tolerance for you?

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card.  – Of course you are not, and I would also like to say to you, that if such zones were to be created in Poland, I would be the first person to fight them. The only problem is Dear Member, when we ask the question 'show where they are, where they fight LGBT people... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I too, I have to say, find it almost unbelievable that we are discussing the notion of LGBTI-free zones. Because apart from being despicable and illegal, the notion in and of itself is absolutely ludicrous: the idea that LGBTI citizens are not present in every country, in every family, in every community. More than anything, the fact that we have to discuss this shows the need for education. I think there’s an incredible irony in the fact that these homophobic actions were sparked by the proposal to have an all-inclusive LGBTI sex education in Warsaw schools, precisely demonstrating why such comprehensive sex education is needed in the first place to combat ignorance and intolerance. I’ve heard people in here saying that ‘Polish people know better about Poland’, ‘Spanish people know better about Spain’. You could have said: ‘Ireland was a Catholic, conservative country’, but Ireland delivered a resounding vote for same sex marriage. Attitudes change when you publicly discuss these issues in a tolerant, loving environment.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, all constitutions of the Member States of the European Union prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, but the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is in force and binding on all Member States , also for Poland — prohibits discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. And when Jaros-aw Kaczy-ski says that homosexuality is attacking the family and children and is an imported ideology, he is practicing a discourse of hatred and attacking the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  And the discourse of hatred that leads directly to aggression must be put limits on it. But it must also be banned when it undermines the dignity of people, who are equal in dignity and rights.  I had the honor of being the Minister of Justice who in Spain promoted the adoption of equal marriage. No one's forcing! It simply establishes the freedom of marriage in terms of equality for people of homosexual orientation with the people of their choice. It therefore creates a space of freedom for people to love each other however they want.  Homosexuality is not a disease. Homophobia is! And I had the honor of being friends with the leader Pedro Zerolo, prematurely deceased, of the LGBTI collective, who made it clear that homosexual people do not fit in a homophobic society. (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Michal Šimečka (Renew).
text: – Madam President, to be honest, the phrase LGBTI free zones, when I hear, is running frost on my back, and I think it should provoke dismay in all of us who know European history and who know about all these attempts to create some kind of zone without one minority or without some ethnic group, and we know where this language of exclusion segregation leads, and he has always congregated with violence in history. Today, this violence is concentrated mainly in the online space, especially in my country in Slovakia we are seeing a traumatic increase in hate speech against the LGBTI community and the result is really psychological suffering and the broken fates of thousands of innocent people. And this homophobia of hatred must be countered above all by both the Commission and the platforms and states, but it is the responsibility of politicians and, in particular, of politicians who tolerate or directly encourage this hateful language when they say that human rights and equality of LGBTI minorities is some kind of civilisational threat, and that is precisely the language at the end of which there is violence.

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, just for the interpreters, I’m going to start with a quote in German and then switch again to English.  „Ich bin schwul, und das ist auch gut so!“ became a very famous sentence in Germany, but also over the borders, pronounced in 2001 by the mayor of Berlin, Klaus Wowereit. In the meantime, 2005, I also became a mayor of a rural municipality and I fell in love with a woman, so I remembered this sentence and I was happy to live in a region where nobody would judge me or discriminate against me because of this love. Indeed, the European Union is founded on the values of respect for freedom, equality and respect for human rights. Today, things are changing and we discuss public discrimination of LGBTI people in the heart of the European Union. What we are seeing more and more is a rise of the public endorsement of anti—LGBTI propaganda and LGBTI—free zones, even from mayors. But how can we accept that so many LGBTI citizens in the European Union have to hide who they are and who they love out of fear for their life? Let’s not forget the common values of the European treaties. We want the Commission to react on this.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Αρβανιτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, we have suddenly come to the Middle Ages. Listening to all these comments: "we are not racists, they are homosexuals". That's how they describe it. "We are not racists, they are black", "we are not racists, they are Jews, they are left-wing, they are yellow, they are different".  It's what we were afraid of. It is the result of the so-called 'European way of life' policy and its protection. Who defines the European way of life? Gentlemen across the street after all. And that's too dangerous.  When the Commission, when Europe wants to impose bank policies, imposes them. And here we are talking about matters of political substance. You idy us three memoranda. Why does it not impose issues of the essence of the political aesthetics of what is defined as democracy? We all have to live in this Europe. The tall ones, the short ones, the homosexuals, the bald ones, the whites, the blacks... This agenda cannot be passed.  And one last thing I close: yesterday the Greek Parliament unfortunately rejected the proposal to change the Constitution, which allowed all people, regardless of gender, identity, sexual orientation, to have the same rights. 170 Greek MPs ...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Katarina Barley (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yesterday Charlot Jeudy, the leader of the Haitian LGBTQ group Kouraj, was found dead. The investigation is ongoing. But one thing is certain: he has long received threats of violence in which his life has been threatened. We hear such reports from all over the world again and again. The EU must take a very clear stand against all states that trample on the rights of LGBTIQ people. That is what I expect from our new External Commissioner, but above all I expect our Enlargement Commissioner to do so. And I expect it from all the Member States, because we do not have to look that far. Across Europe, we see that LGBTI people have no legal protection against discrimination. Some states even practise it themselves, discrimination, as we have heard many times today from Poland.  71% of all EU citizens are in favour of equal rights. But at the same time, nearly 50% of the LGBTI community already has experience of discrimination and harassment. I wonder: why? What is the problem with people who have a different sexual identity? I can only think of two possibilities: either you have a problem with yourself and your own orientation, you may be afraid of the homosexuality you carry within you, or you have a serious problem with love in yourself. But every person has the right to love whom ever and where he wants.

name: Sheila Ritchie (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her opening statement, with which I pretty much completely agreed. We were in danger of having a fairly benign to debate with pretty much everybody in the room taking pretty much the same line until Mr Jaki spoke. I’m actually appalled by what he said. You don’t tolerate people who are different to you. Not in 2019! You love them. You include them. You do not put up with them. We all know that inclusion is as much about culture as it is about legislation. How on earth can you create an inclusive culture if we accept that there are places that may not speak about the lives of 10%-plus of their populations? I’d like to tell you about what the creation of these zones has done to homophobic crimes in Poland, but I can’t because Poland doesn’t recognise homophobia as a motive. That, frankly, tells it at all. Commissioner, please, some action?

name: Francisco Guerreiro (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the advance of extreme and populist movements has dragged lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans and intersex people into political confrontations full of hatred and violence, with regrettable attacks against human rights and which easily move from words to acts of physical violence. Contrary to what many want to try to sell, there is no ideological blow by those who defend human rights and LGBTI rights. But there is, yes, an ideology of hatred, propagated by conservative political ideologies, which feeds ignorance, normalizes fear and makes attempts to suppress equality and restrict freedoms that should never be called into question. It is time to put the protection of LGBTI people on the priorities of integrated policy action at European level. The European Commission, this Parliament and national and international institutions have a responsibility to unite against discrimination and hatred, together with the other civil society organisations that have been doing this work for years and which are often so often isolated and without any support. We want a Europe and a world free of hatred, free of discrimination, not the opposite.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is very sad that in 2019 there are still 71 countries that criminalise same-sex relationships and that people of the LGBTI QA plus communities still face prejudice in all walks of life; but there is progress, there is hope. The movement, its time has come, and it is breaking down barriers. We see it every year when millions march at pride events all across the world. Tomorrow, colleagues, will mark the 41st anniversary of the assassination of Harvey Milk, who was one of the first openly gay elected officials in the United States and killed for being gay. I just want to finish with his immortal words of defiance and hope: ‘all young people, regardless of sexual orientation or identity, deserve a safe and supportive environment in which to achieve their full potential’. Burst down those closet doors once and for all and stand up and start to fight. This Parliament joins the LGBTI QA plus community in carrying on that fight and that legacy and I say that discrimination will not be tolerated. Bigotry will not be allowed; and most importantly love is love.

name: Pierre Karleskind (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, but how did we get to this point? We are talking about an ignominy, an insult to the values of the European Union, an insult to all those people who are discriminated eds. How did we get to this point, in communes, shops, regions, just a few kilometres from camps where, 75 years ago, people were locked up because of their homosexuality, and where the Nazi ideology, which also persecuted the Polish people, organized the mass murders of these people? How can we tolerate the same mistakes in Europe 75 years later? Are we doomed to repeat the same mistakes over and over again in Europe? Colleagues, we are not talking about defending this or that community. Simply put, we are here together to support the European community.

name: President. –
text: Now it’s my pleasure to give the floor to Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips. And I welcome the small presence next to you.

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, last Wednesday was the International Trans Day of Remembrance. As of this year, over half of EU Member States have equal marriage and yet here we are in 2019 discussing the rights of an EU Member State to implement LGBTI-free zones. This dangerous discrimination is not consigned to Poland. In the UK, the number of hate crimes reported has more than doubled since 2013. Since last year, hate crimes against the transgender community have risen by 37%. In a politics where trust has dissolved and political leaders in my own country describe members of the LGBT community as ‘tank-topped bumboys’, the political establishment are giving a green light to acts of hate which can ruin lives and lead ultimately to death. Make no mistake, this persecution is the insidious resurgence of the Right. We must unite to oppose hate in all of its forms. It has no place and must not be tolerated in any of our politics. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Thank you very much for mentioning hate crimes. I would like to ask you if you would like the Commission to send a clear signal today that it will seek to criminalise hate crimes in all countries of the European Union, also against people of a different orientation than heterosexual and because of their gender identity? Will the Commission side with all those who want to criminalise hate crimes throughout the European Union? It would be good for us to come out of this debate today not only with a sense of shame that we are conducting such a debate in 2019.

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Sorry, I did not hear the whole of the question because my translation was on 28 and not number 2, due to this little fellow (baby crying sounds). But, of course, I oppose all forms of hate crime, and it has no place in Europe or anywhere else.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday this building turned orange as a sign of solidarity with the fight against gender-based violence against women. Today, after what has also been heard in this House, we should also think, for the future, of dyeing ourselves, as an institution, in the colours of the rainbow in solidarity with the victims of anti-LGBTQI discrimination in Poland and throughout Europe. The normalisation of this feeling, and in the language even of the institutions, is scandalous and extremely dangerous. I am thinking of my own Italy, where many local administrations that have recently moved to the League have left the RE network. A.DY which promotes good practice against discrimination and for the creation of a social climate of respect and confrontation free from prejudice. In Spinea, in the province of Venice, there was even a call for the removal of "uncomfortable" books from children's libraries. We have already seen the results of the war on "degenerate" culture and decadent books, we have seen where we go. Against these intolerant fundamentalisms, we want the European Commission to take a clear line. It must be clear: strengthening a plural, inclusive and respectful European society with respect for fundamental rights is our priority, because it is homophobia that is a disease.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: Madam President! Równi w prawach' - Equal rights. Those words are enshrined in the Polish Constitution. Because according to the Polish Constitution, all Poles have equal rights. But in Poland today, the reality is different. Because in Poland today, all Poles do not have equal rights. Poland's sexual minorities are not equal to their heterosexual citizens. Because in Poland today, so-called LGBT-free zones have been introduced. If you belong to a sexual minority, you are seen as a threat to society. The Polish authorities take your rights away from you - and they do so solely for whom you love or the way you identify your gender. With their crackdown on the LGBT community, the Polish authorities are violating the Polish Constitution and they are offending Poles. Not only the thousands of transgender, gay and bisexual Poles, but also the vast majority of all Poles who want equal rights for all. If Poland does not want to guarantee the right of Polish sexual minorities to live in peace and freedom, Then Europe must take action. Because, unlike the Polish Government, we believe in the words of the Polish Constitution: 'Równi w prawach'!

name: Marianne Vind (S&D).
text: Madam President! Dear Members of this House. Our EU has been the driving force for the diverse society where love is love, regardless of gender and sexuality. You don't choose whether you're an LGBTI person. In France, it was already legal to have sex with one of your own sex as far back as 1791. In Denmark, homosexuals were able to enter into a registered partnership 30 years ago. If the European Union is to be able to speak in capital letters, when countries such as Indonesia restrict the rights of their LGBT people, then we must and must do the same when it happens in our own Union. Workplaces in the EU must not discriminate against LGBTI people. The same must and must be true on our European streets. Homophobia has no place on our continent. LGBT-free zones bring Europe back to dark times.

name: Liesje Schreinemacher (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to talk about one of my best friends tonight. Not only is he talented, funny and sometimes a little annoying, but he also happens to live with a man. Like everyone else in his or her life, it took him time to get to know himself and fortunately it can be done in the Netherlands. We have a lot of role models that young people can learn from that you can just be yourself. The fact that there are now cities in Europe in 2019 where this is not possible is not possible for me. That's why I want to focus from this place on all those boys and girls who are joining us right now. We stand with you. And we will do everything we can to ensure that you too can become that talented, funny and sometimes annoying person who is so valuable in many lives. Just like my best friend.

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D).
text: – Sinjura President, għax napprezzaw l-individwu jeħtieġ nagħmluha whether l-identità mhix ideoloġija, la fl-Ewropa u mkien f'soèjetà æivilizzata m'hemm spasu għal LGBTI free zones.  L-Unjoni Ewropea jrid ikollha l-istrumenti legali biex dawn ikunu to penetrate biex min jippromw's ikun penalizzat. Anke jekk huma symbolièi huma perikolużi, iġibu l-mibegħda in jweġġgħu. Huma manifestazzjoni ta' diskriminazzjoni in jekk nippermett li jiġu normalizzati nkunu qed nipperikolaw id-dinjità, jekk mhux il-ħajja ta' persuni fostna. Imma mhux f'xi Stat Membru wieħed għandna d-diskriminazzjoni fuq din il-komunità LGBTI x'nindirizzaw, l-Unjoni Ewropea wkoll qed tiddiscrimina. Id-Direttiva dwar trattamenti ugwali fix-xogħol titkellem biss fuq orjentazzjoni sesswali. Għad m'għandniex leġiżlazzjoni Ewropea do anyonepri l-identità tal-ġeneru. Għad m'għandniex leġiżlazzjoni of Ewrope do anyone's tal-ġeneru. Sal-jum li jkollna direttiva kontra d-diskriminazzjoni fl-isferi kollha tal-ħajja tant importanti nkunu għadna niddiskriminaw in nonqsu mid-dinjità lil persuni fostna.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță (Renew).
text: – Mr Biedroń, I want to thank you on behalf of thousands of Romanians who feel the same way as you do. My party colleague, Cristina, told me what it meant to be a member of the LGBTI Romania community during communism. What unites all of us in this matter? We have dreams, we want to be free and we want to love. Millions of European citizens enjoy these rights. But there are millions more that are treated by their states as being less equal than the others.   In 2015 the ECHR, the Oliari decision obliges states to recognise and create civil partnership. But to this day, six European Member States are still not implementing that decision. It is not in the hands of politicians that it is the right to happiness, it is not in their hands that it is the right to love or not to love.
