Young people who commit suicide, who suffer, who are offended, this is the lgbti reality that some are frightened of in this room. I conclude by quoting Martin Luther King: Darkness cannot banish darkness, only light will. Hate can't banish hate, only love will.

name: Raphaël Glucksmann (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a sticker with the rainbow flag with a thick black cross is the sinister symbol that currently adorns many shops in Poland, where some 20 cities have declared themselves LGBTI-free, free of all LGBTI. Are we going to accept such a return of hatred on our continent or, on the contrary, will we do everything possible to send the extreme right and its racist obsessions back to their place, i.e. in the dustbin of European history? The time has come to stand up, to stand up to you, the promoters of this hatred. Where you ban LGBTI people, we'll be there. Wherever you go after Muslims, Jews, Roma, any minority, we will be there. Where you will create anti-migrant militias, like in Hungary, where you will hear monkey cries in stadiums, as in Italy, we will be there. Wherever a person has to bow their head because of who they are, we will be there and we will face you. No one in Europe should ever bow their heads for what it is.

name: Radka Maxová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, LGBTI is a long-term issue that I am very actively politically engaged in. It is not acceptable to me that even in the twenty-first century, people from the LGBTI community face hateful verbal and physical attacks, sometimes it seems to me that there are also increasing attacks. I am sorry that in Poland, our neighbouring country, they have declared so-called LGBTI-free zones, and the Polish conservative weekly Gazeta subsequently distributed stickers with this inscription. And we ask: Why is Poland mentioned here? I don't think it's because of the right approach to LGBTI. I am very sorry that homophobic and transphobic rhetoric is often combined with an emphasis on traditions and values and can, at worst, influence the views of many people and incite hatred. However, let us not just blame Poland, I think that all Member States should act together in the fight against discrimination, because there is still much to correct. We should spread awareness and promote together a culture of tolerance and mutual respect. I thank the Commissioner for her assurance that violence and discrimination against LGBTI must be stopped not only in Poland. And I ask: How many LGBT free zones are acceptable to us? I think it's zero. But we let it go to a higher number. Let's stop it!

name: Luisa Porritt (Renew).
text: – Madam President, across the world, the LGBTI community continues to face discrimination. The EU must lead the way in defending their rights and freedoms. The Commission should be prepared to open infringement procedures against Member States that violate or fail to protect fundamental rights. And – yes – that includes Poland. The ripple effects of homophobic attitudes are felt across the EU, where more than one in four LGBTI people have been attacked or threatened with violence in the last five years. Populist parties create an enabling environment for this kind of hatred. In the UK, we had incredible pride parades all over the country in June, but even in Camden, a liberal, diverse part of London two young women were subjected to a horrific homophobic attack on a bus, just days earlier. Hate crimes have risen since the UK’s 2016 EU referendum, fostered by an intolerant political climate. We can and must do better, and it is incumbent on all of us to lead by example.

name: Karin Karlsbro (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We should have come a long way. We should not have to defend people's right to love who they want, but now I am standing here again and doing just that. However, when fellow human beings are subjected to increasing systematic discrimination, eagerly cheered by political leaders, in this case by a party that absurdly calls itself Law and Justice, and parts of the Catholic Church, we must put our foot down against lawlessness, against injustice. It does not matter whether this is happening inside or outside the EU. The EU is a home port for democracies that should stand up for human rights and liberal values. The world needs more love, not more hate. We need more tolerance, not intolerance. Let us also learn from history. Oppression always starts with minority groups and already vulnerable people, but it never ends there. All you women and men, mothers and fathers fighting for freedom, love and respect in Poland should know that we are and we will be with you.

name: Petra De Sutter (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, this debate – and I have followed it from the beginning – has saddened me because I heard what some colleagues in this Chamber have been telling us this evening. I was catapulted back to my childhood and adolescence, where I was told that you could not be different, that girls should be girls and boys should be boys, and girls should love boys and vice-versa. This was dictated by religious beliefs that, 40 years ago, in my country were dominant. I didn’t believe that one day I would be confronted with that again. It took me almost half a lifetime to liberate myself from that. And yes, it goes on. It is an ideology – of course it is – on the concepts of gender and family. This is what it is all about and the agenda has been hijacked by politicians, by nationalists and populists that want to use it in autocratic regimes, not only in Poland. We see the same narrative in Russia, in Turkey and in other countries around the world. It has not only to do with LGBT persecution, it also has to do with the fight against gender equality and sexual and reproductive rights. it is all connected. We have to see that and, from our belief in our true values in this Union, based on universal human rights, we have to fight this again every day. (Applause)

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for this important debate. Answering the question on Lithuania: the Commission is aware of a draft law on equal treatment currently pending in the Lithuanian Parliament and related amendments which fail to extend a list of grounds for prohibited discrimination, not including gender identity as such, which might result in transgender individuals having no legal mechanism effectively securing them against possible discrimination in a variety of spheres, such as education or work. We cannot comment on draft laws, but we are looking at this very closely, and we will act if there is EU competence to act. The Commission has, during the last year, support different actions and initiatives in several member countries to improve tolerance and social acceptance of LGBTI persons. There was a conference some weeks ago with the Commission and the Finnish Presidency to take stock of what has been done and what can be done further as well. Exactly what will be done will, of course, be for the next Commission to define in this regard. As you know, in the area of employment, there is a directive prohibiting discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation and the Commission proposed more than ten years ago to expand that scope, also covering other grounds for discrimination based on sexual orientation in education, social security, social protection and access to and supply of goods and services. You know very well that negotiations have been going on for a very long time in Council, but the required unanimity has not yet been forthcoming. This is not an ideological discussion. It is about the rights of LGBTI people and the obligation of Poland to respect and to protect them. As I said in my introduction, the Commission strongly condemns the developments in Poland when it comes to hate speech, declarations of so-called ‘LGBTI-free zones’ and the attacks against LGBTI people, especially under the election campaign. We will very soon – in a couple of days in fact – celebrate the tenth anniversary of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I think it is very important to defend the fundamental values of the EU and, unfortunately, even 10 years after, we are standing here today. All Member States have signed up to these values and have signed up to respect them. It is a fundamental value to love whom you want and to be respected for that, and to be who you want. Discrimination, intolerance and violence based on sexual orientation or gender identity are against these fundamental values. I can assure you that in the future, the Commission and my friend and colleague Commissioner Jourová – who has been very engaged in these questions and who will be incoming Vice—President responsible for the rule of law – will continue to engage and fight for LGBTI rights in Poland and elsewhere. I count on your support in that struggle. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place in December. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – What we have heard today in the debate on discrimination and hate speech against LGBTI people in the public sphere from the mouths of Robert Biedronia and Magdalena Adamowicz regarding the situation in Poland is monstrously depraved and untrue.  I have had the privilege of serving as Minister of Interior and Administration in the Government of Law and Justice, and never – I never stress – for me and my subordinate services such as the police did not matter what sexual orientation is a citizen of the Republic who needs help or protection from the state. For me, my ministry and the Government of Law and Justice, the absolute priority was to ensure the safety of all – I stress to all – citizens regardless of gender, religion, origin or sexual orientation. We placed particular emphasis on protection and security during lgbti marches or speeches. I have been criticized and attacked many times by marginal but flashy environments.  Poland has been, is and will remain a democratic rule of law in which every citizen is equal. And i consider statements such as those of Today's Biedronia and Mrs Adamowicz to be extremely unfounded, deceitful and unsued. The political dispute and reluctance of the above-mentioned politicians towards the Government of Law and Justice cannot justify the use of lies on the international stage. This is extremely nasty and harmful to the image of Polish.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI)
text: in writing. The worrying homophobic campaign launched by politicians in poland's last election contests has fostered a dangerous and intolerable climate of increasing intimidation and hatred of the LGBTI community. The actions and proclamations of several regional and local authorities that have declared their territories "LGBTI-free", calling them a threat to the nation, represent a serious attack on the individual freedom and fundamental rights of each human being. Any form of discrimination, marginalisation, intolerance or violence based on sexual orientation is contrary to the values on which the European Union is founded. Discriminatory, violent and hate-inciting attitudes cannot be justified in any way, and the European institutions have a duty to take all necessary measures to demand respect for the rule of law and human dignity.

name: Vera Tax (S&D)
text: in writing. – Hearing about the so-called LGBTI—free zones in Poland is absolutely heartbreaking. Everybody should be allowed to love whomever they want, regardless of their gender. The newly elected Commission should make it their absolute priority that everybody in our Union is treated equally. I stand with everybody who is impacted by these free zones or other forms of hate speech.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on measures to address the impact of the WTO decision on the Airbus dispute on European agriculture (2019/2895(RSP)). Allow me to remind you that requests for speeches on request and blue card questions can be made using either a well-established registration method or an electronic system. You can also pick up the instructions for use at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President: another important subject, of a slightly different kind. Honourable Members: thank you for this opportunity to contribute to the debate ahead of the vote on a resolution later this week. I am, of course, very concerned about the recent imposition of tariffs by the US on a range of our agri-food exports. I know from direct contacts that you are too. This imposition by the US on tariffs on food and drink is a regrettable development. Although the US have formally the legal right to impose these tariffs for a long, long time the Commission has been engaging with the US to ask them to freeze or to suspend this in order to find a negotiated solution to the Boeing-Airbus dispute. We made a credible offer in July for a negotiated settlement. As you know, this is a case that has been going on for many, many years. Unfortunately, this opportunity has not been taken up by the US yet.  We believe that it’s time to turn the page on this dispute and focus on de-escalating tensions rather than adding further uncertainty to a delicate world-trade and economic situation. I hope that goodwill will still prevail. We are committed to finding a solution which will keep trade flowing and for workers on both sides of the Atlantic to be able to keep their jobs. This has been the aim during my mandate and I’m convinced that Phil Hogan will continue these efforts. He will go to Washington in early New Year and continue to engage with members of the US administration.  The four EU Member States where Airbus manufacturing is concentrated – the UK, France, Germany and Spain, together with Italy and Ireland – account for 95% of the total food exports of the EUR 3.5 billion exposed to the tariffs. The target products, in order of magnitude, range from wines, spirit, liqueurs, dairy products and olive oils. These products are highly valued by US consumers, and we hope that the demand from them will help resist price pressures.  Addressing directly the calls made in your draft resolution: there are measures available under the CAP that could be used to mitigate the impact of sanctions in the market. We are reviewing the appropriateness of direct intervention at this stage, because you have to take into account a number of considerations. For instance, we need to clearly distinguish between difficulties that are directly related to the US tariffs and those which are related to other issues. For instance, we recently introduced private storage aid for virgin olive oils in the EU, open for all olive oil-producing Member States. The US tariffs have certainly aggravated a very serious situation, but the underlying reasons for the introduction of these measures are not directly related to the Airbus case. We also need to take account of a wider development of the WTO in relation to the US measures, including the possibilities that the Boeing case will present later next year. But our first preference remains a negotiated settlement because we would thereby avoid a damaging trade dispute, and we would also provide a powerful signal to the world market that we want to keep world trade flowing.  When it comes to the specific measures that we could take, promotion policies are often a very appropriate response to tariff sanctions, offering operators the possibility to consolidate the market or to retain their position on existing markets, or even to seek new opportunities, and you mentioned this in your resolution.  The recently adopted 2020 annual work programme emphasises promotion campaigns in third markets by allocating almost two thirds of the available funding to them – that is EUR 180 million. In response to the concerns expressed by some of you here in relation to the US tariff impact on wine: Commissioner Hogan last week confirmed that he is providing greater flexibility in the implementation and management of promotion operations. This seems to be an appropriate response to market disturbances which are likely to affect the wine sector. This flexibility includes a proposal to increase the Union’s financing rate for promotion to 60%, instead of 50% today, which will alleviate the financial burden on producers.  The Commission has reacted rapidly to the urgency and seriousness of the situation and we hope that we can count on your support to ensure a smooth and swift adoption of the required regulation so that this flexibility can be applied quickly, to the benefit of our producers. Other than our promotion policy, the CAP toolbox also includes certain market management instruments such as private storage.  The Commission is aware that additional measures might have to be considered following the conclusions of the analysis that we’re right now doing on the situation of the agriculture markets. We do this with the sectors and with the Member States concerned. And where the analysis suggests we should, we are ready to activate exceptional market measures including private storages. In the meantime, I want to assure you that in this Commission and the incoming Commission, myself and my friend and colleague Phil Hogan will do our best to find a negotiated, balanced, sustainable and compatible solution with the WTO rules, and one that would put an end to the damage suffered by European farmers, including our wine producers.

name: Juan Ignacio Zoido Álvarez
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, the situation of many exporting agri-food sectors is unsustainable following the imposition of Mr Trump's tariffs; sectors that are emblematic in both Spain and Europe; sectors such as wine, olive oil, table olives, spirits; but citrus and dairy products are also suffering from them. And I do not say this, says the sectors concerned themselves, those who know their products best, those who know sales best and, at the same time, the impact they are suffering from the imposition of these tariffs. They are already beginning to lose their sales, their contracts, and foresees the loss of thousands of jobs, especially in rural areas, where there are few job alternatives.  They see in frustration how so many years and decades of effort to have that leadership they had gained in the American market are being thrown away overboard.  But today I want to bring your voice to Parliament and communicate to the Commission the main message they have sent us: Commissioner, they do not want aid or short-term solutions. They simply want tariffs to go away. They want to be allowed to remain competitive. And they want to stop paying for the broken dishes for all the trade agreements and disputes that occur. It would be unforgivable for us to consent to farmers being punished for a problem in another sector that has absolutely nothing to do with. Today, the People's Party is on the side of those millions of farmers and producers who are affected, as it has always been.  And I sincerely want to regret that certain political groups this afternoon have risen from the negotiating table, boycotting the effort that other political groups have made to end this unfair situation. I am convinced that there will be many groups that we will support this resolution next Thursday, and I am sure that the Commission... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, more than a month has already passed since this commercial reprisal against our agri-food products and, above all, against our excellences protected by European quality systems, without the Union having yet put in place any concrete countermeasures. The diplomatic path that the European Parliament will further strengthen this week, by allocating a quota to the United States for imports of high-quality beef, is certainly the way forward. But we can no longer afford, Mrs Malmström, to wait, jeopardising the economic sustainability of a sector which, let us remember, is Europe's leading industry and employs 44 million operators. For this reason, the greater flexibility granted to programmes to promote our products, both in terms of duration, cofinancing and markets, is an important signal. However, we call for the margins available in the Union budget to be used to finance an increase in the funds allocated to these measures and to launch a genuine extraordinary promotion plan for our agri-food sector, with new interventions also directed at distribution chains. All this, Commissioner, while remaining ready to activate all the instruments available in the CAP, which you mentioned, in order to prevent a market crisis from starting, without waiting for the consequences to become irremediable for sectors that are socially, economically and environmentally strategic. The future of our producers and of the entire agri-food sector is at stake, and only by putting in place concrete measures to support farmers and processors will we be able to rise to this challenge.

name: Sheila Ritchie
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, single malt whisky, wine, olive oil, butter, cheese and cashmere attract 92% of the US’s trade counter—measures. Olives, pork, sweet biscuits – that is shortbread – and other products are also targeted.  I’m horrified that the US is targeting malt whisky. I assume that they think this will be a victimless tariff; it will not. Young male unemployment in rural Scotland is about 20%. The whisky industry employs over 11 000 people, 7000 of them in rural areas. It also has the tenth highest employment multiplier of any industry in Scotland, so trickle—down jobs make this a double blow. Twenty-two percent by value of single malt goes to the States. However much you may drink on a flight to settle your nerves, the Airbus dispute has nothing to do with whisky.  I could be moderately sympathetic to a drop in Diageo’s profits, but I’m devastated at the prospect of the material impact on investment and job creation that this will cause.  The EU is currently applying a 25% import tariff on American whisky. I beg the Commissioner to find a way to use the promise of removal of that tariff to safeguard the economy of rural Scotland. Not that I think there should be a dispute at all, but why should my unknowing constituents find themselves out of work because of a high—level dispute about steel, aluminium and aeroplanes? Please go back to the US with honey, as well as vinegar. The whisky industry spends GBP 70 million a year on bourbon casks from the US, and that trade will be lost. For our side of the Atlantic, stop this tit—for—tat, job—destroying tariff retaliation. I couldn’t afford the tariffs on good malt or cashmere, but I got the Commissioner a tin of fine Scottish ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Benoît Biteau
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again it is the farmers who are paying the bill for a trade dispute that does not concern them. The WTO has decided in the dispute between Boeing and Airbus. The latter received undeclared subsidies of 6.8 billion euros per year. President Donald Trump has therefore intentionally chosen to overtax European food products by 25%: French wines, Italian cheeses, Scotch whiskies, Spanish olive oils, the list is not exhaustive. These invisible subsidies, which are never talked about, have allowed this company to flourish. In April 2019, she wrote a cheque for 33 million euros to her CEO when he left office. In 2018, these disguised subsidies have increased dividends paid to shareholders by 10%. The icing on the cake is that Airbus has moved its headquarters to the Netherlands to pay less tax. Airbus therefore has the kidneys strong enough to support European farmers and the agricultural sector who are ousted from the American market overnight. I therefore ask the European Commission to work towards the establishment of a fund of responsibility and solidarity, abounded by the Member States of this consortium and, of course, by Airbus, which no one disputes that it is a flagship of our industry. I also propose that we use the European Adaptation and Globalisation Fund. This would be the first time that this possibility would be opened up to the agricultural sector, which has been hit hard by trade liberalization, and which is in this case concrete... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, the WTO has condemned the European Union for illegal aid to Airbus. The United States has derived from this conviction the right to tax European products. Unfortunately, they chose to tax French wine at 25% and our dairy products at a lower rate. I draw two lessons from this case. Firstly, the European Union is incapable of defending our trade interests. It made a big mistake in violating WTO rules, which it had accepted. Once again, it is the French farmers who will have to pay for its incompetence when they have no responsibility for condemning the WTO. Secondly, the Brussels Commission is a bad negotiator. It had at least one argument to persuade Donald Trump to waive these sanctions, namely that it should have subordinated its decision to import 35,000 tons of American beef per year to a gesture of goodwill from the United States, but the Commission dropped everything without any consideration. This case is an extraordinary mess and the European Union will have to answer for its incompetence in front of the French public.

name: Mazaly Aguilar
text: ECR Group. – Madam President. Commissioner Malmstrom, I heard her sometimes say that there was very little room for manoeuvre in the European Union and that very little could be done against American tariffs. I am pleased to know that, after the popular cry and after a few weeks, we have realized that, indeed, the agricultural sector of the countries affected by these taxes and these tariffs needs not only words of solidarity but urgent and very concrete measures to compensate for the problem that is emerging with these tariffs. The situation is critical and not only about promotion, but we are asking the European Commission to really support a plan, a strategic plan, a very intensive plan and an urgent plan and to go beyond the CAP's measures in order to compensate for this imbalance. In the case of my nation, Spain, as my colleague, Mr Zoido, pointed out, the agricultural products that are going to suffer these tariffs ⸻the wine, oil, citrus, rice⸻ really represent an important export in the United States, because it is the first country to which we export. And simply one figure: in 2018 my nation's exports in these agricultural products exceeded two billion euros. Uns exporting will unfortunately mean the closure of many farms and, in addition, a loss of thousands of jobs. And that, Mrs. Malmstrom, doesn't seem fair to me. Thank you very much for the support you can give us and for the support that Mr Hogan can also give in his next job.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, while you did give the EPP speaker a slap on the wrist for going on too long, I think he made one of the best points here. He said that farmers shouldn’t have to pay the price for something they didn’t cause. It’s hard enough to get your head around this dispute even if you’re working here all the time, but to try and explain this to farmers is damned difficult. They have enough going on without trying to explain to them that a problem with the aeroplanes is going to result in potentially them going out of business, because while you’re explaining it to them, they’re also asking you to explain: ‘how can I expect the Commission to help me when these people who are meant to be helping me are going along signing another deal with Mercosur countries, which will make things even more difficult for us?’.  One thing that has to be done is that we need concrete support measures – real measures to help farmers here, and not measures like those that were put in place in Ireland in response to Brexit or provisionally signing up to Mercosur, which paid the most sustainable beef farmers on the planet to go out of business: we don’t want that type of support. At the end of this, farmers have got to come out of it all right. It’s very hard to believe how they will, though, because they usually are the ones who – both in a literal sense and in a metaphorical sense – end up with the shit on their hands.

name: Dino Giarrusso (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are once again having to defend our farmers against a dispute that has nothing to do with the agricultural sector. It is incredible that they should have to pay the consequences of a legal issue concerning the air transport industry. The US is the leading importer of European agricultural products, with a value of €22.3 billion in 2018, 16.2 % of total exports. So an increase in duties can have disastrous and dangerous consequences. We therefore call on the Commission to have a coordinated and united response in defence of all products damaged by these new duties, to avoid a division between Member States, which is unfortunately possible because of the unfair distribution of these duties, which risk hitting our own excellence more, which Europe must protect at all costs. We call, having also heard the trade associations, for immediate compensation through new or old instruments within the WTO and we want new funds for projects to promote European products in the USA and other third countries. However, this financial allocation to compensate for damage to agricultural enterprises and cooperatives must be found outside the agricultural budget and the CAP and must be weighted against the effects suffered by the various sectors and products. It is necessary to guarantee European agriculture the resources so as not to suffer damage from events that do not concern it and to do so without taking away a single euro from the only truly integrated sector of the Union, the most important also in the future.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, we are actually experiencing an absurdity at the moment. After about 15 years, the WTO has come to the conclusion that Airbus has received too much state aid. It would be the most logical thing in the world that either Airbus would have to repay this money or, if there are already tariffs, that these duties would then be passed on to that company's products. But no, the soup can be spooned out, at least in part, by making it more difficult for farmers to enter the market for agricultural products in the United States. It is also a problem that farmers are being incited against each other because different products are subject to different tariffs in different Member States, which is, of course, a problem in the internal market. In fact, there should be a huge outcry in Europe. But it does not really exist, and I have the impression that this solution does not really suit the industry very badly. The farmers then have to pay a part. It is now also a bit easy to say: yes, then we will just see that agricultural products are sold somewhere else.  I must now say quite honestly that as soon as there was a threat that European cars would be subject to tariffs in the United States, we did not tell the car manufacturers that you would get a bit of money so that you could sell the cars tomorrow in Nigeria or Saudi Arabia. Instead, we have argued that these duties should not be levied. That is why I would ask the Commission to take this issue very seriously and to try to find a solution to this trade dispute. Anything else is very, very harmful to farmers in Europe in the long term.

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Malmstrom, the new European Commission , which I hope will receive the majority support of this House tomorrow , must take priority in resolving this trade dispute.  As with the Russian veto, and as other colleagues have mentioned earlier, farmers end up paying for the broken dishes of disputes caused by political action or other sectors. Compensatory measures and support for the sectors and products concerned are necessary for the duration of this situation. We need measures under the CAP: private storage is a good measure for Spanish olive oil , especially injured – or other products, or the withdrawal of fresh production. We must also articulate measures for the promotion and search of new alternative markets, as well as make the Promotion Aid Regulation more flexible. Having said that, we need to look beyond the CAP and promotion; additional and urgent support is needed for the sectors concerned. This is the main message I would like to convey to you, Commissioner Malmstrom: the need for measures to avoid the harm caused by US tariff policies.  These tariffs are unfair and apply unequally to the target Member States of this attack, breaking market unity and trying to break our political action unit. In Spain alone, these sanctions put more than 5,000 jobs at risk and will result in losses of more than EUR 1 093 million. Last year I denounced the rise of tariffs on table olives. Here is the WTO decision. We need strong, urgent and appropriate responses so that the sectors concerned feel that this new Commission and Europe are with them.

name: Karin Karlsbro (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Many of us are tired of the protracted dispute that has been going on between Europe and the UNITED States over how we manage our respective aviation industries.  We would like the US to have a greater willingness to find solutions by consensus. However, we must defend the WTO system, not only when the WTO decides in our favour, but also when it comes to the conclusion that we are the ones who have done the wrong thing. I, like my colleagues, hope that the Commission and our Member States will do what is possible to mitigate the effects on the sectors that are now affected by the American countermeasures resulting from this judgment, but also to prevent the cause of the sanctions. At the same time, however, let us remember that a functioning free trade requires a common playing field. It is the basis for European prosperity and growth. If we want to avoid a situation where everyone is at war with everyone, as President Trump advocates, we must stand up for cooperation within the WTO even when it does not directly benefit us.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, why, when German cars were simply threatened by duties, the Commission hit its fists on the table and now that there are duties in the agri-food sector, does the Commission actually shut up? The consequences are paid for by countries such as Italy, which in fact have nothing to do with the financing of Airbus. Agri-food has already been penalised by the Russian embargo. The WTO needs to be reformed, but the European Union must commit itself to giving states the means to intervene and somehow limit the consequences of tariffs. Great Italian excellences, such as gorgonzola, grana, pecorino cheese and Parmesan cheese, will be penalised with duties of up to 25 % for those exporting to the United States. We therefore call on the European Union to provide some aid by increasing funding for the promotion of these products on the American market. The agri-food sector deserves much more attention.

name: Nicola Procaccini (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as the ECR Group we will support the joint motion for a resolution because all the Member States of the European Union are damaged by US duties and agri-food companies are the most damaged of all. But for the sake of truth two things must be said and emphasized. Firstly, the WTO lawsuit over the eu ropean Union's illegitimate subsidies to Airbus dates back fifteen years and was brought by as many as three American Presidents, both Republican and Democratic. Secondly, European subsidies to the Franco-German Airbus consortium have damaged not only the American Boeing but also other European companies, such as the Italian Fincantieri-Leonardo. Unfortunately, it is mainly italian and European farmers, farmers and producers who lose out. That is why we are calling for concrete and immediate compensation for them.

name: Manuel Bompard (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is not Donald Trump's toy. After the WTO arbitration in the Airbus case, the US sanctions force us to react, first by retaliating, because there would be nothing worse than accepting without saying anything. We must therefore prepare trade sanctions, since the WTO will issue arbitration in the Boeing case. We must start now by refusing U.S. beef import quotas until a negotiated solution is reached with the United States. Secondly, we must accompany our farmers, who have nothing to do with it and do not have to bear the consequences of this situation. Of course, CAP funds must be mobilised immediately to help them, but it is time for the CAP to be reformed so that our agriculture turns more towards local consumption, short circuits and food sovereignty objectives. Finally, we must put an end to the hypocrisies of international trade policy. It is legitimate for our states to intervene to support our strategic industries and they will have to do so even more tomorrow to meet the challenge of ecological transition. We therefore call on the Commission, and we call on you, Commissioner, to support a reform of the WTO to put an end to free and undistorted competition and to put social and environmental issues at the heart of trade policies.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the United States imposes new tariffs on European products in response to the European Union's subsidies to Airbus. Similar measures are being prepared by the European Union. The fierce economic confrontation between the United States and the European Union, which is being waged by the interests at issue, will again be paid for by small and medium-sized farmers and workers, as the small peach producers in Greece paid for the Russian embargo in response to European Union sanctions.  The Government of the New Republic, like syriza's previous one, celebrates that, thanks to its alliances with the United States and the European Union, Greek olive oil has finally been exempted from customs duties. It does not say, however, that Greek products such as industrial peach and feta are on the tariff lists of these allies, while small and medium-sized farmers and the people pay for it. It does not say that this year the price of olive oil for small producers has fallen in the way and at the same time the European Union has decided to store it, i.e. to withdraw from the market large quantities of olive oil so as not to drop its price on consumption, so that the popular households continue to buy it very expensively in order to treasure the large traders and the processing groups.  In Greece and Europe, small and medium-sized farmers living with the consequences of the CAP have nothing to expect from tariffs, counter-tariffs and wolf alliances. They must organize themselves, fight for their own needs against the policy that is uprooting them.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: – Madam President, only last Thursday, the WTO reported a 37% increase in the last half of this year in import—restrictive measures implemented by G20 economies, totalling more than USD 416 billion in trade coverage. At the beginning of October, the WTO downgraded its forecast for world trade growth from 2.6% last February to 1.2%. History has shown that the road to devastating conflicts is paved with trade wars. It is clear that it is high time for a de-escalation of trade tensions. It is high time to choose talks over tariffs – even if they are legal for once – and engage earnestly in a reform of the WTO to address existing imbalances.  Meanwhile, European farmers as well as consumers – the weakest elements on both sides of the Atlantic – suffer from a conflict in which they have no fault, and where tariffs are deliberately weaponised by the Trump administration to drive a wedge between European unity. I call upon the Member States to stay united in the face of this challenge. Providing a more predictable international trade environment for our farmers is the surest way to defend the livelihoods of our farmers in the long term.

name: Isabel Carvalhais (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the imposition of tariffs by the United States of America on European agri-food products is another serious blow to this sector. It will once again be about agriculture and european farmers that the bill for a conflict that is alien to them will fall.  Of course, in the immediate future, it will be about the sectors directly targeted, such as Portuguese dairy products, which will weigh the most harmful consequences, particularly felt in the fragile economy of the Azorean islands, where the export of São Jorge cheese, a product of great added value, will be strongly achieved.  However, in the medium term, all European farmers will be affected by these unfair measures and will be hit by the disruptive effect they will have, both on their export markets and in the internal market itself.  It is therefore also necessary, Commissioner, to avoid an escalation of retaliatory measures with a negative outcome for all. It is essential to make every effort to achieve a negotiated solution to the end of these tariffs and, at the same time, to ensure that all measures are taken to protect our farmers from the negative impact of applying these tariffs.

name: Marie-Pierre Vedrenne (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, despite repeated requests from the European Union, the United States refuses to reach an amicable solution in the dispute between Airbus and Boeing, and our farmers, in particular, are paying the price. Many products such as wine, pork and dairy products are covered by the U.S. measures. We therefore call on the European Commission to put in place support measures for our farmers. I welcome the measures announced on Friday by Commissioner Hogan for the wine sector. This is good news that needs to be followed, in particular, by additional measures for other sectors. Moreover, firmness will have to be de rigueur when, in turn, the European Union will be allowed, in a few months, to impose detention measures in the case of Boeing. Finally, I cannot help but denounce the double play of Donald Trump's United States, which is using the World Trade Organization to their advantage, at the same time as they are trying to bury it by blocking the dispute resolution appeals body. The European Union must be united, through the European Commission, to defend its businesses, its farmers and its economy.

name: André Rougé (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the United States is overwhelmingly supporting its strategic endeavours. China, India and Brazil are doing the same. These states are great powers and their leaders are patriotic. The European Union would do well to draw inspiration from this course of action, but it is still a prisoner of free-trade and globalist dogma. At the National Rally, together with Marine Le Pen, we want to defend the strategic and economic interests of the nations that make up it. In the theatre of globalization, we do not want the United States and others to be strong. We would expect the European Union to be inspired by this pragmatic policy of reality. Our farmers and our industries would have everything to gain from such lucidity and firmness. It is for them in particular that we want to change Europe. The Europe we want is precisely that of Airbus, that of concrete projects and that of the cooperation of free and independent nations.

name: Nosheena Mobarik (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the Scotch whisky industry is one which is particularly badly affected by this trade dispute, and one which has had no part in creating it. In a game of tit-for-tat tariffs, the Scotch whisky industry faces 25% import tariffs on a number of its products, and likewise, other products such as Scottish shortbread are also impacted. As someone has already mentioned, the Scotch whisky industry alone directly employs 11 000 people in Scotland – over 7000 of whom are in rural areas.  My constituents are rightly concerned that they are currently set to pay the price of a trade dispute centred on the aerospace industry. I therefore call upon the Commission to consider the impact of this dispute on job creation, investment and economic growth in Scotland, and to work with firmness and diplomacy to correct this damaging situation.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I can only agree with the previous speakers: I naturally also find it interesting how many people in this House are suddenly advocating world trade. This has not always been the case in the past when we have discussed the issue of trade elsewhere. Once again, there is an issue, a judgment on the back spine of agriculture, which has nothing to do with it. That is unfair, and it is unjustified. In particular, the choice of products and the regions, the Member States that are affected, has the huge potential to divide Europe. And that is precisely the intention of the American President. That is why I would like the Commission to react more forceily and to negotiate as quickly as possible, so that we can get rid of these tariffs. As a backlash, punitive tariffs on our part may be understandable at first sight. However, I do not believe that they will ultimately be effective if we continue to have further customs escalations. After all, not only our industry, but also our agriculture, benefits from the export of its goods, and this must continue to be possible. Excessive trade barriers and excessive protectionism are misplaced here. That is why, in order to ensure free and fair world trade for our farmers too, we must find a solution soon.

name: Carmen Avram (S&D).
text: – Madam President, unfortunately the European farmer is beginning to feel like an unwanted child of the family. Although it has the burden of feeding to drastic standards a good part of the planet, a avalanche of uncertainties and worries now collapses on its shoulders, which are not directly related to it: the reduction of the agriculture budget due to Brexit and other recent priorities of the Union, unfair competition and the double standard that will come with Mercosur and , more recently, he's convicted in absentia in the Airbus dispute. Although he did nothing wrong, the European farmer will have to take on more than half of the penalties, or $10 billion if the amount is kept. This tagma is being bankrupted and with it will suffer every citizen of the European Union. If we want to destroy the European farmer, however a rarer species, we are on the right track. But if we want to defend and preserve it, we will have to remember that principles such as solidarity and equity and impartial and just treatment for its citizens are at the heart of the European Union. It is time to put these principles into practice and intervene quickly diplomatically, financially and by any other measures that would be necessary to save the European farmer and the food he provides us.

name: Jordi Cañas (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, last October we had the opportunity to discuss in this Parliament the unfair situation in our agricultural sector, motivated by an aeronautical dispute paid by our farmers. A month ago we asked the Commission for concrete and urgent measures to avoid the enormous damage to the agricultural sector of this unfair situation. A month has passed and what has the Commission done? Well, what he's done has made him late, wrong, and in an insufficient way. And today we hear ⸻ and I'm sorry to have to say it ⸻ say you have to go the page. But you know what's going on? That farmers can't page. That the hundreds and thousands of farmers affected by this situation cannot turn the page and will lose their market. And especially my country, Spain, is going to suffer a terrible impact of more than a billion euros on its exports to the United States, with some products being expelled from the market and with others that will never again be able to return to competitive conditions. And in the face of that, what does the Commission do? Patches, insufficient patches.  This Parliament has proposed this resolution. At least he's proposing something. But what's going on? That the Commission does not take everything just as seriously. Perevering it is that there are first and second sectors and there are first and second citizens, because it turns out that when we talk about steel and we talk about aluminum, the Commission does have solutions, in this case (inaudible words). Finally, the problem is not only what Trump has done, but what this Commission has not done: defending its farmers, European citizens.

name: Bert-Jan Ruissen (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the US decided in October to impose additional tariffs on a range of agricultural products because of the support for Airbus. It is not the first friction between the US and the EU over trade. The WTO will also rule on the Boeing case next year. That could be fascinating. Let us be clear that it is not in the interests of our sectors to engage in a trade war with the US. I therefore call on the Commission to do everything possible to reach a negotiated solution. You are right to talk about the use of de-escalation.  This debate may be about the dispute with the US, but I would also like to remind the Commission that we also have something like a Russian boycott that has been going on for five years now. The sector is still suffering the burden of this and the attention to this in my experience is in danger of slackening. That worries me.  The account of international trade disputes is all too often placed on the agricultural sector. We cannot and must not let that happen.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, once again agriculture is the collateral victim of a conflict that is beyond it. The US decision to impose nearly 25% tariffs on iconic European agricultural products is eminently political and hits a sector that has already faced Russian sanctions since 2015 and must also prepare for the UK's exit from the European Union. We must therefore work to rapidly de-escalate sanctions and trade tensions, and the European Commission must be ready to mobilise all the tools at its disposal to help our sectors diversify their markets or strengthen their presence in the US market. As such, I would like to welcome Commissioner Hogan's announcements, in particular, of the introduction of cross-cutting promotional actions, the increase in co-financing rates and the relaxation of promotion rules in national wine programmes. These proposals respond to our mobilization. Nevertheless, Commissioner, we must remain vigilant, and if these sanctions are to lead to deeper destabilisation of the affected sectors, we should be prepared to use the tools of the CMO, i.e. private storage or the granting of compensation measures. Finally, this episode shows us that in an increasingly unstable world, we must maintain a strong agricultural budget and continue to reform our market prevention and management tools.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in recent months we have seen an escalation of trade frictions between the United States and Europe: first the duties imposed on our steel and aluminium imports, then american retaliation following the Airbus ruling. Trump is evidently using tariffs to build electoral consensus ahead of the next presidential election. In the coming months, a similar WTO ruling will come in on the American subsidies to Boeing, which will allow us to impose duties in our turn. In this scenario, we must be able to put a stop to this trade war. No winner will emerge from this tug-of-war. The temporary benefits are just an illusion, the two economies will suffer significantly. The way forward lies in the search for political dialogue. In the meantime, we must support the sectors affected by American tariffs, particularly those in the agri-food sector, and prevent those European countries that are not involved in subsidies to the Airbus consortium from being penalised.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Madam President! Today we are discussing the effects of US customs duties on the basis of the World Trade Organisation decision in the Airbus-Boeing case on European agriculture. When we talk about this, we must not go past the wider context embodied by the thoughtful policy of customs wars, protectionism and economic blackmail. Its purpose is to destroy multilaterism in world trade, to restrict competition and, in particular, to move jobs past the rules and, above all, to the detriment of other stakeholders, especially to the detriment of the European Union. As this policy is a fact, I expect the current and the new Commission to not only ensure the preservation of multilaterism in the green package and, in trade policies, it will not only ensure, promote and strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy, and also preserve European jobs both in industry and in agriculture, and especially those that will be threatened by customs and other protectionist policies.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Dear Chairman, subsidy policy is extremely widespread in Europe. Everything is subsidised, and what it has market logic for, but also those sectors that should be self-sustaining long ago. This practice has been widespread since ancient times and never seems to be put to an end because politics is too well networked with individual economic giants and benefits them in this way.   All this is always besoed over the backs of small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, and so it will be this time. Due to illegal subsidies to Airbus, European farmers will face new tariffs when exporting to America.   It is high time that, after many decades, we revised the subsidy policy. Subsidies should be given to small, promising and innovative companies, and only until they grow enough to be able to exist independently on the market. By subsidising large companies, we are killing competitiveness, innovation and limiting growth. It's bad economic policy.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it struck me when I was preparing for this debate that the common agricultural policy and subsidies to farmers is heavily criticised as being complex. Well it pales into insignificance when we look at the complexity of the subsidies for the aircraft industry, and that is worth bearing in mind. I think all of us know that there’s nothing worse than being penalised for something that you didn’t do, and our farmers are being penalised for something that they have no hand, act, or part in – and that’s very troubling. And of course, the idea of the US is working, because we’re debating it here this evening. It’s hurting people on the ground and we have to find a solution. So I have a question for the Commission, because you did mention that efforts are being made that a credible offer was made by the EU, but not taken up yet. I’d like more information and detail on that. Are subsidies still being paid to the aircraft industries? What’s happening to the Boeing Airbus situation? But I know that farmers are definitely hurting and angry. I don’t know about your Member State, but it is interesting that in the Netherlands, in Germany and in Ireland today, there are tractor protests in capital cities. This is not being done by organisations of farmers: it is individuals who have decided – because they are angry over many things (not just this issue, but many, many things) – to strike back. I think, as we move towards the climate issue – because there’s been a lot of climate shaming – we have to be mindful of our words, because rural Europe is in difficulty and this issue must be addressed.

name: Inma Rodríguez-Piñero (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I fully support the resolution we are debating today and I ask all the representatives of Parliament for their support next Thursday. And I support it because, on the one hand, it is very critical, as it cannot be otherwise, with the attitude of US policy and, on the other hand, because it recognises the enormous effort that the Commission is making — and which I recognise the Commissioner — to try to avoid this situation.  A situation that is, of course, absolutely unfair. No one can understand that, because of the aid received by a sector, which, of course, had nothing to do with agricultural, they now suffer from an increase in their tariffs which prevents many of them from reaching the North American market. And I would like to point out that, of one of the products concerned, Valencian clementines have sold zero — zero – since tariffs were increased in the United States. And that has happened in many other affected sectors. But I believe that in addition to asking , as we do , for the implementation of measures to alleviate the serious consequences of the sector, it is also important, above all, to have an impact on the substance of the matter. And I believe that, in order to ensure that the sector is not so unfairly affected by these sanctions, in the context of WTO reform — in which the Commission is playing a very important role — we should also address the reform of the sanctions system. If we want citizens to support rule-based trade, the rules must be fair.

name: Raffaele Stancanelli (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the World Trade Organisation has recognised the right of the UNITED States to impose duties on the European Union, which would have paid illicit subsidies to the airbus aircraft manufacturer consortium. Although Italy is not part of the consortium and therefore has no direct responsibility for this diatribe, it could suffer considerable economic damage as part of the duties should affect the agri-food sector. The aeronautical sector is among the most complex industries from the point of view of development, production and financing. The specific nature of the sector therefore requires an overall regulation of subsidies, enabling all operators to compete on an equal footing, but we must not make those who have nothing to do with the sector itself pay the price for certain behaviour. That is why I am asking the Commission to take and say what specific measures it wants to take to reduce the impact that US duties will have on Italian agri-food exports.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the European Union is showing a guilty difficulty in protecting its manufacture in all its aspects in many areas and in many areas. Unfortunately, we have seen the ineffectiveness of the safeguard measures in the steel sector, the invasion of Turkish steel with safeguards that are unable to block it, neither on price nor on the ability to protect market shares. In the agri-food sector, we see a guilty silence on this game. I would like to say a few things about possible compensatory measures, but that is not what our farmers and the processing industry need in the agri-food sector. What it needs is not compensation, which is small and insufficient today, but it needs to remain on the American markets. It is true that on the other hand we have an aggressive President Trump, who shows a culpable ease in trade policies and a total lack of respect for the traditional capacity for economic relations between the United States and the European Union, but on this side we have a European Union that has shown itself to be very fragile. Let us remember, during the previous term of office, the ease with which the European Commission was about to recognise China's status as a market economy, condemning our manufacturing to death. So, once again, the question is: do you believe the European Union in its manufacture? You think you can protect her? If so, hit a beat!

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in response to state aid to the aviation sector, agri-food products, in particular our geographical indications, have been affected by the American side. This denoted the willingness of the US administration to respond more to the needs of domestic policy and particular production sectors. These are duties, as has already been said, in addition to the suffering that the agri-food sector has suffered for many reasons, but also as a result of political and trade disputes with Russia. We must therefore avoid a worsening of the situation, as we say very warmly to the Representatives of the Commission. In particular, we need to strengthen programmes to promote our products in order to gain greater market share and thus compensate for the losses caused by duties. We therefore welcome the fact that, in the recent agreement on the 2020 budget, the Council and the Commission did not accept Parliament's request to increase the funds allocated to promotion programmes. However, we still hope, as Mr De Castro in particular said, that there will be an extraordinary plan for promotion and support measures for the agricultural sector, which is so important for the European economy.

name: Άννα-Μισέλ Ασημακοπούλου (PPE).
text: Madam President, we obviously respect the decision of the World Trade Organisation on State aid to Airbus and we still want a compromise in view of the history and condemnation of Boeing, but until that is done, Commissioner, we cannot overlook the fact that a flagrant injustice is taking place at the moment with disastrous consequences, and that is because , as you are well aware, 60% of the duties are imposed by the United States not on aircraft, but on iconic European agri-food products.  In my own country, in Greece, after the Russian embargo, which brought Greek table peach producers to their knees, mr. Trump's tariffs are now coming and destroying the production of compote exported to the United States with special specifications, worth $50 million. We, Commissioner, as the European Parliament have already made a gesture of goodwill, honouring the agreement of Mr Juncker and Mr Trump on the import of beef from the United States, so we are now calling on you in the European Commission to use all available means of supporting European agricultural products. This also includes direct State aid under Articles 219 and 221 of the Regulation on the common organisation of agricultural markets, and as a matter of priority in countries not related to Airbus.  It is time to move on, Commissioner, from words to deeds.

name: Cristina Maestre Martín De Almagro (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress this call on the unity of this Parliament to defend the interests of European agri-food producers in bulk. The proposal for the agreed resolution is certainly good news, because this is not a problem of a few but is a problem for all. Indeed, Spain, France, Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom and Ireland account for 97% of the exports concerned, but the rest of the Member States will also be directly or indirectly affected. And that is why the European Commission must remain active. It is very important that the countervailing measures in the motion for a Resolution are activated, either through a strong cap and without cuts and also through other mechanisms, such as measures to promote these products internationally, which have to be powerful, both in the United States and in international markets. And we know that there are many possible formulas within the rules set by the market. But in order for this to be possible, there has to be a strong increase in funds as well. The Commission therefore has to implement these measures to defend our farmers and ranchers, to make them stronger and more competitive and to make products as important as wine, oil or Manchego cheese ⸻i.g. unique in the world⸻ stronger and more competitive.

name: Marlene Mortler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I find it unacceptable that the agricultural sector should be involved in a dispute which originates in a sector which it is completely independent of, and should also bear a large part of the costs of litigation. I therefore deplore the US Government's decision to impose tariffs on so many agricultural products and call on the Commission to do everything possible to prevent damage from the agricultural sector.  Can you explain to me where the link between cars and the food sector is? I can't do it. In any case, I am deeply concerned about the collateral damage caused to the EU's agri-food sector as a result of the decision. This must not leave us cold. These tariffs will have a significant negative impact not only on the target Member States and their products, but also on the agricultural sector as a whole along the entire agricultural and food chain, and they will also have a negative impact on CONSUMERS in the United States. The Commission is invited to examine ways of assigning compensation to the sectors concerned in the event of a deep crisis in accordance with Article 221 of the Common Organisation of the Market within the margins available in the budget. Quirky policy decisions are commonplace under the Trump administration. There is certainly a post-Trump era. Until then, we are called upon to limit the political and economic damage.

name: César Luena (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the idea of Europe, among other things, is that, when a part of us suffers, we all suffer, and then we all have to help that part. Products and sectors such as wine, agri-food industries, need the solidarity of this House and the Commission's support for the trade attack and tariff imposition of the ineffable White House tenant. They need help so that a problem of all of us will address it among all by calling, first of all, for negotiation to stop that madness. Let us remember Mitterrand when he said, "Nationalism is war." "Protectionism is trade war," I add. Aid to survive and overcome this blow —promoting, yes—but also additional compensation measures that help wine, help businesses, agri-food industries.  We need a strong European position, solidarity and willing to defend a key part of our economy and jobs.

name: Sven Simon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is indeed unfortunate that the US has decided to retaliate against sectors that have nothing to do with aircraft manufacturing. As my colleagues before stated so clearly, this policy has negative consequences for the livelihoods of thousands of European farmers and targets Member States unequally. But the issue goes much deeper. It is about the capability of the EU to respond and to defend the rule of law in international trade. We want to live in a world in which court decisions are respected. That is why we accept the judgment on Airbus and are open to negotiations. However, we also want to live in a world where such judgments are not misused as a pretext to pursue a protectionist agenda. WTO law must never serve as window dressing for protectionism and isolationism. With this resolution this House takes forward these principles. We ask all European nations to unite behind this and we invite our American partners to solve this issue through dialogue, not confrontation.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Madam President, a huge blow to Greek producers will be the imposition of 25% tariffs by the United States of America on iconic agricultural products such as peaches, compote, feta cheese, yogurt, dairy products. Of course, it is good that Greek olive oil, edible olives, domestic wines have been left off the tariff list.  United States policy will inevitably harm the Greek food industry and hurt jobs and investment, especially in the peach compote sector. It is completely unfair for the rural economy to pay for a trade war, as a result of the dispute over aircraft investment, which has nothing to do with agricultural products. Commissioner, use all available means to heal the wounds in the agricultural sector throughout Europe and in my country Greece.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, sanctions on European Union products by the United States threaten the viability of thousands of producers and small and medium-sized enterprises. Especially in my country, Greece, we have a serious problem with companies that produce peach compote, as the data of the canning association show that the damage is estimated at $50 million. Greek compote exports to the United States account for 20% of domestic production.  And now come to the place of the producer of peaches in Imathia, Pella, which for the second time in recent years is suffering the effects of a trade war, Commissioner, and I know you understand that. We need to de-escalate the confrontation with the United States, but before that happens it is necessary to defend the ability of our producers to continue working.  For this reason, flexibility in the implementation and management of support funds for farmers, as in the example of Mr Hogan's proposals for wine, can also be applied to peaches and feta cheese and yoghurt and other iconic products. We need immediate intervention before households are destroyed, before productive agricultural and manufacturing businesses are lost, not only in Pella and Imathia, but everywhere in Europe.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done The new US punitive tariffs on agricultural exports from Airbus manufacturers are a nasty step against the EU following the WTO ruling against subsidies to Airbus. Our farmers lose their income as punishment for industrial subsidies, but also for false WTO rules. That is not acceptable. The Von der Leyen Commission can learn from this two things: first, don't trust Donald Trump. He does not thank you if the EU wants to buy trade peace through a lot of money for soya and gas from the UNITED States. We must support the farms concerned in the EU, by compensating, but also by promoting the diversification of exports. French wine is also valued in China and elsewhere. Secondly, stop demonising industrial subsidies. Change the WTO rules. Neither Airbus nor Boeing would have made their rise without subsidies. Take money into the hands of sustainable industrial policy and future technology and allow other WTO members to do the same. We need this to stop climate change.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I understand your concerns. As you know, this is an old dispute between the EU and the US –Airbus/Boeing. It has been going on for 15 years. There’s a huge room of papers on only this case in Geneva, and it has certainly paid the wages of many lawyers. WTO has found that both the EU and the US have been guilty of giving unauthorised subsidies to Boeing and Airbus. This gives the formal right to the US now – and to us a little bit later, next year – to impose tariffs. We have made it very clear to the US that we are preparing such a list as well, to have if it is needed.  However, as many of you have said, we already have too many tariffs in this world, and that is why we have been pushing for a negotiated solution. We have provided quite detailed elements of what we could do on both sides for existing, past and future subsidies in this area. Some subsidies have been allowed; some have been condemned; some have disappeared; some are in the process of being disappeared. But it has, of course, to be a balanced process which both Boeing and Airbus dismantles, and this is a process that we have asked the Americans to engage in. I have raised it personally with Ambassador Lighthizer several times. I know that Member States, some of you and others have passed on the same message, so we have been perfectly united there. We have also proposed that, apart from disciplining ourselves, we should set global standards, because the big problem in the future will be other big economies who are already today massively subsidising their civil aircraft. If we could put some global standards here, it would be useful. Unfortunately, the US has not, at this point, been willing to engage. We will keep on pushing, of course, but so far that has not been possible and we are here today, stuck with tariffs that are, of course, disproportionately – and that is totally deliberate from the US side – affecting the agricultural sector. I am aware – and so is Phil Hogan and the whole Commission – of the social and economic difficulties in sectors, in regions, and whole countries that this is causing. This is serious and it is urgent. That is why, since quite some time, we are assessing the situation.  As I said in my introduction, there are several tools at our disposal. Some have already been announced: flexibility and promotion. There might be others as well, but we need to be totally clear on what we do, what the consequences of the US tariffs and the consequences of other market distortions or other problems are, because we need to be able to design targeted, effective measures, and they need to be WTO compliant. That is what we are doing right now.  I would like to firmly reject the notion that the trade policy has been a disadvantage for the agriculture market. On the contrary, there are several independent reports proving that the latest trade deals that we have done with Japan, with Canada and now with Singapore, which is entering into force, and also future agreements with Vietnam, Mercosur and Mexico, are and will be hugely beneficial to the European agriculture sector. We’re opening up new markets for products that are highly in demand from all over the world, and this is, of course, also very important for agriculture. Having said that, I do not in any way want to diminish the problems that farmers and the agricultural and wine sectors are facing here today, and this is why our services in this Commission and the coming Commission will finalise the study and the analysis and come back to you and the Member States. We discussed it at the trade council meeting last week with Member States as well, on further action very soon in this field.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: In accordance with Rule 132(2) and (4) of the Rules of Procedure, seven motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 28 November 2019. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. – The wto professional body's grand deadline expires on 10 December. Then the term of two of the three remaining members expires. If this happens, the professional body is sidelined. Donald Trump is playing a game with the highest authority for settling trade disputes. Europe cannot let this happen. In addition to blocking the appeals body, Trump is also currently blocking wto budgets for 2020 and 2021. When it comes to world trade, it cannot be the case that one man sidelines the referee. That is why I call on the Commission to continue consultations with the various members of the WTO in order to avoid a blockade.

name: Dan-Ştefan Motreanu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The consequences of the trade dispute between the European airline manufacturer Airbus and the American airline Boeing must not affect European farmers, wine-growers and farmers. The recent decision of the World Trade Organization to authorise the United States to impose additional tariffs of $7.5 billion on a number of European products can have irreversible negative effects on producers in different regions of the European Union.  I therefore find it absolutely necessary, through this resolution, to identify effective measures to support the producers concerned with the risk of limiting their export volume or production capacity, such as access to new markets or possible compensation.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew)
text: in writing. – Free trade is a central plank of the EU’s and, in particular, Ireland’s economic strategy, owing to its lack of obvious natural resources – bar our own charm and ingenuity. Irish farmers are the collateral damage of the failure of the EU and the US to reach a common ground. For example, a 25% tariff on butter will have an estimated cost of EUR 50 million for the Irish dairy industry annually. In addition to the direct impact these tariffs will have, the instability also threatens growth and job creation. This pressure comes at a time when markets are already dealing with the ongoing consequences of the Russian ban and the looming threat of Brexit. I strongly supported the calls for the Commission to use all available tools under the CAP to assist the sector, as well as supporting producers in the most affected sectors to seek alternative markets for their products and produce. Imposing additional tariffs on EU-US trade is mutually destructive and doesn’t serve the long-term interest of either the US or the EU. The Commission must de-escalate the trade tensions and to ensure that a timely resolution is found before the spring, to avoid damage to exports of new season products.

name: Susana Solís Pérez (Renew)
text: in writing. As a result of the World Trade Organization's ruling on the Airbus case, the United States Government has decided to impose significant tariffs on a list of 150 European products. Unfortunately, Spain is among the most affected countries, with a potential impact of more than 1 billion euros on its exports to the U.S. Among the most affected products are olive oil, table olives, wine, citrus or mussels. I would like to stress the importance of not starting a trade war between the United States and the European Union, given the potential consequences it can have for both economies. We must continue to bet on free trade as a growth mechanism. However, I am in favour of establishing more measures to support affected producers, especially through advocacy companies to help operators strengthen their presence in the US market or even open themselves up to new markets. We must be strong and use the mechanisms provided for in the CAP to protect Spanish farmers and to ensure that the tariffs imposed do not result in job losses and loss of competitiveness in the European agricultural sector.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the crisis of the WTO Appellate Body (2019/2918(RSP)).

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we are continuing on the WTO and a very serious situation, and that is why I welcome this debate. I would like to thank the European Parliament for taking the initiative to have a resolution on the Appellate Body crisis.
